summary: Hoard of 100 denarii: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-192).
The hoard originally comprised an undetermined amount of denarii. Only 12 coins are known: Trajan-Marcus Aurelius (114-175 AD).
47 de denarii with very poor information on the contents: Hadrian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).

A hoard of 178 Roman denarii, ranging from Marc Antony to Hadrian, found at the bottom of an earthenware jar in 1934, in a field south of Louth, Lincolnshire. Among the coins, one hybrid of Domitian with a reverse of Hadrian (now in the BM).
disposition: Lincoln City and County Museum (part); British Museum (part)

summary: 90 sestertii: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194).

According to Carlier, the hoard filled a hat(!) and is likely to have originally comprised at least 600 pieces.Although originally comprising more than 600 coins, the hoard was quickly dispersed. The forest administration confiscated 98 coins, Carlier bought approximately 300, the brothers Gérin took 40, while Demonteville, the librarian of Douai, took 100 sestertii, 5 or 6 'middle bronze' and 12 silver coins: Tiberius (Divus Augustus) - Commodus) (AD 181-190).
52 denarii of Hadrian of only three RIC types: RIC 119, 256, 339 (AD 134-138). Found together with some bits of amber.
A hoard of denarii, found in a field from 1962 until 2001. FMRD lists 67 coins (Trajan - Pertinax).
The hoard comprised 144 silver and two gold coins dated between 32-31 BC and AD 124-128, buried in a clay juglet.
129 bronze coins (1 provincial) unknown denomination: Vespasian - Antoninus Pius (AD 157-158)
Unknown original number of coins. 36 denarii were recovered: Trajan - Marcus Aurelius (AD 169-170).
In 1908, 6 denarii (Domitian to Antoninus Pius) were found lying together at the entrance of cellar 208 (in the vicus surrounding the Roman fort).
More than 100 denarii found in a ceramic vessel - metal detecting - within an ancient settlement. The latest coins are from Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
53 denarii: Galba - Antoninus Pius (AD 156-157).
disposition: Zemaljski muzej Bosne i Hercegovine (National Museum of Bosnia and Herzegovina) Sarajevo (32 coins) - 1981

summary: Originally 16 denarii, 15 preserved: Domitian - Septimius Severus(AD 193-211); silver weight: 42.63 g. (15 coins).
Hoard of 1000 denarii of the Antonines and 6 aurei of Faustina I, Marcus Aurelius and Faustina II.
272 denarii: Tiberius - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194); silver weight: 813.04 g
disposition: Complexul Muzeal "Iulian Antonescu", Bacău, Romania; inv.nos. 7008-7236

summary: Unknown initial number of coins. 22 denarii: Republic - Antoninus Pius (AD 139)
disposition: National History Museum of Romania, Bucharest

summary: A hoard of 243 Roman imperial denarii and their barbarian imitations was discovered by a treasure hunter in late 2017 or early 2018 in the Sumy region. On January, 11, 2018, information and photos of the coins were published on the Ukrainian treasure hunting forum Violity. The finder reported that the coins were allegedly found in his vegetable garden (a common formula of Ukrainians treasure hunters to conceal information about the place of discovery). Photos of the coins have not been preserved. Forum experts have identified the coins as “standard”, singling out only separate coins of Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius (incl. for Faustina I), Marcus Aurelius (for Faustina II and for Lucilla) and Didius Julianus. In January 2018, the coins were sold in several lots at the Violity auction.

An ensemble of 6 denarii (incl. Vespasian, Hadrian with Clementia on the reverse, 2 Antoninus, 2 Crispina), found during excavations at the broch of Lingro, 1870-71, in different parts of the outbuildings [i.e. of the broch], that may have come from a scattered hoard.
13 denarii from a discovery in the surroundings of the city: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 177-178).
A roll of eight corroded and partly worn AE coins (Trajan to Lucius Verus), found within the group of furnaces north of the west gate (inside the Roman fort), in front of the furnace 5
11 denarii found with a cooking pot: Vespasian - Hadrian (AD 134-135)
20 denarii: Hadrian - Commodus (AD 191).
73 bronze coins: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 180-192).
27 bronze coins (Tiberius - Marcus Aurelius) found in an ash layer covered by a stone and interpreted as a votive deposit.
Hoard of sestertii found while dredging the harbor: Hadrian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 177-178).
Unknown originally number of coins. 90 coins are kept in the collection of the National History Museum in Bucharest: Mark Antony – Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus) (AD 161-169).
141 denarii: Republic – Commodus (AD 180-192).
(200) 17 sestertii: Trajan - Marcus Aurelius (AD 11-180).
237 coins: 11 denarii, 226 bronzes (most of them sestertii): Trajan - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).

Eleven coins found over three private searches; one in 2009, four in 2011 and six in 2012 (described as "being stacked"). The 11 coins are dated from Nerva to Antoninus Pius. It is not certain that all 11 coins are part of a hoard, but it is likely as they have been found within a small geographical area.
A hoard of 121 denarii (Nero - Marcus Aurelius), found at the edge of the gravel pit northeast of Schwepnitz, approx. 0.3 km east of the Schwepnitz - Gottschdorf road.
514 imperial bronze coins: Nerva - Commodus (AD 180-192).
disposition: Collection J. Marcello, Soprintendenza Archeologica di Padova, Italy

summary: 28 bronze coins found near a skeleton: 27 provincial coins minted on Cyprus (uncertain mint under Augustus and Tiberius; Koinon of Cyprus for Claudius, Vespasian, and Trajan) and 1 sestertius of Trajan (AD 114-117).

A hoard of 757 Roman Imperial denarii and a silver ingot was discovered by a treasure hunter on January 11, 2018 in the Lviv region. Information about the find, the silver ingot and a general photo of the bunch uncleaned coins were published on the Ukrainian treasure hunter forum Violity on 11 and 12 January 2018. According to the finder, the hoard was discovered in the forest at a depth of 30-40 cm. Initially a few slipped coins were found, and then the rest of the hoard. Among the coins, a silver ingot (ca. 8.7x1.5 cm) and a fragment of pottery were found. Only photos of 17 coins and the silver ingot were published separately. The further fate of the hoard is unknown, however, most probably it was sold at the Violity auction. Coins: Nerva (1), Hadrian (4), Hadrian (Aelius) (1), Hadrian (Antoninus Pius) (1), Antoninus Pius (3), Antoninus Pius (Diva Faustina I) (1), Marcus Aurelius (3), Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus) (1), Marcus Aurelius (Lucilla) (1), Commodus (1), no information (740).
55 bronze coins with unknown findspot except for the mention north Portugal
The hoard comprised 171 aurei and 1 denarius from Nero to Marcus Aurelius.
disposition: União de Bancos Portugueses. Fundação Millenium, Oporto, Romania

summary: The hoard comprised a greyware vessel containing 122 denarii from Otho to Septimius Severus with a tpq of AD 193. There were also 'some illegible issues' and three silver spoons.

Around 400 denarii found during archaeological excavations. Only 25 denarii provide information on issuers: Domitian - Commodus (AD 180-192). Together with the coins was also a silver bar of 155g and, possible, a brooch.
disposition: Friends of Science Society, Poznań, Poland (25 coins)

summary: Found during excavations. Assemblage of 10 aes coins, Domitian to Commodus, in a roadside ditch, spread out over ca. 5x1 metres. The hoard comprised 3 dupondii and 7 asses.
272 coins found with a ceramic vessel: Claudius I - Hadrian (AD 119-122).
Hughenden - Upon Piggott Common: 24 Roman coins (copper) discovered 1795 in throwing up a bankan earthen vessel about 18 inches below the surface.
The hoard comprised 17 silver coins (Vespasian-Hadrian) and 43 bronze coins.
Six coins of Alexandria: Nero 1, Vespasian 2, Hadrian 2, Lucius Verus 1. No information about site or circumstances.

A small hoard of six Roman imperial denarii: Vespasian — Hadrian (AD 117-138) was discovered by treasure hunter in 2014, possibly in Rivne region. Information about the find and photos of the coins were published on November 28, 2016, on the Ukrainian treasure hunting forum Violity. The finder reported that the find was discovered about two years ago before publication in a ploughed field. The coins were collected from a small area, but he did not probe to sondage on the place of find, assuming that he would find new finds after each ploughing. However, he has not found any new coins at the site in two years. All coins are equally well preserved (minimal worn) and close chronologically, which allows them to be considered as one deposit. In December 2016 and January 2018, the coins were sold on Violity auction. Coins: Vespasian (Titus) (1), Titus (2), Hadrian (3).

In 1955 during ground work at a cemetery children randomly found a Roman hoard with a large quantity of coins. All coins except for the 10 described here (sestertii ranging from Vespasian to Marcus Aurelius) were dispersed. The true size of the hoard is unknown.
52 denarii: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194).
Group of 15 first and second century copper alloy coins metal-detected from the same field over a period of years between 1990 and 1998.
7 sestertii: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-192) found in a building from the military vicus.
disposition: Centrul de Studii de Istorie și Arheologie, Timișoara, Romania; inv.no. 237/2005

summary: 5-6 silver and bronze coins. Among them one piece of Antoninus Pius.
The hoard comprised around 500 tetradrachms and at least 2000 denarii from the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).
Circa 150 coins found with a ceramic vessel. Only 5 sestertii are known: Hadrian 1, Antoninus Pius 1, Faustina I (Diva) 1, 2 uncertain issuer.
The hoard comprised 20 denarii from Vespasian to Commodus (AD 180-192) and was found inside an ostrich egg.
29 aurei including coins of Trajan, Hadrian, Sabina, Antoninus Pius, Lucius Verus. Together were found two gold fingerings.
7 aurei: 6 Hadrian, 1 Sabina (AD 132-134)
disposition: Museum of Iron Gates Region Drobeta-Turnu Severin, Romania

summary: 80 denarii from Mark Anthony to Marcus Aurelius with a tpq of AD 165.
15 of the sestertii from a larger hoard were identified by S. Bottin. The hoard was originally located in Bellaing in error.
25 silver denarii were found along with a considerable amount of human bone, interpreted as being an indicator of a battlefield site.
Unknown originally number of coins. Only 20 denarii were documented: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius/Commodus (Crispina (AD 161-180).
Hoard of 125 denarii. The large majority belong to Trajan including the title DACICVS. The hoard was found with two silver vessels embedded each other.
(10kg?) 18 denarii: Domitian - Commodus (AD 180-183).
Hoard of few kilos of denarii. Only 6 coins are known: Hadrian, Antoninus Pius 4, Lucilla.
The hoard was found during excavations and comprised two piles of 20 base silver coins (plated denarii?) from Augustus to Antoninus Pius or Marcus Aurelius.
The hoard comprised a small iron safe containing two aureii and a variety of jewellery.
disposition: Musée des Antiquités de Rouen, France

summary: A hoard of Roman aurei and their imitations was discovered in an earthen pot: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 145-161).

A hoard of 111 Roman imperial denarii was found by five treasure hunters in 2013 in Chernivtsi region. Information about the find and photos of some of the coins of the hoard were published by one of the finders on January 20, 2014 on the Ukrainian treasure hunter forum Violity. According to the finder, the hoard was found late at night, but there is no more detailed information about the further circumstances of the find. Judging by the information from the treasure hunter, the bulk of the coins in the hoard were denarii of Vespasian, Trajan and Hadrian, although there was also a coin of Galba, several denarii of Nerva, and 10-12 coins of Antoninus Pius and Faustina (I or II). In the photographs posted with the hoard information, there are images of 26 whole and five fragments of denarii (Vespasian, Terva, Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius) – these were probably some of the coins that the informant found. The further fate of the coins in the hoard is unknown.

The hoard comprised a 'ceramic vessel containing approximately 20 kilos of Roman bronze coins (sestertii, dupondii and asses). Of 872 examples, only 423 were identified.': Vespasian - Septimius Severus for Clodius Albinus (Caesar) (AD 193-196).
disposition: Museé de Rouen, France (600 coins) (Inv. III, 2, p. 56, no. 1921)

summary: Two aurei, Domitian (Caesar), Marcus Aurelius (Caesar) found in sequential years, in the same forest. Close chronological range.

The hoard comprised 2,077 bronze coins along with bronze implements and scrap from a bronze foundry. Mostly quandrantes and semisses but also including Greek provincial, Greek, Republican up to 5th century AD
disposition: Heberden Coin Room, AShmolean Museum, Oxford, Great Britain

summary: Hoard found with an amphora: 2 aurei, 2,804 denarii, 2 bronzes: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 166). Together was found a ceramic lamp.
disposition: Private collections: A. Ancona,F. Gnecchi (365 coins), M. Anti (1,080 coins) (in 1887)

summary: 50 denarii found in the debris from a house foundation: Mark Antony - Marcus Aurelius (AD 169).
disposition: Kärntner Landsmannschaft, Klagenfurt, Austria (46 coins); private collection (2 coins), lost (unknown number)

summary: The hoard comprised a ceramic urn containing 50 corroded, worn, illegible Roman coins, with the exception being two sestertii of Hadrian and Antoninus Pius.
The hoard comprised approximately 250 sestertii dating to the second century AD and weighing between 5 and 6kg.
Hoard of 35 Roman imperial bronzes: Antoninus Pius - Commodus (AD 180-192).
disposition: M.K. Ciurlionis National Museum of Art, Kaunas, Lithuania

summary: Some silver coins found in a garden. Only one denarius of Hadrian and one of Commodus were documented.
Hoard of at least 46 denarii: Nero – Commodus (AD 180-192). Possible, part of the hoard from Strunga.
disposition: National History Museum, Bucharest, Romania (25 coins)

summary: Hoard of 17 denarii (Mark Antony - Augustus) and 29 sestertii (Nerva - Hadrian) (AD 117-138).
6 denarii to AD 161 - "hoard 2" Davies 2000. From an occupation layer in range 3 of structure 1, Pickfords Garage site. Scattered in a small area with no evidence of a container.
Hoard of 800 denarii. Among them, three pieces of Pertinax
101 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Vitellius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 175).
13 bronze coins: 4 sestertii, 2 dupondii, 7 asses: Claudius I - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-175).
disposition: Muzeul de Istorie Națională și Arheologie, Constanța, Romania; inv.nos. 64682-64694

summary: The hoard comprised a vessel filled with sestertii, which were shared amongst the finders. After an investigation by the Gendarmarie, 59 were found. In 1980, illegal metal detecting on the site recovered a further 5 coins which are likely to be part of the hoard.
The hoard comprised at least 54 silver coins dated between the Roman Republic and Hadrian (AD 117-138).
76 denarii: Vespasian - Hadrian (AD 134-138).
disposition: Collection Baron of Senzeilles (76 coins), in 1890

summary: The hoard comprised 14 sestertii from Trajan to Commodus and was found placed next to two greyware ceramic vessels.
Unknown initial number of denarii. 11 denarii provided information on the issuers: Trajan - Commodus (AD 183-184).
disposition: Zasadniczej Szkoły Zawodowej w Krasniku Fabrycznym, Poland (1 coin)

summary: Hoard containing, among others, an aureus of Antoninus Pius for Faustina I (Diva) and an imitation of Tiberius aureus.
It comprised c. 500 denarii found with a vessel:Domitian - Commodus (AD 180-192).

Lake Borresø surrounds the medieval castle of Lilleborg. During the draining of the lake in 1832 a mixed gold- and silver hoard was found. "Some" gold fingerrings, of which only one was recovered, and "several" denarii, of which sixteen were handed over to the later National Museum, were found "as if packed into something which had now disappeared".
A hoard of 30 denarii and 1 as (Republic - Trajan) found by the west wall of a plaster layer during an excavation on Reismühler Straße.

11 AR denarii to AD 122. Latest coin is type of Hadrian-Fortuna referring to the departure of the emperor on his great expedition, AD 121-5. RIC assigns date range of AD 119-122.Addenda of 3 AR denarii to 117 in 2014 included here.
Around 1,460 denarii - a number established based on an average weight of 3 g/coin (4.510 g)- comprising Republican issues to Commodus (AD 1180-192). 19 coins entered the collection of the Ermitage.
disposition: The State Hermitage Museum, St. Petersburg, Russia (19 coins)

summary: A hoard of 2000+ silver coins (mainly Cappadocian didrachms, drachms and hemidrachms; two Lycian drachms; c.100 denarii) deposited c. 185 and found in four bronze pots in the village of Sor, near Kayseri. It was dispersed in several batches in the art trade. A large portion was published by W. Metcalf (932 coins) and another by W. Weiser (178 coins, the 'Münchner Fundkomplex'). In addition, 140 coins were recorded in Paris in 1980 (RPC III, p. 376). They consisted in 26 denarii (Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius), and 114 coins from Caesarea (Vespasian - Commodus)
36 denarii found in the military amphitheater: Mark Antony - Marcus Aurelius (AD 166).
disposition: Museum Carnuntinum, Bad-Deutsch Altenburg, Austria (29 coins); 7 coins lost

summary: Hoard of unknown number of denarii. Only for 7 cois is given Information on the issuers: Antoninus Pius - Marcus Aurelius/Commodus (AD 172-192).
Denarius hoard consisting of 14 denarii found with metal detectoring. Galba to Antoninus Pius.
15 sestertii: Domitian - Commodus (AD 180-192).
9 denarii: Vespasian - Hadrian (AD 128-130).
200-150 coins found with a ceramic vessel. Only 48 denarii are known today: Nero – Hadrian (AD 125-128).
162 sestertii and 1 as. The origins of this hoard is doubtful. It is also possible that it contains 2 sestertii from Marcus Aurelius and 2 imitations of a double sestertius from Postumus.

The hoard comprised 60kg of sestertii mixed with some middle bronzes (2,500-3000 coins). Only 26 sestertii and 1 dupondius were preserved: Trajan - Commodus (AD 98-117). The hoard was found by a worker, planting a vineyard.
disposition: History Museum, Louresse-Rochemenier, France (10 coins); finder (17 coins)

summary: A 'valuable find of gold and silver coins', of which one coin was a denarius of Antoninus Pius (broken and much defaced), found on Dewsbury Moor, near remains of two Roman querns.
12 coins: 1 denarius, 11 sestertiiTrajan - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180). Found 800 m westward from the hoard Koropie 2008 1. Together were found a bronze brooch and a horn shape bronze ring
disposition: Laboratory of Archeology, Historical Sociology and Cultural Heritage, Faculty of Sociology, St. Petersburg State University, Russia

summary: Hoard of 314 large Roman imperial bronze coins: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-192).
Coins found in sarcophagus no. 905: 34 gold and silver coins: 3 Aurei: Nero 2, Hadrian 1; 14 denarii: Augustus 12,Uncertain (Augustus?) 2; 1 hemidrachm of Hadrian, and 16 drachms of Gotarzes II.
Around 70-80 denarii, 53 were recovered: Republic - Hadrian (AD 117-138).
The hoard comprised 3 Roman Provincial coins: (Cassandrea, Philippi, Koinon of Macedonia), found in grave 589 in Ierissos.
15 sestertii of which Antoninus Pius 1, Faustina II 1, Commodus 1 were found by fishermen in a dune.

168 Alexandrian provincial bronze coins: Vespasian - Antoninus Pius (AD 148-149). Found in the ground. All drachms, only briefly described. Oldest Vespasian, among the other coins are mentioned "interesting types of Antinous, Sabina, Aurelius Caesar, also some of the rare 'nome' types and few of the famous zodiacal series struck in the eighth year of Antoninus Pius."

A small hoard of 15 Roman imperial denarii and one Lycian drachm: Vespasian – Commodus (AD 180-192) was found in April 2017 in Khmelnytskyi region. Information and general photo of the coins of the hoard were published on April, 29, 2017 on the Ukrainian treasure hunting forum Violity. By the treasure hunter himself, the hoard was called the “purse of denarii”. The coins have a fairly good preservation (weak wear). In early May 2017, the coins were sold at the auction Violity and their fate is unknown.
Unknown number of denarii. 5 pieces entered the museum collection in Kazanlak: Domitian 1, Trajan 4.
disposition: Museum of History, Kazanlak, Bulgaria; inv.no. 3994-3998

summary: 37 denarii part of a hoard found on the same field like GANDARVE 1927 and 1928, now, in a private collection: Vespasian (Domitian Caesar) - Commodus (AD 192); silver weight: 101.03 g.
disposition: Private collection Axel O. Larsson, Stockholm

summary: The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 840 well-preserved sestertii, of which 808 were identified by Auvray. The composition of this hoard varies slightly in lists compiled by Ledru and Cauvin. L'annuaire l'An VIII mentions coins of Septimius Severus and of Caracalla from the same parish. It is possible that these were also a part of the hoard, although they have not been added to the database record.

A hoard of at least 50 Roman Imperial denarii and a silver and gold buckle were discovered by a treasure hunter no later than 2021, probably in Zhytomyr region. Information about the hoard and general photo of the coins with the buckle were published in one of the groups on Facebook, dedicated to treasure hunting on November 1, 2021. One of the group members (Vasyl Ugrynchuk of Volodarsk in Zhitomyr region) reported that the hoard was discovered by his acquaintances (possibly also from Zhytomyr region). On the photo denarii of Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius, Commodus can be recognized. The buckle is quite massive (ca. 5-7 cm), on the clip there is a gold plate with ornamentation. The further fate of the hoard is unknown.
A hoard of 20 denarii (Vitellius - Marcus Aurelius), found in a Roman house, in a room next to the furnace of the hypocaust.
The hoard comprised more than 400 worn coins including issues of Nero, Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius and Crispina.
28 billon Alexandrian tetradrachms: Claudius I - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-139). Probably a hoard, found during excavations.
disposition: Museum of Anthropology of the University of California, Berkeley, USA (1935)

summary: A hoard of 52 denarii (Vespasian - Antoninus Pius) and 1 drachm of Amisus, found during the breaking up of soil in Lausitz. The hoard might have been associated with a series of 7 cremation graves.
5 sestertii ranging from Antoninus Pius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 173-174). Part of a larger hoard.
disposition: Narodni muzej, Ljubljana, Slovenia; 5 coins; dispersed.

summary: 10 bronze coins found during archaeological excavations: 5 sestertii, 2 dupondii, 3 asses: Claudius I - Hadrian (AD 117-138).
disposition: History Museum, Svištov, Bulgaria; inv.nos OF 3583-3588; HCF, inv.no. 886-889

summary: (ca. 600) 569 denarii: Mark Antony - Commodus (AD 180-192)
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. no. ХХХІІІ - 398 coins

summary: A bronze jug containing 160 aurei, found on site 29 in Corbridge. Two bronze coins were found filling the narrow neck of the jug, where they had been placed, to act as a stopper to the narrow neck.
14 copper coins, reported as dated between possibly 69 and 117 AD, but inter alia Vespasian, Domitian, Hadrian, so 69-138 in any case.
The hoard was found in a burial which contained 'two middle bronzes of "Antoninus" and one of Faustina II, as well as a unidentified sestertius.
287 bronze coins: Augustus - Marcus Aurelius/Commodus for Crispina (Augusta) (AD 178-183).
It comprised 200 sestertii from Antoninus Pius to Commodus (AD 180-192) found with a ceramic vessel.
The hoard comprised 31 bronze coins from Augustus to Marcus Aurelius, not further described.
Unknown originally number of coins. 27 denarii are kept at the Institute of Archaeology in Bucharest: Trajan – Commodus (AD 185).
disposition: Institute of Archaeology ”V. Parvan”, Bucharest, Romania (27 coins).

summary: Around 200 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Trajan - Didius Julianus (AD 193).
disposition: Münzkabinett, Staatliche Museen zu Berlin, Germany (2 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised 60 silver coins from the reigns of Nero to Hadrian, deposited during the Bar Kokhba Revolt (AD 132-136). These coins were: 42 denarii (Vespasian to Hadrian), 10 tetradrachms and 1 tridrachm from Antioch (Nero to Trajan), 6 tridrachms and 1 drachm of Trajan from Arabia.
The hoard comprised 65 bronze coins dated between 294-283 BC and AD 117-138.
(700) 612 silver coins: 610 denarii, 2 drachmas: Nero-Commodus (AD 184-185).
A hoard of 74 denarii (Republic- Hadrian), found in 1854 approx. 1 km north of the place, 100 m from the street next to Dahnsdorf behind a hill in a ravine.

A group of 19 Roman silver coins (of the Emperors Nero, Domitian, Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius, Commodus, and the Empress Faustina), found while ploughing at Pitcullo in Fife, presented to the Society of Antiquaries of Scotland in 1781. The 19 coins have not been located in NMAS, Edinburgh
255 denarii found and sent to the Ministry of Finance. The coins were found with pieces of an urn during the removal of stones from a field.

The hoard comprised '100s of bronze coins (150 coins according to Angot). The majority were of Trajan, Hadrian and of Antoninus Pius. In the 1860s, the vicar of Fougerolles, Charles Pointeau, examined 72 coins and Chevallier acquired 'a good number, all large bronzes of Trajan to Commodus'. It has therefore been assumed that this hoard was made up of sestertii.

The deposit was found under a second century occupation layer in the central part of the Gallo-Roman spring sanctuary and comprised 4 sestertii from Trajan to Antoninus Pius and two asses of Antoninus Pius with a tpq of AD 153 to 154.
10 coins found in the bottom of a bowl in locus 29.
The hoard comprised a 'vessel containing 60 aurei, of which 17 were bought by the Cabinet des Médailles and 2 by the Musée de Rouen, although neither acquisition can be found today.'
68 denarii: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 150-151).

46 denarii (Vitellius to Antoninus Pius) discovered in a farm yard. Wynn Williams (1875) observed that the hoard was discovered at ground level, having been exposed by traffic and other activity in the farm yard: "The surface was very hard, and they were actually sticking out of the ground on their edges. Judging from a pen and ink sketch sent me, they must have been closely packed together side by side... evidently the road had got scraped and worn down by wheels, and thus exposed them; but they had been noticed before any one took the trouble to pick them up."
2 denarii - Antoninus Pius for Diva Faustina I and Marcus Aurelius found together with 4 gold bracteates.
36 sestertii, but only 16 are identified: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-183).
79 denarii found circa 25 m from the Jerzmanowice 2005 hoard and one more denarius found in 2009. Most likely one owner: Hadrian - Septimius Severus (Julia Domna) (AD 193-196).

Found in the garden of one of the villagers. Consisted of denarii (quantity unknown), which were in a pot. The coins were taken by villagers. V. Lyaskoronsky in 1926 saw only two denarii from this hoard (Antoninus Pius and Marcus Aurelius). In 1964, L. Pobal examined the probable place of the find, but did not find additional information about the hoard.
(c. 3000-3500) 474 denarii: Mark Antony - Marcus Aurelius (AD 168)
30 denarii: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180), latest coin, AD 156-157.
disposition: Rijksmuseum van Oudheden Leiden, Netherlands; inv.no. 17379

summary: The hoard comprised 5 drachms of Trajan minted in Bostra (AD 113).

A small hoard of 4 Roman imperial denarii: Marcus Aurelius - Didius Julianus (AD 193) was discovered by a treasure hunter in early July 2023 somewhere in Cherkasy region. Information about the find and photos of the coins were published on the Ukrainian treasure hunter forum Violity July 3, 2023. The finder reported that the coins were discovered “in one small pit”. The further fate of the hoard is unknown.
37 sestertii found during rescue excavations. 32 coins were found in a ceramic jug and 5 next to it: Vespasian - Commodus (Divus Marcus Aurelius) (AD 180).
Three denarii found in a funerary urn together with an amber bead and a wire link ring: Domitian, Hadrian Marcus Aurelius (Divus) (AD 180).

Iron Age British silver and copper-alloy coins, Roman Republican silver denarii, Roman imperial denarii, Roman copper-alloy coins, totalling 465 specimens. The assemblage seems to constitute continuous votive deposition rather than a hoard.

Arm purse containing 63 coins (3 aurei and 60 denarii), ranging from the late Republic to Hadrian, found while quarrying stones. Each of the gold coins was wrapped up in a separate piece of greenish leather or vellum, which was still quite tough and strong.
disposition: Clayton Memorial Museum, Chesters (purse). The coins are said to have been given to the Blackgate Museum, Newcastle, but have not been located there

summary: Unknown originally number of coins. Six denarii of Marcus Aurelius were seen.
Originally 390, 371 preserved: Vitellius - Septimius Severus (AD 194-195); silver weight: 965.17 g.

The hoard comprised 5 sestertii, dupondii or asses from Tiberius to Commodus and was found in association with a key handle, an incense burner, two statues (one being of Mercury) and a statue base. The remains of a Roman building, the function of which was undetermined, was found close by.
175 silver coins: 173 denarii, 1 quinarius and 1 drachm: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Stadtmuseum, Neunkirchen (165 coins), private collection? (10 coins), Austria; lost (unknown no.)

summary: (32) 2 denarii: Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180)
74 denarii: Vespasian – Commodus (AD 180-192).
5, or possibly up to 8 aurei, from Nero to Diva Faustina I (AD 161). 5 aurei are listed here, and the other 3 ones (Bland/Loriot 343-5) are listed separately as single gold finds.
disposition: Harris Museum, Preston (part); Blackburn museum (2 coins)

summary: Unknown originally number of denarii found with a ceramic vessel. 63 coins were recovered, 62 denarii, 1 drachm: Vitellius – Marcus Aurelius (AD 162-163).
1,446 denarii found during construction activity: Republic - Marcus Aurelius/Commodus (AD 177-192).
disposition: Münzkabinett, Kunsthistorischen Museum, Vienna, Austria (964 coins)

summary: Few hundreds, 150 were documented: Republic - Commodus (AD 186-187).
The hoard comprised 'a vessel containing 100 sestertii': Antoninus Pius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
181 denarii found in the foundations of a prehistoric house: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 197-198); silver weight: 491.23 g. Found together with sherds and animal bones.

A small hoard of 21 Roman imperial denarii (from Domitian to Commodus) and three bronze artefacts was found by a treasure hunter in March 2016 somewhere in Central Ukraine, probably in Cherkassy region. On March 10, 2016, on the Ukrainian treasure hunting forum Violity was published information about the hoard and a photo of the coins and items from it (the finder identified the deposit as a “purse of denarii”). There is no information about the conditions of the find. The coins have heavy wear, one of the coins has strong oxide traces. The bronze items are rectangular in shape and are most likely belt plate: two measure 4.5x0.7cm and one (with six rivets) measures 4.3x1.3cm. In March 2016 the hoard was sold at the Violity auction, and the further fate of the coins is unknown.

1590 bronze coins (1452 Dium, 47 koinon of Thessaly, 39 koinon of Macedonia, 13 Thessalonica, 7 Philippi, 2 Edessa, 2 Corinth, 1 Amphipolis, 1 Magydus, 1 Tralleis, 10 uncertain, and 15 Roman bronzes), ranging from Claudius to Antoninus Pius, found in the foundation level besides the west wall of the first (western) room excavated at the place of the former sanctuary of Zeus Olympios, next to two other hoards (Dion 1998 and Dion 2000). All three hoards were buried in clay vases. The exact function of the area where the hoards were found is unclear, but the hellenistic sanctuary of Zeus Olympios had been transformed in Roman times, the wall of the temenos built over, and a theatre established.
A hoard of two Antonine sestertii and several items of gold jewellery, found in grave 23 in the western cemetery of Pella.
Unknown original number of denarii, 69 preserved: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 168); silver weight: 194 g.
The hoard comprised a terracotta vessel containing approximately 50 sestertii of Trajan, Hadrian and Antoninus Pius. The hoard was found on the Mortrais farm.

A Roman coin hoard of 80-100 denarii was unearthed in Samenheim. The precise find location and circumstances are not further ascertainable. The bulk of the find is lost. Only 20 denarii, ranging from Nero to Hadrian, now part of a private collection, are preserved. It is possible that these 20 coins may represent the full chronological coverage of the original find.
(460) 452 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: M. Antony - Marcus aurelius (AD 176-180).
22 bronze coins found together: Obol, prutahs, local, provincial issues: Ptolemy VIII Physcon - Antoninus Pius (AD 158-159).
60 denarii found, probably, with a ceramic vessel: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194).
Three aurei found at the bottom of "an old wall": Faustina I, Faustina II under Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius (Caesar). The hoard was found by a farmer.
12 denarii: Republic – Marcus Aurelius (Commodus Augustus) (AD 178). Some doubts have been expressed as the coins are now in a private collection.
Unknown number of Roman bronze coins, only 3 pieces are known: Augustus, Nero, Hadrian
Four denarii (Vespasian - Trajan), allegedly found in 1845 in or around Minden. It is not impossible that these belonged to the Minden I find, made in 1844.
102 billon Alexandrian tetradrachms found during excavations in the foundation of a house: Claudius I (Messalina) - Antoninus Pius (AD 149-150).
Originally, 1,500 denarii and a drachm found with a clay vessel. 1,391 coins preserved: Nero - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194); silver weight: 3,924.6 g. (1.391 coins).
Two aurei depicting Lucius Verus (AD 161-169). No description. Callu-Loriot record these coins as single finds, however, same findspot, same coin issuer (quite rare).

"In 1847 a small pot containing 8 Roman coins - a silver denarius of Trajan and 7 bronze coins, including one of Trajan - was found in cutting through a hedge or earth bank on the boundary between the parishes of Upton and Withiel Florey. Two of the coins are in the Spencer G Perceval collection" (Pastscape)
918 silver coins found with a ceramic vessel: 916 denarii, 1 drachm, 1mitation denarius: Nero – Septimius Severus (AD 193-194).

469 (or more?) silver coins of Caesarea in Cappadocia found with a ceramic vessel. These range from Nero to Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus) (AD 161-169). The hoard also included one denarius of Augustus and a barbarous imitation of a stater of Lysimachus.
disposition: National Museum of Georgia; National Museum of Abkhazia (91 coins); Pushkin Museum of Fine Arts in Moscow, Russia (104 coins)

summary: Initially, there were 1,500 aurei. 144 aurei studied: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-162). Together were found one gold and two silver ingots.
Hoard of 120 coins: 2 aurei, 118 denarii: Titus - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Museo de San Isidro, Los Orígenes de Madrid

summary: 2 denarii found on manor field: C. Porcius Cato, Hadrian (119-122).
disposition: Museum of Moravia, Brno, Czech Republic

summary: 97 coins: 1 denarius and 96 bronzes found concentrated around an earthenware dish within a level of a building: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 166-167). The coins were found together with a brooch, as well as several pieces of pottery and nails.
62 denarii: Nero - Hadrian (AD 134-138).
A hoard of 150 denarii found in a ceramic vessel, covered by another ceramic vessel: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 193).
Unknown initial number of coins: 28 denarii: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 166); silver weight: 54.2-84.4g.
disposition: Regional History Museum, Vratsa, Bulgaria; inv.no. M I 233-250

summary: Unknown initial number of coins. 244 denarii: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-175)
Around 150 denarii and a drachm. Only 43 coins provide information on issuers: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
Unknown originally number of coins. Most likely there is just one hoard found here and 36 denarii are known: Vespasian – Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
726 denarii: Nero - Commodus (AD 187-192).
8 denarii found on a field: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (Lucilla) (AD 161-180).

The hoard comprised 12 aes coins (sestertii and dupondii) ranging from Domitian to Marcus Aurelius Caesar. They were recovered during the excavation of a inhumation burial (tomb 5/1966) in the necropolis and were interpreted as the contents of a purse.
disposition: Ufficio dei beni culturali, Bellinzona (12 coins)

summary: 18 denarii found on a field: Otho - Hadrian (AD 128-136).

The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing at least 11 coins (10 sestertii and 1 dupondius) found during construction work. The pot and 11 coins were given to the Museum Laufen, where, ca. 2014, only these 11 coins could be identified: Domitian (1 coin), Trajan (1 coin), Hadrian (5 coins), Antoninus Pius (1 dupondius), M. Aurelius/L. Verus (1 coins), Commodus (1 coin), Crispina (1 coin).
91 tetradrachms of Alexandria in a small pot found during excavations. Range: Claudius I - Marcus Aurelius (AD 169-170).
disposition: 12 in London, 5 in Oxford. The rest dispersed. Detailed list in Oxford

summary: 119 Alexandrian billon tetradrachms: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 155-156) Found during excavations.
disposition: Museum of Anthropology of the University of California, Berkeley, USA (1935), inv.no. 445

summary: A hoard of ca. 639 Roman denarii, found in a 'crock' at Upwood Farm, near Handley, while digging up an allotment garden in 1877. A list of 571 coins (by emperor only, see NC 1950, pp. 311-312) was made by Dr. Blackmore who himself received 464 coins of the hoard. His list is as follows: Marcus Antonius 20, Nero 2, Galba 2, Otho 4, Vitellius 3, Vespasian 60, Titus 5, Domitian 31, Nerva 19, Trajan 55, Hadrian 78, Sabina 4, Aelius 4. Pius 79, Faustian I 44, Marcus Aurelius 63, Faustian II 23, Verus 14, Lucilla 13, Commodus 36, Crispina 5, Didius Iulianus 1, Severus 1, and Domna 1. What remains of these 464 coins is now preserved in the Dorchester Museum, but only 440 coins were catalogued by Roberston (NC 1950). These are all denarii (Mark Antony - Julia Domna), except for one Lycian drachm of Trajan.
110 denarii. Only 79 were recovered: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 193); silver weight: 202.4-323.4 g.
Around 100 denarii, 27 were studied: Nero – Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II) (AD 161-175).
20 sestertii and 1 as: Nero - Commodus (AD 180-192).
Group of 3 denarii: Nerva, Trajan, Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
2,250 denarii: Galba – Commodus (AD 180-192). No further details.

177 denarii with portraits of emperors from Vespasian to Trajan and two denarii of Mark Antony's 'legionary' series. The denarii were found with a ceramic vessel. The metal analyses, fresh minting loo-alike state of preservation for the large majority of the coins as well as the overweight for most of the coins reveal a 'hoard' of ancient counterfeited coins. The dating of coin type is based on the genuine prototype, otherwise, it looks that they were all minted in/after AD 116.
disposition: Museum of National Union, alba Iulia, Romania

summary: 6 denarii and 1 AE coin, ranging from Domitian to Commodus, found in cellar 207 between 1897 and 1908. These 7 coins of this find were not identified according to inventory number or type and could thus not be separated out from the list of single finds.
The hoard comprised 18 denarii, sestertii, dupondii and asses dating to the second century AD. TAF interprets the hoard as the contents of a purse lost when the building was demolished.
Hoard of at least 62 denarii. Only 13 are known: 8 republican among which Julius Caesar 1, Augustus 3, Hadrian 2.
Five 2nd century AD bronze coins, found in the area of the town hall.
Grup of two denarii: Hadrian, Antoninus Pius (AD 145-161); silver weight: 5.52 g.
18 denarii were discovered in the vicinity of the village of Raksha. Fifteen were documented: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 192).
Two denarii found on a field: Antoninus Pius, Commodus (AD 185).
22 denarii, part of a hoard: Vespasian - Clodius Albinus (AD 193-197).
55 billon drachms of Alexandria: Hadrian - Antoninus Pius (AD 154-155) found at floor level in a room during excavations of a house.
81 denarii found with a ceramic vessel while building a new house: Otho - Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II) (AD 161-180).
Hoard of denarii dispersed among locals. 88 denarii entered museums' collections. Six denarii can be entered at coin level: Antoninus Pius 1, Lucius Verus 1, Faustina II 3, Commodus 1.
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Warsaw (8 coins), Lublin (60 coins), Poland; Local museum, Lutsk (20 coins), Ukraine.

summary: The hoard comprised around 200 tetradrachms and 1,000 denarii from the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).
A hoard of ca. 300 denarii, found in 1842, during peat digging, close to the so-called 'Römerbrücke' in the Bourtanger Moor. The coins are now lost, except for two.
Unknown originally number of coins. 68 denarii are kept in the collection of the Library of the Romanian Academy: Republic – Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Coin Room, Library of the Romanian Academy, Bucharest, Romania (inv.nos. 29069-29136)

summary: The hoard was found on the West of "Blanche-Fontaine" district. A worker discovered an amphora with 1000 aurei, only 164 are now recorded from Augustus to Hadrian.
300 denarii: Augustus - Commodus (AD 180-192).

A hoard of at least 259 Roman imperial denarii was found by treasure hunters in 2016 in Cherkasy region. On October 4, 2016, a video of the process of sondage at the site where the hoard was found by seven treasure hunters was published on YouTube, on the “Sokrovische nacii” (“Treasure of the Nation”) channel. A few days earlier, another group of treasure hunters found a batch of denarii - 192 specimens - on the surface (up to 15 cm deep in an area of about 10x10 m) of a ploughed field. Then, on October 4, on this place was made several sondages (approx. 2-3x1 m), in which, at a depth of 40-50 cm was found another 67 coins (each of the seven treasure hunters took as many coins as they found). According to the assumption of one of the treasure hunters there may be more coins at this place. The video footage shows coins with traces of patina, among which can be distinguished denarii of Hadrian (incl. for Sabina), Antoninus Pius (incl. for Faustina I), Marcus Aurelius (incl. for Faustina II), Commodus. The further fate of the coins is unknown.

The hoard comprised 23 sestertii struck for Trajan, Hadrian, and Antoninus Pius. Discovered at a depth of 4 metres when a drainage ditch was being dug during road improvement works to the south of the railway station in Kiesen.
Hoard of 37 coins: 6 republican denarii, 1 imperial denarius, 25 sestertii, 1 dupondius, 4 asses: Republic - Antoninus Pius (AD 157-161).
A hoard of 257 denarii: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 175-176).
disposition: Museum, Dortmund (243 coins); the Ruhr Valley Museum in Schwerte and Fröndenberg (14 coins)

summary: Two denarii found above ground in 1921, assumed to have derived from a ditch dug at the site.
6 Roman imperial bronze coins. The latest one is a sestertius of Antoninus Pius: Gaius - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).

6 denarii found in the foundations of a prehistoric house: Trajan - Commodus (AD 191-192); silver weight: 10.46 g. Found together with Bronze fibula, bronze sheet, bronze bar, iron knife, iron mounting, fragment of glass vessel, glass paste bead, amber bead, potsherds.

Several hundreds coins (principally of Nerva, Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, and Faustina), found in 1842, while removing some sods from the surface of a piece of moss land. Three publications (see under references) list groups of coins belonging to this hoard. Some coins had marks indicating that the hoard had been buried in a bag of coarse cloth. One further denarius of Trajan in HCC, p. 34, no. 207, Glasgow.

The hoard was found at a natural spring and comprised votives (including numerous wooden statuettes) as well as '149 copper coins of Roman emprors'. 79 of these coins were identified. The others were illegible.
Hoard of 500 coins of the Bosporan kings: Ininthimeus, Rhescuporis IV and V.
99 denarii: Otho - Commodus (AD 182-183).
disposition: Museo Archeologico Nazionale, Ancona, Italy (inv. nos. 7395/22336 - 7493/22434)

summary: Grup of two denarii: Antoninus Pius, Antoninus Pius (Diva Faustina I); silver weight: 5.32 g.

Four denarii (Vespasian - Antoninus Pius), found at Aitnock fort (an Iron Age fort), situated on the summit of a cliff which rises about 60 feet perpendicularly from the waters of the Rye stream at the south-west angle of Hindog Glen near Dalry in Ayrshire. The coins had been wrapped in some material and were found in a layer of occupation.
c. 20 denarii: Vitellius - Hadrian (AD 117-138).
102 bronze coins found with an amphora and dispersed in the coin trade: Tiberius - Marcus aurelius (AD 161-180).
The hoard comprised 301 Alexandrian tetradrachms. 300 were of Nero with a single coin of Hadrian. They were acquired in Egypt by Dattari.
115 denarii: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194); silver weight: 354 g
735 denarii found with ceramic vessel and a textile bag: Nero – Septimius Severus (AD 195). Found together with a silver T-brooch within a Sarmatian settlement.
disposition: Numismatic Collection of the Institute of Archeology, Iași, inv. no. 323370 (the brooch)

summary: Hoard of 6 Roman coins, most likely denarii, including: Vespasian, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).

In 1900 the Hanauer museum acquired 44 denarii from an antique dealer in Büdingen, which obviously belonged to a find. The coins were supposedly found in 1899 in Marköbel during the construction of a house. The coins are today no longer present in the Hanauer museum. Coins range from Nero to Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus).
Unknown initial number of denarii. 27 coins provide information on issuers: Nerva - Commodus (AD 180-192).
Three denarii: Republic 1, Hadrian 1, Antoninus Pius 1 (AD 138-161).

A hoard of ca. 850 Alexandrian tetradrachms (Nero to Antoninus Pius) found at Amheida (Dakhla/Dakhleh oasis) in area 4, divided in three textile bags, on top of a mudbrick debris layer filling pit F90, immedialely adjacent to the temple of Thoth.
Hoard of 300-400 denarii. Only two coins are documented: Trajan, Antoninus Pius.
110 denarii found in the Principia from the legionary fortress: Mark Antony - Marcus Aurelius (AD 168).
disposition: Museum Carnuntinum, Bad Deutsch-Altenburg, Austria (108 coins).

summary: 21 bronze coins (Vespasian-Hadrian) published in am auction catalogue without details on the circumstances of discovery.

The hoard comprised 65 sestertii from Domitian to Commodus (AD 180-192). All the coins were very worn. Fragments of a ceramic vessel were found in association with the coins suggesting it was originally placed inside a pot.
The hoard comprised a broken ceramic vessel containing 30 bronze coins of Antoninus Pius. A bronze bell was found at the same findspot.

A hoard of ca. 1100 Roman imperial denarii: Trajan - Didius Julianus (AD 193) was allegedly discovered by a treasure hunter in the late 2010s near the town of Turbiv in the Vinnytsia region. The coins had a strong degree of wear. This information cannot be verified, as neither the coins themselves nor their photographs are available. The further fate of the hoard is unknown.

A hoard found in Barton Wood, consisting of nearly a gallon measure of Roman brass coins. The coins, from being originally deposited in a box, had become so corroded, that they were unable easily to be separated, and in the attempt to effect this separation by a strong liquid the coins were rendered nearly illegible. Some were, however, rescued for the Newport Museum, and include an Augustus, a Trajan, two of Antoninus Pius, two of Lucius Verus, and two of Faustina, wife of Marcus Aurelius.
The hoard comprised 77 silver coins dated between 32/31 BC and AD 125-128.
16 aurei: Vespasian - Trajan (AD 107-110).
Hoard of 282 coins: 252 denarii, 1 quinarius, 29 bronzes: Augustus - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).

9 denarii (Vespasian to Trajan) found among the infill of a trench carrying a conduit to service latrines in Building B, outside the north-western corner of the fort. Wheeler (1927) dated the infill (and therefore the construction of the conduit) by the date of the latest coin, arguing that its fine condition supported a deposition soon after its issue around AD 120. Simpson (1967) agreed that the hoard must have been deposited at about this time, but added that the accompanying pottery indicated the conduit and trench belonged to the later second or third centuries. The hoard, therefore, is likely to have been disturbed and moved from its original place of burial among the soil and other waste material used to fill the trench.
The hoard comprised 8 bronze coins of the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136) found with traces of a leather bag.
12 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Vespasian - Hadrian (AD 125-127).

A hoard of 47 Roman imperial denarii: Vespasian to Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161) was discovered at the end of 2021 in Lviv region. Information about the hoard and photos of the coins were published in one of the groups on Facebook, dedicated to treasure hunting, by user Mikhail Tabachko (Михаил Табачко) on December 14, 2021. The finder reported only that the coins were found together somewhere in the Lviv region. The coins are well preserved. The further fate of the hoard is unknown.
(circa 400) 22 denarii: 2 republican, 20 imperial: Republic - Trajan (AD 105-107)
The hoard comprised approximately 200 'small Roman bronzes' of the Antonine period, most of which were well preserved. Unfortunately, an acid bath rendered them indecipherable.
Originally were 108 denarii. Nowadays, 80 coins: Otho - Commodus (AD 192); silver weight: 215.80 g. (80 coins). Found in a domestic building with bones fragments and an oval whetstone.
During the excavation of the Sanctuary in Insula 20 of Colonia Ulpia Traiana, 6 coins were found deposited under wall plaster. The latest coins date to the period AD 103 to 111.
The hoard comprised 461 bronze coins, including 4 dupondii and asses and 457 sestertii of Galba to Marcus Aurelius, with a tpq of AD 172 to 173.
Five denarii (Vespasian - Commodus Caesar), found together on the premises of the Pipinsburg (a megalithic hillfort of Viking times), close to Sievern.

151 billon Alexandrian tetradrachms, 9 Greek bronzes, 1 provincial bronze and 1 ring: Ptolemaic dynasty - Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus) (AD 166-167). Reported to have been found in an alabaster container. Mixed up with another hoard of over 130 coins not identified.

Hoard bought by E.T. Newell in Cairo in Dec. 1923, found near Sakha. It comprised 299 coins: 33 Greek silver coins from the 2nd and 1st c. BC, 261 denarii (Nero to Trajan) and 5 provincial silver issues of Trajan (one Arabian drachm; three drachms of Cyrenaica and one hemidrachm of Cyrenaica).
The hoard was hidden inside the camp: 25 aurei, 610 denarii, 2 asses, 1 quadrans, as well as gold and silver jewelry in a bronze cauldron: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 165-166).
disposition: Historischen Museum der Stadt Regensburg, Germany

summary: 14 denarii: Domitian - Marcus Aurelius (Commodus Augustus) (AD 177); silver weight: 38.41 g.
Hoard of circa 100 denarii. 18 coins were documented: Antoninus Pius - Commodus (AD 180-192). Weight: 29.86.

Accidentally discovered by schoolboy Leonid Ryshchuk in 1974. The hoard was found on the territory of the Lyshchitsy peat enterprise, on the northern edge of the peat bog, near the bridge across the ditch, 250 m south of the field, south of the cemetery of the village of Ogorodniki. According to the discoverer, the total number of coins ranged from 350 to 500 pieces. Most of the coins were taken by local residents and collectors, only 48 denarii have survived from this find (transferred to the Brest Regional Local History Museum). In 1974, at the hoard find spot, L. Pobol carried out excavations, another 63 coins were discovered (transferred to the Museum of ancient Belarusian Culture of the National Academy of Sciences of Belarus). 5 coins from the hoard are in the private collection of V. Pinchuk in Minsk. A total of 116 coins are known: 115 denarii (Nero-Marcus Aurelius) and one imitation of denarius.
disposition: Brest Regional Local History Museum (48 coins); Museum of ancient Belarusian Culture of the National Academy of Sciences of Belarus (63 coins); private collection of V. Pinchuk in Minsk (5 coins)

summary: In 1962 an excavator found a jar with 7 aurei, 1346 denarii (Nero - Marcus Aurelius), and 4 Lycian drachms (Domitian - Trajan), while building the foundations of the new building for the paper mill factory at Stockstadt.
disposition: The majority of the find was sent to Aschaffenburg Municipal Museum

summary: More than 80 gold coins were discovered as surface finds between 1830 and 1958: Domitian - Commodus (AD 180-192). Only seven of the coins were described sufficiently well to be accurately identified.
Unknown originally number of coins. 50 denarii were sent to the Sankt Petersburg. Among issuers: Vespasiaen, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Faustina I, Commodus (AD 180-192).
Six gold Roman coins found in a burial: Vespasian 1, Trajan 1, Hadrian 4.

Four denarii, pressumably belonging to a hoard, found at the same place at different dates. ”The scientific literature has falsely perpetuated the locality of Mircești (situated 5 km to the west) as the place of origin for the coins.”
The hoard comprised 48 sestertii from Vespasian to Marcus Aurelius and was buried around AD 170.

The coins were found in 1938/39 during excavation works on the west wall in the region of Geilenkirchen-Linnich (Kreis Jülich). 14 of the coins were lost. The remaining 21 ones are sestertii, ranging from Trajan to Commodus. All are very worn.

The hoard comprised a vessel containing more than 200 coins. 13 were shown to the local archaeological society: 6 were 'frustes', 6 of the Antonine family (including Faustina I and II) and one depicted a wolf. Bizeul states that they were all coins of the High Empire. Sanquer suggested that the coin depicting a wolf was a fourth century nummus, but reverse types of the Antonine period also depict the wolf. The three coins of Antoninus Pius and 2 of Faustina given to the museum by Gauja 'found in Rezé in 1851' are likely to come from this hoard. The hoard was found during the building of the east-west road through the city.
Six aurei found in grave of Asfagur: Titus, Trajan, Hadrian 4 (AD 117-138).
Circa 300 denarii found with a ceramic vessel while metal detecting. At the moment, 17 pieces are available for description: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 151-160).
95 sestertii: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 195).
The hoard comprised approximately 40 tetradrachms and 150 denarii from the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).

A very large find of Roman denarii, made in 1858 in the vicinity of Filsum. Around 1960, three further denarii (Domitian Caesar, Commodus) were found on a field, and can probably be connected with the same find.
Unknown originally number of coins. 78 bronze coins: Augustus - Commodus (AD 189).
disposition: Museu da Região Flaviense, Chaves, Portugal

summary: 8 coins: 7 denarii, 1 sestertius found in a destruction layer caused by fire: Vitellius - Antoninus Pius (AD 159-160).
Unknown originally number of denarii. 10 coins were seen: Vespasian 2, Trajan 4, Antoninus Pius 1, Marcus Aurelius 3. Possible, part of the same hoard with Strunga II and III.
22 asses: Augustus - Antoninus Pius (AD 145-161) .
3,728 denarii: Republic - M. Aurelius (AD 166-167)
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Veliko Tarnovo, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 2599-3353 (3626 coins)

summary: 200 bronze coins: Domitian - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
9 bronze coins from Trajan to Marcus Aurelius, most likely a part of a larger find.
9 denarii: Antoninus Pius - Septimius Severus (AD 194-195).
(c. 50) 25 bronze coins: 22 sestertii, 3 asses: House of Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus) (AD 161-169)
The hoard comprised 16 denarii dated between AD 98/99 and AD 128/129.
(14) 10 coins of unknown denomination: Celtic, Republic, Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-192).

The hoard comprised 1 denarius (Diva Faustina I) and 8-9 aes coins ranging fro Hadrian to Faustina II. They were recovered during the excavation of a inhumation burial (tomb 1/1965) in the necropolis and were interpreted as the contents of a purse. Only 5 coins are preserved today, but descriptions of the other ones exist.
disposition: Ufficio dei beni culturali, Bellinzona (5 coins); lost (4-5 coins)

summary: About 40 AR denarii found during construction of Bowers Fold redevelopment in 1963. The hoard was unreported and dispersed, two coins of Hadrian bought by Doncaster Museum.
Over 600 denarii found while digging up a grave. Only 6 pieces provide information on the issuers: Trajan - Commodus (AD 179-180).
21 sestertii, 1 dupondius and 1 AE (copper or brass) found in the neighborhoud of a Roman building next to some clay sources.

A hoard of 197 denarii (Mark Antony to Trajan), found in a 'rude earthen vessel', while ploughing a field in 1874 near Lavenham Lodge. Of these, 184 were examined and 183 published, the others were dispersed.
154 denarii found with a small ceramic vessel: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: According to W. Łonak, the coins were kept by the Provincial Heritage Department for Cultural-Historical Soil Alterations in Racibórz.

summary: Around 100 hundred Roman bronze coins (sestertii, dupondii/asses): Domitian - Didius Julianus (AD 193)
disposition: Museum of Chambéry, France (partially). private collections: Conte, Faudrain, Fivel etc.

summary: The hoard comprised 112 sestertii: Trajan-Septimius Severus (98-196 AD).

A hoard of approximately 100 sestertii, dupondii and asses (Augustus - Commodus), found 500 m east of the village of Allaman, while digging the ground to install phone cables. 58 coins are preserved today (= ca. 60% of the hoard). The coins were heavily worn.
disposition: Musée cantonal d'archéologie et d'histoire, Monnaies et Médailles, Lausanne

summary: 556 denarii found with a bronze vessel: Trajan - Septimius Sverus (AD 193). Silver weight: 1,694g.

The hoard comprised a terracotta vessel containing a block of Roman bronze coins stuck together with corrosion products. Rever identified approximately 180 sestertii and 5 'middle bronzes'. The hoard was found by a labourer digging a hole to plant a tree.
5 or 6 silver denarii. The coins were originally corroded together. Three coins were separated, leaving a stack of either 2 or 3 denarii.
A hoard of 54 bronze coins (Tiberius - Diva Faustina II) found during excavations in the Roman vicus; it was unearthed in stages, in 1983 and then 1986.

Portions of this hoard were acquired by the ANS in 1911 and 1912, totaling 783 coins. 451 of these could be identified in the museum's collection, including 448 denarii, Vespasian to Commodus (AD 183-184) and 3 Cypriote didrachms of Vespasian. This hoard is said to have been discovered in Larnaka, though no details are available.
Hoard of 190 denarii found with ceramic vessel: Republic (?) - Hadrian.
10 denarii (Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius) found corroded together with a bronze fibula and a clasp. They might have been contained in a purse.
9 denarii: Hadrian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180)
Three bronze coins in a small vessel: 1 sestertius Trajan, 1 AE Hadrian, 1 AE L. Aelius (AD 137-138).
Unknown number of Roman coins. Five denarii were placed in a liturgical cup in Limanowa!
84 silver coins found with a ceramic vessel; Trajan - Marcus Aurelius (AD 166); weight: 281 g.
disposition: Muzeului de Istorie și Arheologie, Piatra-Neamț, Romania

summary: The hoard comprised a mixed hoard of gold, silver, and bronze deposited in relation to the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).

A hoard of 59 plated Roman silver coins (cistophori and denarii), found on the south slope of the Acropolis in excavations by the Greek Archaeological Service, near the central room of the Eastern Roman cistern. Of the 59 coins, 35 could be identified: 16 cistophoric tetradrachms (Claudius – Nerva) and 19 denarii (Trajan – Commodus).
Around 400 denarii of the 1st-2nd centuries AD. 153 provided information on the issuers: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Tsarist Archaeological Comission, St. Petersburg, Russia (153 coins)

summary: A hoard of 32 Roman imperial denarii (from Trajan to Commodus) was found in April 2018 in Cherkassy region. Information about the hoard was published in three videos on YouTube, in the channel “Aleksander Mercedes w poiske klada”. The hoard was discovered by a group of treasure hunters on April 20, 2018 on ploughed field, at a depth of up to 15 cm. 21 coins and half of a bronze bracelet were collected from the surface of ca. 10-15 square m (the main concentration, 12 coins, in an area of 5x5 m). On April, 24 a sondage was undertaken at the findspot (ca. 3x3 m. with a depth of ca. 20-50 cm), and 6 more coins were found, including one broken into several pieces. On August 31, 2018, one of the finders found another 5 denarii at the site of the main concentration of coins. It is possible that further searches were also made at this site. The fate of the coins in the hoard is unknown. The identification of the coins was based on the photos that were posted in this video.
Eight sestertii found in Pot Ridings Wood.
Three coins found together by a detectorist and recorded by M. Lyne. Details from HER.

199 denarii found at wetland deposit. Not one hoard, but a collection of several all deposited together. The earliest known contexts for Imperial denarii in Scandinavia are the Illerup weapon sacrifice dated by dendrochronology to c. 210 AD.
228 denarii: Vitellius - Marcus Aurelius/Commodus (Crispina) (AD 177-191).
Uncertain whether the coins were found together or single finds. Only four coins were provided with some information.
17 silver and bronze coins in Principia/barrack: 1 denarius, 1 quinarius, 2 sestertii, 7 dupondii, 6 asses: Vespasian - Hadrian (AD 128-138)
The hoard comprised 4 copper-alloy statues and 2 copper-alloy vessels. One of the copper-alloy vessels contained 6 bronze coins of Marcus Aurelius and Divus Lucius Verus. One coin was lost.
92 denarii: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180). Found in a ceramic vessel together with a silver bracelet.
52 aurei ranging from Nero (AD 63/66) to Marcus Aurelius (AD 164), found at the Stephansgasse, in the foundations of a stone building. This hoard could be connected with the Marcomannic wars.

A hoard of 9 provincial coins from Athens (periods VB and VC) and one sestertius of Commodus. The coins were excavated in 1936 in front of the north end of the Stoa of Attalos (grid P 7). When found, several of the coins were stuck together, suggesting that all ten were originally put away in a purse.
The hoard apparently comprised 68 denarii, although the catalogue gives a total of 59 coins.
Unknown originally number of denarii. 8 denarii, 1 drachm of Dyrrachium and 1 denarius Antoninus Pius (Faustina I/Diva Faustina I) were recovered.
220 denarii: Republican (163), Imperial (57); Republican - Antoninus Pius (AD post 141)
disposition: Union Museum Alba Iulia, Romania (49 coins)

summary: 28 sestertii: Hadrian - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
disposition: Collection E.C. Lefèvre, Brugge, Belgium, in 1851 (28 coins)

summary: HER record of 30 to 40 denarii from Vespasian to Antoninus Pius found in the mid 1970s following dredging of the Little Ouse and not apparently recorded elsewhere.
The hoard was discovered after 1863 in the rubble from the excavation of the bathhouse. It comprises 21 aurei, ranging from Nero to Trajan.
Two denarii of Commodus (AD 186); silver weight: 4.66 g.
Hoard of 87 aurei: Nero - Commodus (AD 180-192).
The hoard comprised 35 aurei (Nero-Lucius Verus) and 29 silver coins (Nero-Trajan).
Twenty-two denarii found on an agricultural land: Otho - Commodus (AD 187-188).

A hoard of 291 Roman imperial denarii: Hadrian – Commodus (AD 180-192) and their imitations was found by two treasure hunters in early June 2016 in the Kyiv region. Information about the find and photos of the coins were published by one of the finders on the Ukrainian treasure hunting forum Violity on June 21, 2016. The finder reported that the coins were collected from an area of 3 square meters. The first coins were found at a depth of 10-20 cm, although the pit for their search was dug about 1 m deep. Some coins have traces of bronze oxides. In general, the preservation of coins is good (weak wear). In August 2016, the entire hoard was sold at a Violity auction. The further fate of the coins is unknown.

A Roman arm purse was found on a field, southwest of Hahn (today in the district of Pfungstadt), in the vicinity of the Hofgut Grabenbruch. The purse contained 8 Roman denarii, ranging from Galba to Trajan.
55 denarii found with a ceramic jar: Galba - Commodus (AD 189). Found one meter from STARYIE VALKY 2013 2, practically, one hoard.

IARCH record for a hoard of 30 denarii found between 1985 and 1992. The latest coins are two of Lucius Verus and Divus Antoninus both dated to AD 161 and an undated coin of Faustina II. This might suggest deposition in the earlier part of the reign of Marcus Aurelius. See WMID-1AC648 for full details and images. One of the coins of Trajan is a small fragment.
The hoard comprised 13 silver coins dated between AD 62/3 and AD 123.
Over 200 silver coins. 168 are known: 166 denarii, 2 drachms of Lycia: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 167).
800 denarii. 274 pieces were studied by V. Haralanov: Nero - Hadrian (AD 117-138).
11 denarii: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
Hoard of 177 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 197). Together were found two silver rings and one of gold.

Udmarken on Bornholm has yielded three hoards with a total of 217 denarii. All three, A, B, C, have been interpreted as being of either the same hoard or of chronologically identical hoards. A and B were found a week apart in 1853 and C was found in 1857. Udmarken B contains 53 of the 217 denarii.
78 denarii: Antoninus Pius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
150 coins, of which 10 sestertii: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
A hoard of 20+ Roman silver coins (i.e. certainly denarii), found while digging out peat on the Dörpstedter Moor.
Hoard of around 1,600 denarii found with a ceramic vessel. 573 coins were documented: Titus - Septimius Severus Severus (AD 193-211).

A hoard of 138 Roman imperial denarii: Galba - Marcus Aurelius (AD 180-161) was discovered by a treasure hunter in 2017 in the Kyiv region. The first information about the hoard and photos of 60 coins were published on the Ukrainian treasure hunting forum Violity on January 6, 2017. Then the treasure hunter went to the hoard findspot nine more times and found a different number of coins: 24 January (2 coins), 25 January (7 coins), 24 February (8 coins), 15 May (1 coin), 12 June (1 coin), 3 August (1 coin), 4 August (19 coins), 14 August (38 coins) and 20 August (1 coin). According to the finder, the deposit was found in the forest, under the trees. In the photograph on forum a small pit in the sandy soil (up to 50 cm deep) located on a slight slope can be seen. A few coins were closer to the surface, the main butch was deeper. The hoard was in a reddish-colored pottery vessel, of which several fragments have survived (according to the finder it was a “pot”, but judging by the photographs it was a pottery bowl). The coins are in very good condition (minimal wear). The coins were sold one by one at the Violity auction.
At least 1381. Uncertain if all the coins belong to this hoard or they are contaminated from NIETULISKO MAŁE 1: Nero - Septimius Severus (AD 197-198).
disposition: State Archaeological Museum, Wrasaw, Archaeological and Ethnographical Museum, Łodz; Museum in Ostrowiec Świętokrzyskie, Archaeological Museum in Krakow

summary: Group of six denarii found on the same area of an ancient settlement (?): Mark Antony - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161/post). Similar structure with RATENICE 2002
Three aurei of Hadrian. Only one was seen.
7 coins found stuck together: 4 denarii, 1 plated denarius, 1 sestertius, 1 as: Mark Antony - Hadrian (AD 121-122).
disposition: County Museum of History and Art, Zalău, Romania (inv.no. CC 315/90)

summary: 20 denarii, 15 studied: Trajan – Commodus (AD 189).

A hoard of denarii, found while digging sand in a sand-pit, between the Lion Foundry, Kirkintilloch, and Barley Bank houses. 24 coins were first published in 1894, followed by a more complete list in 1911 (42 coins). 5 more coins were found since, giving a total of 47 denarii (Vespasian - Faustina II) that were published.
A hoard of an unknown number of denarii. Only 15 coins were documented: Hadrian (Aelius Caesar) - Marcus Aurelius (AD 177-178). Kropotkin suspected that it may be the same hoard as Sosnitsa.
disposition: University Museum, Kyiv, Ukraine (15 coins until 1917)

summary: 44 denarii: Trajan - Didius Julianus (AD 193). Found together with a silver brooch dated between the end of the 4th century beginning of the 5th century AD.
50 denarii: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180). No information about circumstances.
2 silver coins: Titus for Divus Vespasianus, Hadrian.
The hoard comprised '20 coins of which the most recent was an issue of Marcus Aurelius' The hoard was discovered by peat cutters.
Unknown number of aurei and silver coins found with a ceramic vessel. Only five aurei were seen: Trajan 4, Trajan for Plotina 1.
Penhallurick (2009, 245 no. 251) records a metal detector find of 9 sestertii found in an area of about 50 square metres in the same field. Considered to be part of a scattered hoard.
41 Alexandrian bronze coins: Trajan - Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II) (AD 164-165). Found during excavations .
disposition: Exhibited in London 1902, now in Toronto. Detailed list in Oxford

summary: 15 AE to AD 195.
Denarius hoard consisting of 97 denarii found through metal detectoring and excavation. Vespasian to Antoninus Pius.
480 denarii: Republic – Antoninus Pius (Marcus Aurelius Caesar) (AD 155-156).
2 denarii: Hadrian, Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161). Found while ploughing.
Unknown number of antoniniani, among, those of Aurelian and Severina.
disposition: Regional History Museum, Vratsa, Bulgaria; inv.nos. M III 6197-6234 (38 coins)

summary: 322 coins found in a ceramic vessel: 1 aureus, 302 denarii, 18 bronze pieces. Only 242 coins were recovered: Vespasian to Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
130 denarii: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 190-191); silver weight: 360.44 g. Together with the coins were found two bronze rings.
The hoard comprised 1 dupondius and 5 asses terminating with issues of the period AD 178-183. The coins were found together, but without trace of a container.

Originally 17 denarii, 16 preserved: Trajan - Commodus (AD 183-184); silver weight: 44.65 g. (16 coins). Together were also found: 1 gold bracteate, 1 gold finger ring, 2 neck-rings of bronze with silver mountings, 2 somewhat smaller bronze rings, 1 bronze clasp, 1 bronze strap-end, several bronze spirals, 1 amber bead, 2 coral beads.
Unknown originally number of coins, around 160-200 denarii. Only 90 were documented: Otho - Clodius Albinus (AD 195-197).
20 sestertii, found on a small plate with ashes: Domitian - Commodus (AD 180-187).

14 coins (Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius, mostly bronzes) were found embedded in fire debris, on terrain M, Handwerkerbau (Fläche 60, Planum 0-1). N.B. Coin 1 (Vespasian) is wrongly described as a denarius in FMRD.
The coins were found in a glass urn along with a human cremation. Among issuers Hadrian and Antoninus Pius.
The hoard comprised a total of 22 denarii dating from the Republic to Antoninus Pius. There are no further details about the structure of the hoard.
disposition: National History Museum, Bucharest, Romania (22 coins)

summary: Two coins of Antoninus Pius, one Marcus Aurelius and one of Hadrian found in 1725, as part of a large 'parcel' of coins.
Two denarii found together: Hadrian, Marcus Aurelius.
26 denarii: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 176-177).
Circa 60 aurei. Disintegrated cloth bag found during excavations in the courtyard of a house.
5 denarii from Vespasian (Domitian) to Antoninus Pius (M. Aurelius). Part of a larger hoard, details unknown.

Date of discovery is date of publication, so might be one year earlier. Uncertain number of bronze Tiberius and Marcus Aurelius coins, thus at least 2, found during dike reconstruction found together with glass, bronze objects, terra sigillata, jars, urns and rough earthenware. A bronze purse in the shape of a boat was found in or around 1939 in the same village and might be connected
32 bronze coins found glued to each other: Domitian - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
A hoard containing nearly 100 silver denarii from the period of Trajan and Hadrian was unearthed between Trostadt and Siegritz.
Unknown number of denarii. Only two of them are known: Hadrian, Marcus Aurelius for Lucilla (AD 161-180).
The hoard comprised 514 imperial bronze coins: Nero-Septimius Severus (AD 193-196).
disposition: Museo Archeologico Nazionale di Altino, Italy; private collection; some lost

summary: 3rd century. "Six coins, a small mid-3rd century AD hoard, found in soil (751A), 3 sealed by east wall (763) of Structure Y [a trapezoidal stone-walled enclosure appended to inner wall face of the round]. Another coin found in (728), the surface of Structure Y, & 2 more in overlying soil (785). These 3 coins of similar date & condition, & formed part of scattered hoard.
11 denarii found in a purse (vanished): Mark Antony - Hadrian (AD 125-128)
disposition: Centrul de Studii de Istorie și Arheologie, Timișoara, Romania; inv.no. 237/2005

summary: 62 tetradrachms of Alexandria: Claudius I - Hadrian (AD 127-128)

Råmosen, the numerically largest denarii hoard in Denmark, was found in 1782. The hoard consists of 428 denarii. There are two lists of coins for the hoard; one lists the end coin as a Marcus Aurelius, but there are contemporary letters mentioning coins with a portrait of Crispina.

A hoard of 10 aurei and 120+ denarii, found in 1878 near the Roman fort. The closure date of this hoard is AD 192. However the penultimate coin is an issue of 185 and a seven year gap between the terminal issues is unusual. In the event the hoard is listed as closing with RIC 241, with the caveat that the last coin may be a site find rather than a hoard item (P.J. Casey).
Seven denarii found through several rounds of detecting.

A hoard of four denarii (2 Domitian and 2 Trajan) was found during field-walking in the South Annexe of the fort at Newstead. The coins were recovered in a little roll, with possible traces of a copper/bronze container.
39 Roman imperial denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Vitellius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
The hoard comprised 9 figurines, 1 patera and 7 bronze coins from Vespasian to Commodus.
Unknown originally number of coins. 34 bronze coins: 21 sestertii, 13 dupondii: Trajan - Antoninus Pius (AD 145-161).
Treasure numbers associated with this hoard: 2013 T096. Other PAS records associated with this hoard: DEV-269707
107 denarii found with a bronze vessel: Republic - Trajan (AD 112-114).
disposition: Museo Arqueológico Provincial de Lugo, Spain

summary: The coins were found in a block, stuck together with corrosion products and comprised 151 sestertii, dupondii and asses from Trajan to Commodus. The coins were found during gravel extraction in the river and may represent a hoard washed out from a riverbank or a votive deposit.
666 coins: 665 denarii, 1 drachm: Nero – Antoninus Pius (AD 140).
More than 800 originally number of coins found with a ceramic vessel. 441 coins: 406 sestertii, 29 dupondii, 5 asses, 1 AE provincial: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 186-187).
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Namur, Belgium (443 coins); Cabinet des Médailles, Bruxelles, Belgium (1 coin).

summary: 3,561 coins of Lucius Verus.
During the excavation of the Roman town, 2 small hoards of both silver and bronze were found from below the front of site VI. Hoard A comprised 23 coins, ending with Hadrian.
The hoard comprised 31 sestertii, stacked one on top of the other, suggesting that they may have originally been packed in a tube or similar which has not survived: Nerva - Commodus (AD 189).
Hoard of around 200 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Nero - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194).
disposition: Institute of Archaeology of the Academy of Sciences, Kyiv, Ukraine (22 coins); National History Museum, Moskow, Russia (inv.no. 92088; 105 coins); private collection (1 coin)

summary: A hoard of ancient coins, including a tetradrachm of Thassos and a denarius of Faustina I found with a ceramic vessel.

Over 486 silver and bronze coins found in four ceramic vessels. Found 3 m from KRISTENDORF 1. Vessel a: 38 denarii: Mark Antony 2, Nero 1, Vitellius 1, Vespasian 11, Titus 1, Domitian 4, Nerva 1, Trajan 3, Antoninus Pius 5, Faustina I 4, Marcus Aurelius 1, Faustina II 2, Lucilla 1, Commodus 1. Vessel b: 151 sestertii: Galba 1, Vespasian 1, Titus 2, Domitian 2, Trajan 12, Hadrian 23, Antoninus Pius 28, Faustina I 11, Marcus Aurelius 24, Faustina II 13, Lucius Verus 5, Lucilla 7, Commodus 15, Septimius Severus 5, Julia Damna 1, Caracalla 1. Vessel c: 237 bronze coins: Vespasian 1, Titus 1, Domitian 3, Trajan 13, Hadrian 41, Sabina 2, Antoninus Pius 32, Faustina II 11, Marcus Aurelius 56, Faustina II 34, Lucius Verus 6, Lucilla 8, Commodus 24, Crispina 1, uncertain 4. Vessel d: 60 sestertii: Titus 1, Nerva 1, Trajan 3, Hadrian 5, Sabina 1, Antoninus Pius 13, Faustina I 2, Marcus Aurelius 14, Faustina II 11, Lucilla 2, Commodus 4, Crispina 1, uncertain 2.
9 denarii and 2 aes (Mark Antony to Antoninus Pius) found in Room 28.

Discovered in 2007 in a field, near a village, between the village and the Lyasnaya river; the coins were scattered over an area of 500x100 m and had two large concentrations (two hoards?). Included at least 500 denarii, of which only 20 are available for study (Vespasian-Clodius Albinus). Information about the hoard in 2009 came to the archaeologist V. Belyavets, and in the spring of 2010 V. Sidarovich examined the place of the find. In the same field, other items were found: fragments of silver brooches, a gold brooch, a spearhead, a gold ring (?). Their relation with the hoard is doubtful (items from the settlement?)
Two denarii: Antoninus I (Faustina I), Marcus Aurelius.
A farmer in 1864 found over 60 specimens of Roman silver coins during plowing on a small hill in the vicinity of Erfurt. 29 coins were described (Trajan - Marcus Aurelius).
