A number of coin finds were made during controlled archaeological excavation by Wessex Archaeology at the RLE sites Springhead Roman Town (RLE Event Code ARC SPH00) and Springhead Nursery (ARC SHN02) as part of the programme of archaeological works undertaken in advance of the construction of the Channel Tunnel Rail Link (now known as HS1), between 2000 and 2003.

A Roman burial was discovered in the spring of 1929 in widening the south side of the Ashford-Maidstone-London road. This almost certainly represents an untouched cremated deposit. Together with other objects, it contained 18 gold coins or disks.
14 denarii part of a hoard found on the same field like GANDARVE 1927, 1928, 1928-1931: Vespasian (Domitian Caesar) - Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II) (AD 161-175); silver weight: 22.67 g (8 coins).
The hoard comprised approximately 10 tetradrachms and 35 denarii from the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).

The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing approximately 350 sestertii of which 250 were too worn to identify. Hahn compiled a catalogue of 107 examples which is given here. A news article mentions a sestertius of Severus Alexander which is not included in Hahn's catalogue which may or may not be part of the hoard.
7 denarii: Vespasian 3, Nerva 1, Trajan 1, Marcus aurelius 2 (AD 166-167).
9 sestertii from Trajan to Marcus Aurelius (AD 177-178).
29 denarii: Otho - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194).
disposition: Museum of Cultural History Stralsund, Germany (26 coins); Museum Szeczin, Poland (3 coins)

summary: Unknown initial number of denarii. 40 coins entered the museum collection in Sofia: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv.no. X

summary: 52 denarii: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 186-187); silver weight: 135.15 g.
Hoard of circa 60 denarii: Nero - Commodus (AD 180-192). Only 18 denarii were documented.

The hoard comprised '27 aurei of Vespasian to Commodus along with some silver denarii.' The gold coins were distributed amongst the family of the landowner. Although 9 of the aurei were given to the Musée de Rouen by M. Esnault, these were later stolen.
disposition: Musée de Rouen, France (9 coins. stolen)

summary: A hoard of at least 60 Roman imperial denarii: Vespasian – Commodus (AD 180-192) was discovered by a treasure hunter in the late 2010s. The hoard was found in a forest, the coins were collected from an area of 10x10 m (slightly higher was another area of 30x40 m where several coins were also found). 60 coins were collected by treasure hunters during six trips. A fragment of an iron Roman sword blade was found 200 m from the hoard. The coins have a rather bad condition (heavy wear). The further fate of the coins is unknown.
26 denarii found in three separate finds (1921, 1924, and 1946): Hadrian - Septimius Severus (AD 194).
The hoard comprised 4 aurei and 132 silver coins, as well as jewellery from the second century AD: Nero - Hadrian (AD 117-138). Associated with Bar Kochba revolt (AD 132-135).
The hoard was found in a ceramic vessel and comprised 722 'bronzes'. It has been suggested that they were sestertii dating from the reign of Hadrian to Commodus. Found close to the brickworks.
Unknown number of initial coins. 20 pieces - unknown metal - are kept in the Coin Room of the Institute of Archaeology in Bucharest: Trajan - Antoninus Pius (Ad 138-161).
disposition: Coin Room of the Institute of Archaeology, Bucharest, Romania

summary: A large hoard of 1,500-2,000 coins: 508 republican coins are identified; all the emperors up to Hadrian are represented except Augustus.

Circa 30 denarii: Republic - Septimius Severus (AD 194-197). Near the denarii, a silver "pendant" was found, a piece of a brown object of unspecified utility, coins from the 15th to the 20th century and sherds of pottery (probably modern). The coins from the hoard were identified based on poor or very poor quality photos.
13 denarii found in a mound next to ceramic vessels: Antoninus Pius - Commodus(AD 180).
disposition: Frisian Museum, Leeuwarden (FML A 1129-1141), 2 coins lost.

summary: (21) 19 bronze coins: 11 sestertii, 7 dupondii, 1 as: Trajan - Hadrian (AD 134-138).
Two double pierced coins (aureus - Commodus and an Indian imitation of Marcus Aurelius/Commodus) were found along with modern earring.
Over 60 denarii found on a field during 19th-21st centuries: Vespasian - septimius Severus (AD 193-194).
disposition: National Museum of Archaeology, Warszaw, Poland (6 coins); Private collection (21 coins)

summary: Hoard of 23 denarii: Trajan - Commodus (AD 188-189); silver weight: 52.27 g.
40 denarii and 30 sestertii ranging from Domitian to Commodus (Crispina).
11 bronze coins: 5 sestertii, 4 dupondii, 2 asses: Domitian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 177-179)
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles, Bruxelles, Belgium (11 coins), donations P. De Baeck.

summary: 2 denarii: Trajan, Antoninus Pius/Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II).

Unknown originally number of denarii. 5 coins are kept in the History Museum in Bacău: Trajan 1, Antoninus Pius (Faustina I/Diva Faustina I) 1, Marcus Aurelius 2, Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II/Diva Faustina II) 1.
189 denarii: Nero – Marcus Aurelius (AD 176-177).
disposition: History Museum of Moldova, Iași (134 coins), History Museum "lulian Antonescu", Bacău (21 coins), History Museum, Onești (13 coins); Museum of History and Archaeology Piatra-Neamț (22 coins)

summary: Hoard of 39 denarii, 26 glass and amber beads, several fragmentary specimens, and fragments of metal ornaments, including two silver brooches: Vespasian - Commodus. "Denarii are dated to the second half of the 1st century – the end of 2nd century AD, dating of the brooches, however, indicates that the hoard was deposited in the second half of the 5th century AD."
278 denarii found with an small amphora: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 194-195).
disposition: National History Museum of Transylvania, Cluj-Napoca; Town Museum Gherla (20 coins), Romania

summary: 16 denarii: Antoninus Pius - Commodus (AD 192).
307 denarii: Republic – Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Muzeul Județean de Istorie și Arheologie Maramureș, Baia Mare, Romania

summary: Unknown initial number of coins. 1,481 denarii: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 169-170).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Vratsa, Bulgaria; inv.nos. M I 453-1933

summary: 669 denarii found with a ceramic vessel near a Carpic settlement: Republic – Marcus Aurelius (AD 166-167).
(?) 29 denarii: Republic - M. Aurelius (AD 166-167?)
Over 200 silver coins from Vespasian to Hadrian (Ad 117-138). No detailed information.

103 denarii (Nero to Antoninus Pius) found near a large stone building and a series of ditches identified by a geophysical survey in 1999 and described as a farmhouse. The site has turned up building debris, pottery, and a series of other metal finds, including at least 46 other denarii that might have come from the coin hoard (Treasure report SS 91 69).
Initially 368 denarii, nowadays, 367: Vitellius - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194); silver weight: 1009.47 g.
disposition: The National Historical Museum, Stockholm (inv.no. 10155/1-167, 169-368); Stockholm Numismatic Institute, Stockholm (inv.no. 179)

summary: Around 100 denarii found with a ceramic vessel. 95 coins provide information on issuers: Vespasian - Pertinax (AD 193).
9 sestertii: Hadrian - Commodus (AD 181).
The hoard was found during the 1988 excavation in the southern part of the Roman vicus. The coins (26 denarii, ranging from Nero to Antoninus Pius) were corroded together in a clump.
160-180 denarii found in a ceramic vessel - metal detecting - within an ancient settlement. The coins are dated to the 1st-2nd centuries AD.
Unknown quantity of silver and bronze coins found in a copper vessel. 11 coins in the History Museum in Lom: Trajan - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
9 coins: 1 aureus, 3 denarii, 1 sestertius, 4 asses: Galba - Hadrian (AD 117-138)
(2820) 2819 denarii: Republic - Septimius Severus (AD 205).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Ruse, Bulgaria; in.no. 1867

summary: The hoard comprised 45 silver tetradrachms from Claudius I to Antoninus Pius. It is not clear whether the coins represent a complete hoard or part of a hoard.
The hoard comprised an earthenware vessel containing 100 Roman coins including denarii, sestertii and dupondii, nearly all issues of Antoninus Pius, Faustina I and Faustina II.
Unknown originally number of denarii. 27 coins are known at the moment: Republic - M. Aurelius (AD 161-175).
The hoard comprised 118 sestertii found with a ceramic vessel: Domitian-Commodus (90-183 AD). Most of the coins are kept in a private collection (Antonio Egger).
disposition: Museo Civico di Bassano (26 coins); Museo Bottacin di Padova (6 coins); private collection Egger family (86 coins).

summary: HER record of a first century hoard found on Sheringham Beach along with remains of a ceramic container, exposed through cliff erosion. Only 5 coins were examined but the hoard was much larger.
50 denarii ranging from the 2nd century BC Republic coins to Trajan, and including one plated specimen, found in a wooden building from the late 2nd century AD.

A hoard of at least 160 Roman imperial denarii was found by a treasure hunter in 2009 or 2010 near the village of Baikivka. According to his information, the hoard was partially ploughed, but the main part of it was at a depth of ca. 50 cm together with fragments of a vessel (pot?). The coins had traces of bronze oxides. Photographs of the deposit have not been preserved, but it is known that most of the coins date from the Nerva-Antonine dynasty, including coins of Antoninus Pius and Commodus. The fate of the coins is unknown.
Hoard of 50 denarii. Only 8 pieces are documented: Antoninus Pius 3, Marcus Aurelius (Antoninus Pius Divus), Commodus 4.
disposition: National Museum of History, Moscow, Russia (inv.nos. 14863, 14865-14869)

summary: Two denarii: Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus/Divus Lucius Verus) (AD 161-169). Militky considers a misidentification of this hoard with the one Dobřichov-Plaňany (PLAŇANY 1892).
166 bronze coins: Galba - Septimius Severus (AD 195).
disposition: Museo Arqueológico de Asturias, Oviedo, Spain

summary: Unknown originally number of denarii. 25 coins were seen: Nero – Commodus (AD 180-192). Possible, part of the hoards with Strunga I and III.
160 denarii, 80 recovered: 41 republican, 39 imperial: Republic - Trajan (AD 102-103).
disposition: National Museum of Union, Alba Iulia, Romania

summary: A hoard of 427 silver coins (426 denarii and one Lycian drachm), of which the first lot was found in 1910 in a clay pot, while ploughing a field. It comprised 367 Roman denarii (Nero to Commodus), one Lycian drachm of Trajan and one contemporary cast forgery, also from Trajan. A further lot of 50 denarii (Mark Antony – Commodus) was found between April and December 1988 by members of the Chesterfield Metal Detector Club, in the vicinity of the first lot and can be regarded as a further portion of the same find. A further 8 denarii (Vitellius - Antoninus Pius) were found with the aid of metal detectors in November 2012.
disposition: Doncaster Museum (part); Newark Museum (part); British Museum (part)

summary: Two denarii of Hadrian (AD 134-138).
Four denarii, unknown whether they were found together or were part of a larger hoard: Titus, Trajan, Antoninus Pius, Faustina II, Crispina. Most likely
35 sestertii, 707.80 g, found on a field ranging from Vespasian/Titus to Commodus (AD 186).
(49) 48 denarii: 35 republican, 13 imperial: Republic - Trajan (AD 101/102) .
Three denarii found on a field: Trajan 1, Lucilla 1, Faustina II/Lucilla 1
(c. 215) 199 bronze coins: 194 sestertii, 5 dupondii: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 191).
8 aurei: Nero - Antoninus Pius: M. Aurelius (Caesar) (AD 140-161)

12 denarii, of which 10 plated, were found with a ceramic vessel in a garbage pit: Trajan 3, Antoninus Pius 2, Antoninus Pius (Diva Faustina I) 3, Antoninus Pius (Faustina II) 2, Marcus Aurelius 1, Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus) 1 (post AD 173-174).

In 2010 archaeological excavation of the northern part of Tyritake city-site (site XXVIII) a boxlike altar made of limestone tiles was found in Room I. Altar clearing uncovered two golden staters of Bosporus kings Eupator and Sauromates II, which are most likely to have been offerings to Dionysus. Sauromates II’s stater suggests dating offerings to Dionysus to AD 179 or a little later.
70 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Augustus - Hadrian.
The hoard comprised approximately 46 tetradrachms and 200-350 denarii of the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).
disposition: L. Hamburger (British Museum); Montagu Collection; J. Evans; Kelsey Museum of Archaeology in Ann Arbor, Michigan; Detroit Institute of Arts

summary: 28 sestertii in a ceramic vessel: Domitian - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
Only 4 sestertii are known: Hadrian - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
ca. 80 sestertii and dupondii, but not all of them are identified: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-192).
236 aurei and denarii from the time of Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
27 denarii: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).

Originally 5 denarii, 2 preserved: Hadrian, Hadrian (Sabina), Antoninus Pius Antoninus Pius (Faustina I), Didius Julianus (Manlia Scantilla); silver weight: 4.61 g. (2 coins). Not certain that they were found together!

In 1925 a hoard comprising 1081 bronze coins, originally included in a pottery vessel, was found after agricoltural works. Coins inlcuded in this hoard returned to the finders and went missing, except for 1 sestertius of Didia Clara now kept in the Museum Bottacin in Padua. Only a brief report on the coins included in the hoard is now available.
More than 188 billon provincial coins of Alexandria: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus) (AD 161-169). 'Found at Avenue of the Sphinxes during clearance excavations.'

A hoard of denarii was found approx. 0.7 km northwest of Ausleben, on the Ausleber Hoch (alt. 135 m) in a probable neolithic grave mound. 142 coins (Otho-Commodus) were described, but the total amount of coins is unknown.
Originally 312 denarii, 299 preserved: Nero - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194); silver weight: 758.24 g. (299 coins).
A hoard found in a field south of Castlethorpe, comprising 20 denarii and 35 bronze coins, up to Lucius Verus.
Originally 30 denari, 29 preserved: Nerva - Commodus (AD 179-191); silver weight: 78.54 g.
1 silver + 4 bronze coins: (1st century -2nd century AD), Augustus - Commodus (AD 192) found during archaeological excavations.
324 denarii: M. Antony - M. Aurelius (AD 166-167)
Fifty bronze coins were discovered in Roux, but only 9 were preserved, ranging in date from Trajan to Marcus Aurelius.
At least 9 denarii and 1 aureus: Trajan-Hadrian (AD 117-138).

Hoard of 450 denarii found with a ceramic vessel covered by another pot: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (Clodius Albinus Caesar) (AD 194-195). Weight: 983 g. According to Kropotkin, the hoard ends with the coin of Clodius Albinus as all the coins of Septimius Severus are issues of AD 193-194.
disposition: Local History Museum, Uman, Ukraine (inv. nos. 1675/2760 et 2355/3440)

summary: Mr. I.L. Faingold may have inherited a hoard of 100 denarii from his father. 44 coins were documented: Galba - Commodus (AD 190).
disposition: University Museum, Kyiv, Ukraine (44 coins until 1917)

summary: The hoard comprised 9 aurei found near the 'Caserne' of Autun. The aurei dated from Vespasian to Faustina I, and may be just a small part of a more important hoard.
5 denarii (Vespasian - Hadrian) found together in Rottweil, in the south of the Roman city (Parzelle 969/3, Firma Mahle).

A hoard of 12 Roman coins (apparently silver), found in 1755 while building a road from Taymouth to Glenquaich, near the crest of the hill. The same find (but described as 14 denarii) is recorded as having been found while digging the foundations of a tower near Taymouth. The coins are from the Antonine period, none later that Marcus Aurelius. No further details given.
Four coins on PAS database centered to village - possibly a hoard or addenda to one of the previous hoards?Other PAS records associated with this hoard: CAM-531F17

54 Republican and imperial denarii issued by M. Fonteius, L. Marcius Censorinus, C. Naevius Balbus, M. Cordius, L. Plautius, A. PLautius, P. Clodius Turrinus, L. Thorius Balbus, Sextus Pompeius, Julius Caesar, Mark Antony's legionary denarii (III, VI, VIIII, XII, XIX, XII) des denarii of Sex. Pompey (with reverses of Amphinomos and Anapias), Julius Caesar and emperors to Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
Unknown number of aurei of the Anoninian house (the number expressed were between 5,000 and 9,000). Only one piece of Antoninus Pius was identified.
In 1853 not far from the Oste river during earthworks three bronze coins (Marcus Aurelius) were found at a depth of 10 feet. Pit holes and other remains indicate a settlement.
6 denarii found on the construction site: Vitellius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 166).
Around 300 denarii possible found with a leather bag. 134 coins provide information on the issuers: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211).
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Krakow (132 coins); private collection, Gnojni (2 coins)

summary: 7 sestertii: Trajan 2, Hadrian (Sabina) 1, Antoninus Pius (Faustina I) 2, Marcus Aurelius 2 (AD 161-180).
8 bronze coins - 7 sestertii, 1 as - range: Galba- Trajan (AD 103-111) found in a ditch on the area of the Roman cemetery.
A hoard of 48 denarii, ranging from Vespasian to Commodus, discovered in the fortress of Gaṙni in 1955.
2 sestertii of Antoninus Pius
Originally 3 denarii (Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, imitation) found within an Iron Age settlement together iron, earthenware, bone artefacts.
Over 361 silver and bronze coins were found in five ceramic vessels. Only 191 coins were documented: 157 sestertii, 24 denarii were studied: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 180-192).
16 sestertii found stuck together in a Roman edifice: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD162-163).
disposition: Museo de Arqueología de Álava, Spain

summary: 5 bronze coins (Hadrian - Marcus Aurelius), found dispersed across the excavation area. It is possible that an Augustan as (RIC 436) also belonged to this hoard. One interpretation is that these coins could have belonged to a small 'hoard' (or purse) that was later scattered across the site, though admittedly there is no sign of other artefacts being moved around the site.
40 denarii: Titus - Pertinax (AD 193).

A mixed hoard of Syrian tetradrachms, Cypriote tetradrachms / didrachms, and denarii, ranging in date from Nero to Hadrian. One coin of Vespasian is countermarked by Marcus Aurelius (AD 169-180), which is why the closing reign is given here as Marcus Aurelius.
70 denarii: 69 Rome issues, 1 imitation: Trajan - Commodus (AD 187-188). Together, it was found a ring made of a silver-coloured metal.
410 denarii: Galba - Marcus Aurelius/Commodus (AD 161-192).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2519

summary: The hoard comprised an unknown number of coins of which 24 denarii, including 11 Republican issues and 13 imperial issues from Vitellius to Antoninus Pius were recorded.
3200 silver coins found with bronze cauldron: 3197 denarii, 3 drachmas Lycia: Republic - Antoninus Pius (AD 158-161) . 10.8 kg
disposition: Museum ”Dr. Molnár István”, Cristuru Secuiesc, Romania (1965)

summary: c. 300 sestertii from Hadrian to Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180). No further information about composition of hoard.
disposition: Archaeological Museum Zagreb, Croatia; dispersed; Ervin Meixner coll.

summary: 100 coins of which one bronze coin of Marcus Aurelius/Commodus for Crispina (Augusta) (AD 178-183).
disposition: Private collection and museum Eindhoven, Netherlands

summary: A hoard of 300 Roman denarii ranging from Vespasian to Commodus (AD 74). Only 19 coins have been recorded. Based on the portrait style, the coins seem to be imitations of known genuine types.
disposition: Private collection A.A. Tarpi, Dushambe, Tajikistan

summary: Unknown number of denarii hoard. 4 coins entered museum collection in Yambol: Vespasian 2, Nerva 1, Trajan 1.
disposition: Regional History Museum, Yambol, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2924-2929

summary: Towards the end of October 1878 three aurei were discovered in Bliesen between the Church of St. Remigius and the Rhine road. These date from Vespasian to Antoninus Pius. The coins are now in the collection of the Munzkabinett im Rheinischen Landesmuseum. A fourth aureus in the possession of this museum has been associated with the Bliesen hoard. It dates to the reign of Vespasian (72/3) and was acquired from the Bliesen area.
6 sestertii were found at a gravel pit close to Eisenfeld.

Three denarii of Hadrian, found around 1896 on the Debra, a plateau approx. 1.5 km northeast of Rudolstadt, near Debrahof, on Rudolstadt-Teichweiden road; the coins could form part of a larger hoard of denarii.

Unknown original number of coins. 184 denarii of which two imitations: Vespasian - Didius Julian (AD 193). Found together with a "belt set of one massive silver buckle for a sword belt and two buckles for a girdle. The find also contains eighty-four silver belt plaits. This belt set, dating to the latter half of the 5th century AD (phase D2 of the Great Migration Period), is a girdle for bladed weaponry."
disposition: The State Museum of Military History and Natural Preserve “The Kulikovo Polye”, Tula, Russia (inv.no. BX 1823/1-184)

summary: In 1884 a large hoard of Roman bronze coins was found in the area of Mindelzell. 30 specimens arrived in a private collection in Memmingen, of which 12 were later bought by the Memmingen museum. They are now lost.
Unknown number of bronze coins: Augustus - Commodus/Pertinax (AD 193).

Hoard of 34 bronze sstaters of an autonomous (Agrippia) city and Bosporan kings: Aspurgus, Gepaepyris, Rhescuporis II, Sauromates I, Cotys II, Sauromates II and one issue of the mint of Agrippia Caesarea (Phanagoria).
disposition: Museum of Anapa, Russia (labelled as the "Gunyaevsky Hoard"; inv.nos. AM 10750/1-34)

summary: Unknown originally number of coins. 52 denarii were found with a hand-made ceramic vessel: Mark Antony – Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
Hoard of around 2,000 denarii. 90 denarii entered the University Museum in Kyiv: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
64 bronze coins: sestertii, dupondii and asses: Augustus - Marcus Aurelius (AD 177-178).
20 bronze coins found with a ceramic vessel. Only eight pieces were recovered: 2 sestertii, 3 dupondii, 3 asses: Antoninus Pius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Museum History and Archaeology, Constanța, Romania

summary: 32 coins: 1 republican denarius, 31 bronze coins: Augustus - Septimius Severus (AD 197-198).
The hoard comprised 86 denarii from Mark Antony to Antoninus Pius (AD 143).
2 denarii of Hadrian (AD 117-138).
Three Roman bronze coins (Trajan - Marcus Aurelius Caesar) were found together in a field, inside an old foundation wall.
120 denarii. 32 were donated to the History Museum in Silistra: Mark Antony - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).

A hoard of 298 aurei dating from Nero to Lucius Verus was discovered in Vienna in 1799 during the construction of the Wiener Neustadt Canal. Of the 298 aurei, 24 were stolen and 274 initially were recovered. There is information for 279 coins: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180). The average weight of the coins was 6.3g.
disposition: Münzkabinett, Kunsthistorischen Museum, Vienna, Austria (191 coins)

summary: Around 100 denarii found with a ceramic vessel. Only 29 coins were recovered and sherds from the vessel: Vespasian – Commodus (Divus Marcus Aurelius ) (AD 180).
Unknown originally number of coins found by metal detecting. Only 41 denarii are recorded: Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II Diva) (AD 176).
Nine denarii placed in a cavity: Hadrian - Commodus (AD 185).
The hoard comprised a broken ceramic vessel containing 400 sestertii, dupondii and asses from Vespasian to Commodus. Most were very worn.

Four bronze coins (Trajan - Marcus Aurelius), found on the Dowe-See estate on the Bullenteich in Braunschweig, next to other small Roman objects (bronze fibula, bronze ring, glass pearls, spindle whorl, etc.).
Hoard of didrachms and drachms of the 1st and 2nd centuries AD. 8 coins have been purchased by the local museum in Zugdidi: 5 didrachms Trajan, 2 didrachms Hadrian, 1 drachm Trajan.

A large hoard of gold coins (ca. 8 kg), found 40 km south of Mardin in 1890. Gnecchi also reports gold ingots, though Regling doubts this. The hoard was dispersed, but 302 aurei (Nero - Marcus Aurelius) have been published by Regling.

Ten Roman imperial denarii were found in the vicinity of ancient Olbia, to the west of Adzhigolskaya Balka, near the villages of Dmitrivka and Ivanivka (the exact location is not known). The coins have been identified by V. Stolba and U. Peter from photographs. The cirent location of the hoard is unknown.
A an aureus of Commodus and an imitation were acquired by Nagpur Museum.
A large hoard of denarii and a few bronze coins was found during construction works in 1957. Only 139 coins (Vespasian-Marcus Aurelius, 70-180 AD) were recovered but subsequently stolen in 1972-1973.
85 denarii: Nerva - Didius Julianus (AD 193).
The hoard of 175 gold and silver Iron Age coins, and 23 Roman denarii, ranging from from c. 50 BC to the latter half of the second century AD, uncovered on a field at Waltham St. Lawrence.
From 465 only 60 denari are known: Nero - Hadrian (AD 117-138). Found in a ceramic vessel.
157 coins found in a ceramic vessel: Mark Antony - Marcus Aurelius (AD 162-163).
Hoard of unknown number of bronze coins. 1 coin of Antoninus Pius and 1 of Faustina I (Augusta/Diva) were seen.

The hoard comprised either a) a ceramic vessel containing several hundred sestertii of Nero to Marcus Aurelius. b) two ceramic vessels found on separate occasions containing 60 and 110 coins respectively.

96 coins: 10 silver denarii, 1 quinarius, the other 85 coins are copper asses, dupondii and sestertii, and 1 unknown copper denomination. Other finds include 18 wire fibulae, a fragment of a bracelet and 1 unidentified artefact. Antoninus Pius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 138-180).
Hoard of 15 imperial denarii found with a jug in an inhumation grave: Nero - Hadrian (AD 134-138).
1000 denarii found in a ceramic vessel - metal detecting - in an ancient building. The latest coins belong to Antoninus Pius.
23 denarii, group of single finds, found within a settlement: Hadrian - Commodus (AD 183-184); silver weight: 57.89 g.
The hoard comprises 17 asses from Vespasian to Hadrian (AD 117-138).

A hoard of about 20-25 Roman imperial denarii: Trajan - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180) was discovered by treasure hunter in the late 2010s between the villages of Pysarivka and Hrushkivtsi in the Vinnytsia region. The coins were found on an area of ca. 20x20 m and all had the same traces of bronze oxides. The finder did not provide a photo of the coins, but said that among the coins were denarii of Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Faustina (I or II?), Marcus Aurelius (including those with the rank of Caesar). The further fate of the coins is unknown.
Two denarii: Trajan, Marcus Aurelius.

The first 20 (?) denarii from the hoard were discovered by schoolchildren in 1968, eight of them were transferred to the Coin Room of the Belarusian State University. V. Ryabtsevich tried to establish the place where the hoard was found, but to no avail. In the first hoard's publication the village of Žukievičy was named as its location. After that, at the hoard's place, amateurs conducted further searches for it. Separate denarii were found, two of which (Trajan and Antoninus Pius) were transferred by V. Kakareka to the Coin Room of the Belarusian University. The rest of the hoard was discovered by treasure hunters in 2011 near the village of Aliekšycy: 426 denarii and 18 fragments of brooches, which were donated to the Museum of the National Bank of the Republic of Belarus. Later, 10 more coins were transferred there. In total, 446 coins are known from the hoard (Vespasian-Septimius Severus).
disposition: Coin Room of the Belarusian State University (10 coins); Museum of the National Bank of the Republic of Belarus (436 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised 218 Syrian tetradrachms from the reigns of Nero to Hadrian.
17 denarii: Titus - Hadrian (AD 117).

During the construction of the protestant Alumneum (Gesandtstraße) in 1900, remains of a hypocaust system were found. Within the debris a group of 8 coins - 7 aurei and 1 denarius - were recovered, ranging from Nero to Antoninus Pius. They might have been stored in a wooden box or leather bag. The hoard's deposition is conjectured to have been linked to the Marcomannic Wars.
A hoard of 138 denarii (Galba - Hadrian), found at Sleddle Mouth, Mallerstang Edge, concealed in a hole in the ground and covered by a flat stone.
disposition: Carlisle Museum and Art Gallery (part); British Museum (part)

summary: 18 denarii of which two imitations (one hybrid) found as a lump: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194). The imitation denarii were struck with the same dies as other two denarii found in Ukraine (Dymowski 2017)
17 denarii and 1 aureus: Gaius - Hadrian (AD 121-123).

This hoard was found in three ceramic pots and contained more than 4000 silver coins from which H. Ceka has published a total of about 3900 Roman Imperial coins in 1958. According to the publication of the hoard, which refers to the inquiry held by the Albanian Institutions at the time of the discovery, the hoard was constituted by silver coins and gold jewelry (rings, necklaces) but the latter was dispersed immediately after the discovery. Also, more than 100 coins were dispersed after the discovery. The coins are mostly Denarius dating from Nero to Marcus Aurelius (54-175 AD). Based on the numismatic data (there is no archaeological excavation that can help at the precision of the hoard's burying date), it should have been buried around or short after 170 AD.
disposition: The hoard is actually part of the collection of the Coin Cabinet, Institute of Archaeology, Albania

summary: 107 denarii were found in a ceramic vessel together with 6 silver bracelets (3 pairs), a plated silver brooch and glass beads. No further informationn
A hoard of sestertii of which 4 pieces are known: Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Faustina II and Lucilla.
Large hoard of silver coins. Only 7 denarii are kept in the museum of Pleven: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Okrazen Istoriceski Muzej, Pleven, Bulgaria; inv.no. 1452 1-7

summary: 33 denarii (Mark Antony to Antoninus Pius) found by a party of schoolchildren among rubble in a chamber of the prehistoric and Roman mine workings beneath the hill fort at Llanymynech Ogof. The coins were fused together before being separated by a local antiquarian. A piece of black pottery picked up on another occasion close to the site of the discovery may possibly indicate that the hoard has been disturbed at some time.
disposition: National Museums Wales, Cardiff (part); Oswestry Museum (part)

summary: 13 denarii found in a room of a Germanic house: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 169-170).

A hoard of an unknown number of coins. Only three coins entered a museum collection: Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius. Another denarius of Nerva comes from the same place, most likely part of the hoard

The hoard of 79 denarii (one Republican denarius; imperial coins range from Nero to Antoninus Pius) and one Lycian drachm was found in 1882 during plowing of a court at Middels-Osterloog. The coins lay in a container.
33 denarii: Republic - Hadrian (AD 125-128)
disposition: County Museum of Bistrița-Năsăud, Bistrița, Romania; Inv.no. MB 20918-20950

summary: 83 bronze coins and (silver coins?) found in a marble rock. There is some information on 28 coins: Mark Antony - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180). The three denarii may not belong to this hoard (Dembski 1977).
disposition: Museum Carolino Augusteum, Salzburg, Austria (26 coins); Prähistorischen Staatssammlung, München, Germany (3 coins?)

summary: The hoard was discovered in 1993 by Vasily Prigodich (excavator operator), during the digging in a chalk quarry (between the villages of Malyech and Kabaki). The coins were in a hand made pot. In total, the hoard contained 408 (or 409?) coins, but to study preserved only 383 denarii (Vespasian-Septimius Severus) and four barbarian imitations of denarii.
disposition: National Historical Museum of Republic of Belarus

summary: Discovered during agricultural work near the village, on a field belonging to the peasant Grigory Radzevich. The hoard included 21 denarii (Trajan-Commodus) and silver items (ingot and four rings). The hoard was sent to the Imperial Archaeological Commission in St. Petersburg, where the coins were identified by J. Iversen; then transferred to the State Hermitage
disposition: The State Hermitage Museum, St. Petersburg, Russia

summary: Group of 2 dupondii: Marcus Aurelius, Faustina II (Diva) (AD 175-180).
The hoard comprised 22 denarii overstruck by the Bar Kokhba administration (AD 132-136).
40 denarii found in a ceramic vessel. Majority belongs to Hadrian.
Four coins found in Jülich, during the construction of the technology center.
A little more than 20 coins were found (only 11 known and recorded). The coins were found while leveling two tumuli revealing some 'depots' of denarii Trajan - Commodus (AD 181-182).
The hoard comprised 26 bronze coins and 3 silver coins dated between the reigns of Vespasian and Hadrian.
(50) 25 denarii: Vespasian - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161). Found together with a silver bracelet.
48 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Vespasian – Antoninus Pius (Faustina I/Diva Faustina I) (AD 138-161).
disposition: History and Art Museum, Bacău, Romania

summary: A deliberate deposit from the excavations at Ashwell. E Ghey writes: Group 2002 T215 (5) consisted of items in a 'placed deposit' in context 203. This deposit consisted of two copper alloy units of Tasciovanus, four copper alloy units of Cunobelin, one silver Icenian unit, a pierced dupondius of Claudius, an as of Vespasian and an as of Hadrian. The non-coin objects consisted of second century AD Roman objects (a brooch, mounts, numerous fragments of iron mail armour and implements, a fragment of a pipe-clay figurine) and part of a Bronze Age spearhead, in addition to fragments of pottery, animal bone and cremated bone. The as of Hadrian places deposit (5) in the second century AD at the earliest; a time in which the coin evidence as a whole suggests a reduction in activity at the site.
92 silver coins, 90 denarii, 2 drachms of Lycia: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 175); weight: 292.04 g.
disposition: Muzeul de Istorie și Arheologie, Piatra Neamț, Romania (inv.nos. 28530-

summary: 514 denarii found in a ceramic vessel: Augustus - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
14 Roman bronze coins and one autonomous Histrian coin found in a small ceramic vessel: Hellenistic - Hadrian (AD 117-138)
disposition: Coin Room, Institute of Archaeology, Bucharest, Romania

summary: 12 bronze coins found stuck together, in a barrow: 5 dupondii, 7 asses: Hadrian - Antoninus Pius (AD 160-161).
disposition: National History and Archaeology Museum, Constanța, Romania (inv.nos. 81602-81613)

summary: 100 denarii found in June 2008 (Oswestry Area I), followed by a further 23 denarii found in September 2008 (Oswestry Area II), both up to Marcus Aurelius. These were regarded as two separate groups, even if the date range is similar.
The hoard was found in a broken ceramic vessel. It comprised approximately 150 'large bronzes' likely to be sestertii. The hoard was discovered by a farm labourer on the plain of Saint-Rémy.
Hoard of circa 350 silver coins. 26 denarii: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 180-192). A tetradrachm of Thassos (intruder?) were documented.

Six (or more?) Roman gold coins found on a field. First, three were found by labourers in 1845: Domitian (1 coin) and Hadrian (2 coins). Then came a report that "two years ago" two aurei of Vespasian had been found in the same field, and probably more, thrown out by the labourers as brass items. In 1860 another gold coin found in the same field was reported. - The 3 aurei found in 1845 were described in detail and documented in sealing wax (lost) and later copied in drawings (preserved).
Seven bronze coins: Hadrian - Antoninus Pius (AD 152-153) found secreted in a wall of a vaulted storage room during excavation of a granary.
12 denarii (Hadrian and Antoninus Pius) found among charcoal, animal bone, and other debris inside the furnace next to Turret 1.
25 bronze coins of which are know Augustus 1, Hadrian 1, and 1 of the two Faustinae (AD 138-180).
20 denarii: Trajan - Commodus (AD 188-189). Among them two imitations. Together it was found an iron axe typical for the Chernyakhov culture (4th-5th centuries AD).
(1006) 978 denarii: Vitellius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 177).
1,055 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Nero – Septimius Severus (AD 193-194).
disposition: History Museum, Piatra Neamț, Romania (1,042 coins; inv.no. C 706); History Museum "lulian Antonescu", Bacău (8 coins); private collections (5 coins)

summary: Three coins of Hadrian found in a tomb (1 aureus and 2 denarii), but the information does not look trustworthy and the coins are not preserved.
Originally, 47 coins. 33 denarii were described: Vitellius - Trajan (AD 103-111).
NA
Unknown originally number of coins, denarii and antoniniani (radiates). Among the coins were recognized those of Vespasian, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II).

453 denarii from Nero to Commodus (AD 180). The latest coin has the reversed inscription as: TR P V IMP IIII COS II P P. The composition of the hoard is described by D. Tacchella (1896) by of number types not by the number of coins (!). There are 224 types: Nero 1, galba 1, Vitellius 1, Vespasian 21, Titus 4, Domitian 9, Nerva 4, Trajan 13, Hadrian 34, Sabina 2, Antoninus Pius 54, Faustina I 23, Marcus Aurelius 30, Faustina II 12, Lucius Verus 6, Lucilla 5, Commodus 1, Crispina 1.
disposition: Some of the coins entered the National Museum in Sofia in 1895.

summary: Group of 3 coins: Domitian denarius, Trajan denarius, Hadrian sestertius (AD 117-138).
Hoard discovered on the surface and during the archaeological investigations: Trajan – Septimius Severus (Clodius Albinus Caesar) (AD 193).
disposition: History Museum, Târgu Neamț (23 coins); History Museum, Piatra Neamț (7 coins); private collections (6 coins)

summary: Hoard of 126 Roman imperial denarii was discovered by a treasure hunter on the outskirts of Uman in mid-November 2014. Information about the discovery of the treasure and a photo of 53 coins were published on November 16, 2014, on the Ukrainian treasure-hunting forum Violity. The finder reported that the treasure was found on November 13, 2014, in the forest on the outskirts of Uman. The coins were dispersed over a small area, and on the first day of the search, four treasure hunters managed to find 62 coins. On the second day, the search was continued by three treasure hunters, they found an additional 32 coins. On November 18, 2015, the same informant reported that a total of 126 coins had been discovered. The further fate of the coins is unknown.

12 coins listed as 'loosely associated with the hoard' from Cadeby in CHRB (no. 2519) and said to have been found 60-80 yards away. These were treated as a separate Treasure Trove case so an additional entry has been created here. They may have been part of another scattered hoard.
70 denarii: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 180-192).
7 denarii: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180). Two other coins, one bronze and one bronze of the 4th century were handed together to the museum.
Denarius hoard consisting of 17 denarii. Vespasian to Commodus.
700 aurei and denarii found with a pot, probably ending with coins of Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
Hoard of 11 denarii.
12 denarii entered the collection of the Pedagogic High-School in Iași: Vitellius – Hadrian (AD 125-128). Part of the hoards Strunga I and II.
764 denarii: Republic - Trajan (AD 103-111). Together were found four silver earrings and 3 silver bracelets found in a ceramic vessel.
disposition: Regional History Museum Vratsa, Bulgaria; inv.nos M II 3331-4094 (764 coins)

summary: (c. 3 kg, c. 900 coins) 196 denarii: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
Circa 100 Roman coins, silver and bronze. Only, 2 denarii of Antoninus Pius and Faustina I and 5 bronze coins (Vespasian to Trajan) were known.
1,300 Provincial bronze coins of Alexandria: . 'Acquired in Egypt by Dattari, who sold it to Milne and Currelly.'
disposition: Partly in Oxford, partly in Toronto.

summary: Over 1,000 denarii: Nero - Commodus (AD 186-191).
Hoard of nine aurei found in a ceramic vessel: Hadrian, Antoninus Pius 3, Antoninus Pius (Diva Faustina I) 1, Marcus Aurelius 4 (AD 177-178).
Ten denarii (Vespasian - Commodus), found in 1872 during peat digging. Two thereof arrived in the Oldenburg archive; an additional three were noted in 1905 in private possession.

A small hoard of 10 Roman imperial denarii: Hadrian – Commodus (AD 193-211) was discovered by a treasure hunter in March 2021 somewhere in Poltava region. Information about the find and photos of the coins were published on the Ukrainian treasure hunter forum Violity, March 18, 2021. The finder reported that the coins were discovered “in one pit”. The further fate of the hoard is unknown.
A hoard of 9 Alexandrian tetradrachms (Nero - Hadrian), found in house E.
Funerary find: 2 aurei in a grave: Nero, Marcus Aurelius
disposition: Musée Château d'Annecy, France; Registre des entrées, III, f. 114, nos. 3558-3559

summary: A hoard of Roman denarii comprising at least 47 coins ranging from Nero to Septimius Severus.
The hoard comprised 25 coins (23 sestertii, 1 dupondius and 1 Provincial bronze of Trajan of the Koinon of Cyprus), ranging from Titus to Antoninus Pius.
8 bronze coins: 5 sestertii, 1 dupondius, 1 as, 1 AE: Hadrian - Commodus (AD 180-192).
10 large Roman imperial bronze coins: Hadrian 3, Antoninus Pius 4, Faustina I 2, Lucilla 1.
41 denarii: Domitian - Marcus Aurelius (Divus Antoninus Pius) (AD 161)
The hoard comprised 2 aurei from Antoninus and Faustina II and 5 denarii from Trajan, Antoninus, Faustina I, Faustina II and Lucilla. It's probably a part of hoard.

Udmarken on Bornholm has yielded three hoards with a total of 217 denarii. All three, A, B, C, have been interpreted as being of either the same hoard or of chronologically identical hoards. A and B were found a week apart in 1853 and C was found in 1857. Udmarken C contains seven of the 217 denarii.
(52) 49 denarii found with a ceramic vessel of Carpic manufacture: Vespasian - Antoninus Pius (Diva Faustina I) (post AD 141).
Two denarii: Trajan, Marcus Aurelius for Lucilla. No further details.
Hoard of an unknown number of denarii. Only 9 coins were documented: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 190). One nummus of Constantine I can be considered as an intruder.
disposition: Archaeological Museum Warsaw, Poland (donation R. Turkievich, 1936 )

summary: 31 denarii found in a ceramic vessel inside a mound: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
Over 100 silver and bronze coins. 80 pieces were recovered: 1 denarius, 67 sestertii, 12 dupondii, 1 As: Vespasianus - Hadrian (AD 134-138).

The hoard was found in a niche in a wall structure and comprised an 'important assemblage of gold and silver Roman coins which were dispersed amongst the workmen. It appears that there were more than 2,000 coins, mostly silver issues dating up to the reign of Septimius Severus. There were two aurei of Commodus mounted in jewellery. Comarmond notes two aurei of Nero and a gold quinarius of Commodus. Issues of Septimius Severus and Julia Domna were numerous and well-preserved, but there were no coins of Caracalla or Geta. There were also numerous items of gold jewellery, weighing a total of 741g, which the brother supervising the works managed to collect together. The jewellery was the subject of a detailed publication by Comarmond. The hoard was found by workmen digging foundation trenches for a new boarding school run by the Christian Brothers.
4 silver denarii: Hadrian (Sabina), Marcus Aurelius, Faustina II, Commodus (AD 180-192).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv. no. 2562

summary: (c. 40) 27 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Trajan - Commodus (AD 190-191).
disposition: Muzeul Naţional de Etnografie şi Istorie Naturală; Inv. 18.494/AR 6.698-6.724, N 6.110; acquisition document 86/22.05.1986.

summary: Around 100 denarii, among them, one of Antoninus Pius for Faustina II. No further details.
30 sestertii found stuck together in a Roman edifice: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD162-163).
disposition: Museo de Arqueología de Álava, Spain

summary: Forty-eight Roman denarii were found with a ceramic vessel in the rubble of a Sarmatian house in 1995 in the area of ​​an Avar burial ground in Hetényegyháza.
The hoard comprised 22 aurei (70 ca.-158-159 AD) found most likely between the West Bank, Upper Galilee and the Golan.
180 coins ending with issues of Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180). Trajan was the other issuer recognized among the coins of this hoard.
The hoard was found during the excavation of a Gallo-Roman villa and comprised 6 sestertii from Trajan to Commodus with a tpq of AD.
235 denarii found with a ceramic vessel. Only 235 were documented: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194). Weight: 597.2g (196 coins).
disposition: The State Hermitage Museum, St. Petersburg, Russia (collection Iversen); University Museum, Kyiv, Ukraine (36 coins)

summary: 15 denarii: Vespasian/Titus - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).

A hoard of at least 595 denarii, ranging from Nerva to Crispina, found in the middle of the 19th century in the fortress of Krani in Cephalonia. The coins were given to the Numismatic Museum by the Phocas-Kosmetatos family (in 1970 and 1972).
The hoard was found in a ceramic vessel hidden under a stone and comprised 3 coins including a sestertius of Nerva, a denarius of Trajan and an as of Hadrian.
4 sestertii: 2 Marcus Aurelius, 2 Lucilla. Identification based on a picture. (Lang 2007, 257, fig. 153); weight, c. 80 g.
Unknown originally number of denarii. 8 coins are kept in the History Museum in Iași: Domitian 1, Trajan 1, Hadrian 2, Antoninus Pius 3, Marcus Aurelius (Divus Antoninus Pius) 1.
disposition: History Museum of Moldova, Iași, Romania (inv.nos. 680, 714/9, 744, 768, 774, 779)

summary: A hoard of silver and bronze (perhaps also gold) coins. There is only data for two coins of Antoninius Pius.
The hoard comprised 57 dupondii and asses from Augustus to Antoninus Pius with a tpq of AD 150 to 151.
Around 600 denarii of which only 17 provide information on issuers: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 180-192).
6 denarii, probably, part of a larger hoard: Antoninus Pius 3, Faustina I (Diva) 1, Antoninus Pius (Divus) 2
16 denarii found by metal detecting: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-163).
disposition: East Fife Museums, St. Andrews, United Kingdom (5 coins)

summary: A hoard of 18 denarii (Otho-Commodus) found during excavations at Dura Europos, in E4-15.
15 sestertii found in a grave with ceramic objects: Hadrian - Commodus (AD 180-192).
Unknown originally number of coins. Only 9 pieces were recorded: 7 sestertii, 1 dupondius, 1 as: Claudius I Commodus (AD 184).
Five aurei found in grave no. 6: Nero, Galba, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Commodus (AD 180-192). Together were found 11 drachms of Gotarze and 3 denarii of Augustus.
Two denarii issued by Marcus Aurelius (AD 166-176) were bought from the same local person.

The hoard comprised 2 denarii (Trajan, Hadrian) and 25 aes coins ranging from Domitian Caesar to Faustina II. They were recovered during the excavation of a inhumation burial (tomb 2/1965) in the necropolis and were interpreted as the contents of a purse. 20 coins are preserved today, and reliable descriptions of the other ones exist.
disposition: Ufficio dei beni culturali, Bellinzona (20 coins); lost (7 coins)

summary: In 1867 west of Gräpel on the right bank of the Oste river coins were found 2 ft deep during the removal of sand from a ridge of hills. The find totals ca. 350+ denarii (Augustus? - Commodus).
2 denarii of Trajan and Hadrian.
A hoard of denarii found at Brixworth, in 1892. It is complete except for one denarius of Antoninus Pius of uncertain reverse. Coins range from Vespasian to Crispina.

The 22 coins (sestertii, Trajan - Marcus Aurelius) are the remnants derived from a hoard of at least five pounds from a meadow (Eckenweiher) where Roman villas have been found. The find is labelled as 'Kollektivfund' in FMRD.
13 denarii found with a money-box: Vespasian - Antoninus Pius (AD 153-154).
The hoard was found in a vessel containing coins of the Principate, including 2 coins of Antoninus Pius and Marcus Aurelius.

A hoard of 49 denarii (Mark Antony - Commodus, including a Lycian drachm of Trajan), found while digging for peat in the vicinity of Dellstedt (Nordermoor). The coins were found in a cavity, reflecting the size of the original container (leather bag or wooden box). Eight coins have been lost.

100 denarii found in June 2008 (Oswestry Area I), followed by a further 23 denarii found in September 2008 (Oswestry Area II), both up to Marcus Aurelius. These were regarded as two separate groups, even if the date range is similar.
Found during excavations, in an early medieval cemetery. Tomb 569B: inhumation, male; among grave goods 3 (?) Aes coins, part of the "Tascheninhalt".
A hoard of five bronze coins (Philippi, Koinon of Macedonia, Topirus), found in grave T2 in Lithochori.
Six coins found while extracting stone: Antoninus Pius 2, Faustina I 1, Commodus, 1 uncertain. No further information.
10 coins found together in a tomb (purse?): Domitian -Marcus Aurelius (AD 177).
The hoard comprised 2 batches containing 24 bronzes from Trajan to Antoninus Pius for the first and 300 bronzes for the second.
Two medallions (Hadrian, Commodus) were found with a vessel. Together were seven bronze tintinnabula, one patera, and two iron objects.

About 40 aurei were found by a peasant while he was digging, he also found a Hindu temple. This is the earliest recorded find of Roman coins on Indian soil. The hoard seems to have consisted exclusively of second-century coins.
Unknown number of coins. 46 coins of Nerva and 31 of Hadrian were in possession of the antiquarian Fornier.

A hoard of 60 Roman imperial denarii was discovered by a treasure hunter at the end of September 2021: Vespasian – Commodus (AD 180-192). Photos of 45 coins were published on the Ukrainian forum for treasure hunters, Violity. According to the finder, the coins were in a “small pit”, not far from a settlement of the Chernyakhiv culture, on the depth ca. 15-30 cm. At the end of 2021, the coins were sold at the Violity auction.
300 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Trajan - Didius Julianus (Manlia Scantilla) (AD 193).

Seven denarii (Trajan - Antoninus Pius), set on a goblet ('Pokal') dating to around 1830, which were part of a hoard found in a pot at the beginning of the 19th c. on the grounds of the mansion of Welsede.

A hoard of at least 385 Roman imperial denarii: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180) was allegedly discovered in the late 2010s in the vicinity of Ivano-Frankivsk. The hoard contained mostly coins of "early mintages", and the latest ones date back to the time of Antoninus Pius and Marcus Aurelius (10-15 such coins in total). No further information.
Some aurei. Only five are presented from Nero to Antoninus Pius (Marcus Aurelius Caesar).
Hoard of unknown original number of coins found with a ceramic jug. 96 denarii: Trajan - Clodius Albinus (AD 193).
disposition: Museum of History, Kyiv, Russia (50 coins; inv.nos. AR/9256-9304); Local History Museum, Chernovitsy, Ukraine (46 coins)

summary: 322 denarii are issued from Nero to Septimius Severus (AD 193-195).
Around 800 denarii, among them issues of Trajan, Hadrian and Marcus Aurelius.
The hoard was found in a female burial and contained a box or casket containing 18 Antonine coins, earrings, brooches, a belt buckle and a terracotta figurine in the shape of a small horse.
10 coins. Unknown denominations: Augustus - Hadrianus (AD 117-138).
The hoard comprised more than a hundred copper alloy coins of Hadrian, Antoninus Pius and Commodus.
103 denarii, among which one imitation: Vespasian – Commodus (AD 181).
1600 denarii found in a ceramic vessel - metal detecting - within an ancient settlement. The latest coins are from Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
The hoard comprised approximately 1,600 aureii, from Julius Caesar to Commodus. Most of the hoard was immediately dispersed and sold.
The hoard comprised 22 bronze coins from the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).
310 denarii found with two leather bags placed in a ceramic vessel, ten meters from BIRNIE 1996-2000 hoard: Nero - Pertinax (AD 193).
13 bronze coins: 9 sestertii, 4 asses: Domitian - Marcus Aurelius Aurelius (AD 166).
Hoard of 40 bronze coins found with a ceramic vessel. Only 24 coins were documented: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 140).
Hoard of 340 denarii were found with a bronze cauldron. Together was a silver ring.
disposition: The State Hermitage Museum, St. Petersburg, Russia

summary: 5 denarii: Trajan - Antoninus Pius (AD 145-161) found during excavations.
disposition: Muzeul Dunării de Jos, Călărași, Romania; inv.nos. 46511-46514, 46518

summary: 103 denari: Vitellius - Septimius Severus (AD 197-198); silver weight: 262.8-420.7 g.
disposition: History Museum, Razgrad, Bulgaria; inv.no. IF, hoard 12 (103 coins).

summary: The hoard comprised numerous copper-alloy vessels, a mirror, a folding seat, Samian ware cups and plates and six glass bottles, one of which contained 40 very worn sestertii and dupondii of Nerva, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius and Faustina II.
Hoard of 320 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Nerva - Pertinax (AD 193).

The hoard of 126 gold aurei contained within the fragmentary remains of a small pot was discovered while searching with a metal detector on land near Didcot, Oxfordshire, in April 1995. Coins range from Nero to Marcus Aurelius Caesar.
Two denarii found on a field by chance: Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius for Antoninus Pius (Divus).
It comprised 210 sestertii found with a ceramic vessel, notably from Hadrian, Antoninus Pius and one of the Faustinas.
A find, comprising one aureus and seven denarii, was made at the south end of site XXVIII. The coins were found loose on the floor of a house of the Antonine period.
In 1857/8 at least 11 denarii ranging from Vespasian to Hadrian were found during building work in the basement of a house.
The hoard comprised 46 tetradrachms dated between AD 60/1 and AD 118.
15 sestertii, dupondii, asses: Augustus-Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).

HER record of a hoard of 32 Roman copper coins, "chiefly of the Middle Empire" found in 1772 at North End in Turville. Eight of the coins were said in 1797 to be in the possession of Col Innes of Ibstone House, of which there were 2 of Antoninus Pius, 2 "Faustinas", 2 "Vespasians", 1 Trajan and 1 "Aurelius". Source: Thomas Langley 1797 "History and Antiquities of the Hundred of Desborough" p.383.

3,997 bronze coins recovered from a shipwreck on the bottom of the Garonne river. The coins were recovered in two stages: 939 in 1965, 3,058 in 1970. In total: 3,663 sestertii, 270 dupondii, 33 asses, 31 dupondii/asses: Claudius I - Antoninus Pius (159-161).
20 coins: 18 denarii, 2 bronze coins: Vespasian - Antoninus Pius (AD 138).
18 bronze coins: Augustus - Marcus Aurelius
270 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Nero - Commodus (AD 183-184).
Five denarii found together: Vespasian – Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
11 denarii: Vespasian – Commodus (Divus Marcus Aurelius ) (AD 181).
85 sestertii found with a ceramic vessel within a burial ground of the Wielbark Culture: Hadrian - Commodus (AD 184).

81 bronze coins (72 Dium, 3 Thessalonica, 1 koinon of Macedonia, 1 Philippi, 1 koinon of Thessaly, 3 Roman bronzes) ranging from Domitian to Antoninus Pius, found in the foundation level besides the east wall of the first (western) room excavated at the place of the former sanctuary of Zeus Olympios, next to two other hoards (Dion 1999 and Dion 2000). All three hoards were buried in clay vases. The exact function of the area where the hoards were found is unclear, but the hellenistic sanctuary of Zeus Olympios had been transformed in Roman times, the wall of the temenos built over, and a theatre established.
A find of 8 coins of Faustina II, made in the area of Panagia Vrontou in Salamina.
The hoard comprised 13 sestertii from Trajan to Commodus.
(c. 550) 165 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Nero - Commodus (AD 181-191).
The hoard was discovered near the village in 2011. Consisted of 13 denarii (Trajan-Pertinax). The circumstances of the find and the place of the coins storage are unknown.
Three denarii (Nerva - Faustina II), found with others on a field in Halsmühlen.
Hoard of an unknown number of denarii. Only 4 coins were documented: Trajan, Marcus Aurelius, Lucius Verus, Commodus.
13 silver coins: 10 denari, 3 cistophori: Domitian - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194). Found with traces of a textile bag.
The deposit was found at the major Gallo-Roman spring sanctuary site at comprised three asses from Hadrian to Marcus Aurelius with a tpq of AD 164.
Hoard of around 1,000 silver coins: 999 denarii, 1 drachm: Nero - Septimius Severus (Julia Domna) (AD 193-211).
disposition: Poltava Local History Museum (954 specimens; inv.nos. 4919-4920, 5090)

summary: The hoard comprised 83 silver coins from the Second Jewish Revolt dated between AD 132-135/6.
Hoard of 47 Roman aurei documented in the archives of the Real Academia de la Historia - Antonio Delgado Fund: Nero - Antoninus Pius for Faustina II (AD 145-161).
Group of 3 Roman coins: Antoninus Pius (Diva Faustina I) 1 denarius, 1 sestertius, Marcus Aurelius (Diva Faustina II) dupondius (AD 161-180).
645 Alexandrian tetradrachms: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 166-167) purchased by Currelly and Frost from "native diggers".
Unknown initial number of coins. 145 denarii: Galba - Marcus Aurelius/Commodus (AD 178-191).
disposition: Muzeul de Istorie Națională și Arheologie, Constanța, Romania; private colection V. Heisu from Parava (145 coins)

summary: 6 sestertii: Domitian - Antoninus Pius/Marcus Aurelius for Faustina II (AD 145-175).
Unknown initial number of denarii. 11 coins provide information on the issuers: Hadrian - Commodus (AD 180-192).
Circa 500 denarii, of which 264 were brought after 1873 to the National Hungarian Museum in Budapest. 168 coins were identified: Nero – Antoninus Pius (Diva Faustina I) (AD 141-161).
Unknown originally number of coins. 42 denarii: Otho - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194); silver weight: 78.0-122.8 g.
10 coins found compacted together during excavations in Tofts Field in 1974. Recovered from surface of first re-metalling of Dere Street, to the east of the later fort, in Tofts Field.
Several hundred Roman silver coins (coins of Galba - Antoninus Pius / Marcus Aurelius are mentioned), found during building working in Minden, in or before 1844. The coins were lost.
Hoard of 21 sestertii. Among them coins of Domitian, Nerva, Hadrianus and Antoninus Pius (AD 138).
Hoard of 300 denarii found with a vessel. 130 pieces are known: Antoninus Pius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: At the beginning of the 20th century, in the collection of the industrialist Hertig in Łódź.

summary: 30 bronze coins: Trajan - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180). Found 800 m eastward from the hoard Koropie 2008 2
disposition: Laboratory of Archeology, Historical Sociology and Cultural Heritage, Faculty of Sociology, St. Petersburg State University, Russia

summary: 5 AE (2 Hadrian, 1 Antoninus Pius and 2 unidentified)
257 denarii found with an amphora: Republic – Commodus (AD 191-192).
Six denarii found together on a floor of a Roman edifice from the Dacian kingdom capital of Sarmizegetusa Regia Republic - Trajan (AD 101-102).
disposition: Muzeul Civilizației Dacice și Romane, Deva, Romania

summary: "About 100 tetradrachms and denarii together with a few dozen Roman coins (the latest being a fresh Hadrianic denarius...)" (Mildenberg 1984, 55).
A hoard of 30 Roman silver denarii, found at Waddow Hall, Waddington, and declared Treasure Trove. All the coins with the Lancashire Museums Service
Hoard of 120 denarii. Among issuers, Trajan and Marcus Aurelius. No further details.

Unknown originally number of coins. 10 denarii entered the collection of the Center for the Social Sciences in Craiova: Vitellius 1, Domitian 1, Trajan 1, Hadrian 1, Antoninus Pius 2, Antoninus Pius (Diva Faustina I) 1, Antoninus Pius (Marcus Aurelius Caesar) 2, Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus) 1.
disposition: Center for the Social Sciences, Craiova, Romania

summary: A cultic area with two temples was excavated southwest of the intersection of Groß-Umstädter straße/Aschaffenburger straße. One of the two temples had a quadratic cella, corresponding to the Gallo-Roman type. A small hoard of 5 bronze coins (Trajan to Antoninus Pius) and a complete set of cultic vessels was found in its immediate vicinity.
23 denarii found with a money-box: Trajan - Marcus Aurelius (AD 175-176)
disposition: Muzeul de Istorie a Județului Vâlcea, Râmnicu Vâlcea, Romania

summary: 92 denarii: Vitellius – Commodus (AD 180-183).
29 coins of unknown metal from "the 4th consulate of Vespasian to the 4th year of reign of Antoninus Pius " (AD 149.
Unknown number of Roman denarii, only 3 coins are known: Trajan 2, Hadrian.
disposition: Collection of Antonín Hofmeister (an archivist, 1945), Josefov, now missing.

summary: 47 denarii ranging from Nero to Hadrian (1 Nero, 3 Vespasian, 4 Titus, 6 Domitian, 3 Nerva, 20 Trajan, 10 Hadrian) were given to the Historisches Museum in Olten by the Schmid family in 1901/1902, next to 13 other Roman coins. Records say that all of these belonged to a find made in the vicinity of Matzendorf in 1841, but probably only the denarii are part of a hoard. No further details of the discovery are known.
Five denarii, from the reigns of Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius, and Commodus, discovered in a garden in Berlin-Lichterfelde in 1919.
Five denarii: Vespasian, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius, Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II Augusta) (AD 172-173).
Originally, 222 coins. 133 denarii are documented: Nero - Commodus (AD 185).
disposition: Iron Gates Museum, Drobeta-Turnu Severin, Romania (122 coins); inv.no. 562-683; private collection, Bucharest, Romania. (11 coins)

summary: A hoard of ca. 500 (?) Roman imperial denarii was discovered by treasure hunters in February 2014 in Chernivtsi region. Information about the find and a general photo of two part of the coins was published on the Ukrainian treasure hunter forum Violity on December 27, 2014. According to the finders, the coins were found in a field, on an area of 5x5 meters, together with a silver buckle (only the frame of the buckle is preserved). The search for the coins lasted for two days. This field, according to the informants, was quite popular among local treasure hunters. Some of the coins from the hoard found on the second day were stuck together. There are two general photos of the coins: one shows at least 60 denarii, the other at least 71 (there are also photos of this part of the hoard on a scale, together with the silver buckle: 336.5 g). These photos were published by different treasure hunters, so they most likely represent different parts of the hoard. I managed to identify only a small part of the coins in the photos: 13 coins in the first photo and 13 coins in the second photo. The further fate of the coins is unknown.

A hoard of 8 complete and 1 halved Roman provincial copper alloy coins (Antioch, Beroea, Laodicea, uncertain) from the reigns of Trajan and Antoninus Pius, found at Assur, iC6V, West, 50 cm below the surface of the hill.

A hoard of about 500 Roman imperial denarii: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180) was discovered by a treasure hunter somewhere near the Dniester, on the borderland of the Ternopil and Ivano-Frankivsk region. The hoard was found in a pot (a few fragments are preserved). Several coins were glued to the fragments of the vessel. The coins are quite well preserved (minimal wear). Deposit was not published on Violity, and was immediately sold to one of the collectors. The further fate of the coins is unknown.
Unknown quantity of bronze coins. Three sestertii: Claudius I, Nero, Marcus Aurelius were offered to the Regional History Museum in Ruse.
disposition: Ruse Regional Museum of History, Bulgaria

summary: Roman settlement at Rowler Manor Estate first recorded in 1991 during archaeological watching brief, when Roman pottery & two coin hoards were recovered. Later investigation revealed stone building remains & 4th C. mosaic floor. APs suggest this just one of many buildings in much larger complex over 5ha in extent.During work in 1991, 6 sestertii found as small hoard, initially by detectorists. Coins stuck together in a column after probably being kept in a narrow textile wrapping/bag. Coins from Trajan to Lucilla.Guest, P. 2008. The Roman coins. In M. Dawson Excavation of the Roman villa and mosaic at Rowler Manor, Croughton, Northamptonshire. Northamptonshire Archaeol. 35: 45-93. Hoard identified by Curteis 2003.

The hoard was discovered in 1850 by a private person during a search quarry stones. The coins lay concealed without a discernible container in the wall aperture of a Roman cellar (Quintan- obere prätorische Straße)). The hoard is thought to have comprised 360-370 denarii. 280 of them are now in the collection of antiquities from Nassau, in Wiesbaden. Coins range from Nero to Antoninus Pius.
Unknown originally number of coins. 28 denarii are known: Antoninus Pius – Commodus (AD 190-191).
Originally, 78 denarii, 14 preserved: Antoninus Pius - Commodus (AD 189); silver weight: 36.63 g. (14 coins).
6 sestertii recorded with the PAS, 3 further from excavation of the site (see Amber Valley barbarous radiate hoard). Not classed as Treasure.
The sculptor Zanda of Desulo discovered a deposit of Roman bronze coins, near the church of San Pietro. One of them belongs to Faustina I and one to Lucilla.
Unknown original number of denarii. 32 denarii have been studied: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 193).
Hoard of unknown number of denarii. Only two pieces are known: Trajan, Hadrian.
105 denarii: Trajan - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
Originally circa 660 denarii, 290 coins were studied, 100 preserved: Titus - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194); silver weight: 270.19 g. (100 coins).

Around 600 silver and bronze coins found with a ceramic vessel. Only 10 denarii were identified. The hoard was lost during WWII: Vespasian 5, Domitian 1, Trajan 1, Antoninus Pius 2, Marcus Aurelius 1.
disposition: School Museum, Brăești, Romania. Today, lost.

summary: Unknown initial number of coins. 40 denarii entered Museum Collection in Opole in 1973:
disposition: Municipal Museum Opole, Poland (40 coins in 1973)

summary: In 1931, 14 bronze coins (Domitian to Antoninus Pius) were found on the surface in front of the southern gate of the Roman fort, which were oxidised together in a clump. Some specimens show exposure to fire.
7 denarii: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-192) found in an Iron Age warrior grave.

From information obtained by Khaled Ben Rhomdane, the hoard comprised 2000 Republican denarii, although there is some suggestion that there were also imperial denarii including issues of Antoninus Pius. The hoard was stolen.
Hoard of 89 gold stateri of the Bosporan kings: Sauromates I - 3, Cotys II - 6, Rhoemetalkes - 11, Eupator - 69.

The hoard comprised 4 sestertii ranging from Trajan to Faustina II. They were recovered during the excavation of a inhumation burial (tomb 2/1957) in the necropolis and were interpreted as the contents of a purse. Only 2 coins preserved, but descriptions of all of them exist.
disposition: Ufficio dei beni culturali, Bellinzona (2 coins); lost (2 coins)

summary: A hoard of 10 aurei (Domitian - Antoninus Pius), found in the 1880s in Trier, in a small earthenware container; it was published in 1928 as part of the collection of Dr. Leopold Seligmann.
Unknown number of silver coins. One denarius of Trajan and one of Hadrian are kept in the museum in Ruse.
disposition: Ruse Regional Museum of History, Bulgaria; inv.no. 9, 553

summary: 1,268 coins: 7 aurei, 1,261 denarii: Republic - Hadrian (AD 136-138). Total weight: 4,023.93g.
disposition: Historischen Museum der Stadt Wien (Karlsplatz), Austria

summary: West Parade site Area III, Roman interval tower. In late Roman period, interval tower became derelict, & much of upper part prob. demolished/ robbed. Lower part of tower infilled with demolition debris, incl. ceramic tile frags. & mortar, animal bone waste from food consumption, & bird & animal skeletons, incl. ravens & dogs, frogs & toads, & remains of owl pellets. 3 silver denarii in fine condition also found amongst demolition debris, of Trajan, Hadrian & Faustina, minted in early to mid 2nd C. before tower even built; & it is likely that they were hidden & subsequently lost, poss. as part of a larger hoard, whilst tower was still in use.Gilmour, B. 1999. Excavations. In C. Colyer, B.J.J. Gilmour & B. Jones The Defences of the Lower City. Excavations at The Park and West Parade 1970-2 and a Discussion of Other Sites Excavated up to 1994. The Archaeology of Lincoln VIII-2. CBA Res. Report 114, pp. 191.
Unknown originally number of coins. Only 11 denarii are known: Vespasian 2, Titus 1, Nerva 2, Trajan 3, Hadrian 3.
The hoard comprised between 150 and 175 bronze coins 'mostly of the Early Empire'. One coin bears the effigy of Faustina II
A hoard of an unknown originally number of coins found by metal detecting. 44 coins were recovered: Republic - Trajan (AD 102).
disposition: National Museum of Union, Alba Iulia, Romania

summary: 4 coins: 1 denarius, 3 sestertii: Vespasian, Hadrian Marcus Aurelius (2)
(25) 15 denarii: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
disposition: Regional History Museum Vidin, Bulgaria; inv. no. 426

summary: 22 denarii: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 194).
A hoard of 24 denarii, found on the Dwoberg in 1795. Of these, 22 (Hadrian - Commodus) were found to be in the Oldenburg state museum.
11 denarii found on the same field: Caesar – Vespasian (AD 69-79).
68 coins: 67 denarii, 1 imitation: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (Julia Domna) (AD 193-196). Weight: 156 g.
86 denarii: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 155-156).
14 denarii found at a distance of a few hundred meters from each other on both banks of the Sonia River, the tributary of the Sona: Titus - Commodus (AD 185).
770 denarii found with a ceramic vessel. Among issuers: Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius.
72 sestertii found with a ceramic vessel: Augustus - Didius Julianus (AD 193).

The hoard (5 bronze coins ranging from Domitian to Faustina I) was found in 1964 northwest of the Jewish cemetery in house pit 27-29 of Ernst-Kahn-straße, in a depth of 30 cm. The coins lay in a varnished pot. The hoard remain in private possession.
14 Alexandrian coins: 13 tetradrachms, 1 drachm: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161). Found during excavations.
disposition: Museum of Anthropology of the University of California, Berkeley, USA (1935)

summary: 204 aurei found with a ceramic vessel, 97 pieces studied: Nerva - Commodus.
Unknown original number of coins. 15 pieces are known: 14 denarii, 1 dupondius: Mark Antony - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Museum of Moravia, Brno, Czech Republic (7 coins); Collection Červinkova (8 coins)

summary: 19 asses found within one square meters: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 177).
2 denarii found in mound: Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius/Faustina II (Diva).
17 bronze coins: 3 dupondii, 15 asses: Vespasian - Hadrian (AD 117-138).
The hoard comprised 66 sestertii from Domitian to Septimius Severus with a tpq of AD 195 to 196. It was found with a small statue of Mercury.
(over 100) 3 sestertii: Hadrian - Marcus Aurelius (Divus Lucius Verus) (AD 169).
Three aurei are said to have been found by Landrat von Weyhe. These might be the remnants of a gold hoard. Apparently, there was another aureus found at the place.

The hoard was found in a heap of stones without any obvious container and comprised 'some Roman gold coins. There is some debate over the number of coins found. According to Chassant, there were 5, but Leclerc de Pulligny suggests there was 'a multitude'. Pulligny also mentions a coin of Lucius Verus, but this is not recorded amongst the coins examined by Chassant. Found in a pile of stones with no obvious container.
311 denarii and 1 drachm, ranging from Nero to Commodus (AD 187-188), found in a leather purse while cutting peat.
Around 40 silver coins. Only 4 denarii of Antoninus Pius are known.

The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 85 sestertii, the majority of which were rendered illegible by oxidation. However, those that could be identified range from issues of Hadrian to Commodus.

The hoard comprised a total of 1,133 coins, including 1,031 sestertii, 68 dupondii, 26 asses, 3 dupondii or asses and 5 imitations: Gaius - Commodus (AD 188-189). They were found during the excavation of building C in a Gallo-Roman vicus.
Eight denarii found at Testrup Teglværk with fragments of a clay pot. One additional denarius was found nearby also with fragments from a clay pot. The finds may represent a series of sacrifices.
Coin hoard consisting of 54 Roman sestertii (Domitian - Commodus) was discovered in 1922 while excavating an old lime tree. The coins were stratified in three layered rolls. They have been lost.
Around 200 denarii of which only 8 have provided information on the issuers: Vespasian 1, Trajan 3, Hadrian 2, Antoninus Pius 2.

A probable hoard of 3 sestertii and one 1 denarius (Vespasian and Hadrian) found among charcoal and other occupation refuse in Room 25. Their date range suggests a hoard, but this cannot be said for certain as their exact depositional context was not recorded.
16 coins: 1 denarius, 15 bronzes were found as "cast bronze core" of 570g.
A hoard of 47 denarii (Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius), found in a megalithic grave in an urn also containing ashes. The grave was located 20 m away from the mansion of Fickmühlen.

A hoard of at least 24 Roman imperial denarii: Vespasian – Commodus (AD 180-192) and possibly a silver fibula were allegedly discovered by a treasure hunter in the late 2010s nearby village Semaki in Vinnytsia region. The coins were found in an area of 15x15 m. The silver brooch was found on the same area. Based on a photo of five coins, three of which were denarii from the time of Titus, Antoninus Pius and Commodus, one cast copy of a denarius with a portrait of Hadrian and an anonymous quadrans with a portrait of Mars on the obverse and cuirass on the reverse. While the denarii have general preservation and similar bronze oxides, the cast copy of the denarius and the anonymous quadrans are probably not part of the hoard. The further fate of the coins is unknown to me.
13 denarii: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 191-192).
Seven aurei found in grave no. 7: Nero 2, Antoninus Pius, Faustina I, Marcus Aurelius 2, Faustina II (AD 161-180).
Over 26 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Hadrian - Septimius Severus (Julia Domna) (AD 193-196).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology and Ethnology, Łódź, Poland (2 coins)

summary: Hoard of 89 coins of the Bosporan kings: Sauromates I, Cotys II, Rhoemetalces, Eupator.
2 denarii part of a hoard found on the same field like GANDARVE 1927, 1928, 1928-1931: Trajan, Antoninus Pius; silver weight: 5.57 g.
8 sestertii: Antoninus Pius - Commodus (AD 191-192).
Hoard of unknown originally number of denarii found with a ceramic vessel. Only 13 coins were bought: Trajan, Hadrian 2, Antoninus Pius 4, Marcus Aurelius 2, Lucius Verus, Faustina II, Commodus 2.
13 coins (10 provincial coins of Philippi, 2 denarii of Trajan and 1 imperial bronze of Domitian) found in grave T45 in the eastern cemetery of Philippi.
23 coins (2 denarii; 21 provincial coins: Dium, Thessalonica, Koinon of Macedonia) found in grave 12 in Sevasti.

Approx. 200 Roman silver coins found by chance as a waggon had crushed the jar that contained them. One of the accounts relating to this find gives a list of emperors: Nero, Vespasian, Titus, Domitian, Nerva, Trajan, Hadrian, the two Antonines, Faustina and L. Aelius Verus.
343 bronze coins: 337 sestertii, 6 dupondii: Galba - Septimius Severus (AD 193-196). Weight:8205.03 g.
disposition: Saint-Remi History Museum, Reims, France; inv. nos. B-C

summary: Five denarii (Vespasian - Antoninus Pius), found while digging for peat in the vicinity of the Buchow-Karpzow estate, probably only part of a larger find.
The hoard comprised 53 copper-alloy coins from Trajan to Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
Few dozens of denarii of the Antonine dynasty (AD 96-192). Only 10 denarii are known: Trajan, Faustina I, Marcus Aurelius.
121 denarii: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 194-195); silver weight: 322.18 g.
Unknown original number of sestertii: Titus - Commodus (AD 180-192).
disposition: Town museum, Kaliningrad, Russia (inv.no. КГОМ 1.18842/1-119); Archive Rudau (in 1911) (inv.no. Rudau_wNL_SH_1_3-150_2, Rudau_wNL_SH_1_3-148_1, Rudau_wNL_SH_1_3-150_1)

summary: 12 denari: Vespasian - Trajan (AD 114-117).
A hoard of one denarius of Divus Antoninus Pius and one Roman Provincial coin of Marcus Aurelius minted in Edessa, found in grave 22 in the western cemetery in Pella.
10 coins, a finger ring and a fibula in a wooden case with 3 hinges preserved
disposition: Musée communal des Beaux Arts et d'Archéologie de Nivelles

summary: 4 denarii up to Commodus found in an arm purse.
Unknown originally number of coins. Circa 200 sestertii were seen From Flavians to Septimius Severus (AD 197). Only 29 were available for study.

The 16 coins listed here (14 sestertii and two dupondii, ranging from Trajan to Marcus Aurelius) were found in the area of the Dampfziegelei in 1897 and 1898. All coins have the same patina and corrosion, so it could be a hoard. Further particulars about the circumstances of the find are undetermined.
2 denarii: Vespasian (Domitian Caesar), Marcus Aurelius (AD 163-164); silver weight: 5.33 g.
A concealed hoard of 22 aurei of 'Nero, Hadrian and the Antonines' found c. 1888. It is believed that the hoard was from Wanborough / Durocornovium, but this is not certain.
Five denarii found together following metal detecting: Hadrian (Sabina) - Commodus (AD 190).
Unknown originally number of coins. Only five denarii are known: Tiberius - Antoninus Pius (Marcus Aurelius Caesar) (AD 145-160).
83 denarii: Nero - Hadrian (AD 117-138).
A hoard of 61 Roman coins to Hadrian and 616 Iron Age bronze coins found some years ago in Southants. It was contained in an earthenware pot which was broken in the course of the discovery.
disposition: British Museum (part); Hunter Coin Cabinet, Glasgow (part); Red House Museum, Christchurch (part)

summary: 110 denarii: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180). Dispersed.
The hoard comprised 31 tetradrachms, 17 denarii, and 7 bronze coins from the Bar Kohba Revolt (AD 132-136) and one denarius of Trajan.
3 coins, unknown denomination: Trajan, Hadrian and Marcus Aurelius (Caesar) (AD 145-161).
The hoard comprised 5 gold coins, 15 silver coins, and 4 bronze coins dated to the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).
