A Roman coin hoard consisting of 106 denarii (Republic - Commodus) was discovered in 1908 during the renovation of a grinding mill, 2 km south-west of Unterammergau. The hoard was in earthenware jar, that had apparently been placed between rocks. The coins are now lost.
Unknown originally number of coins. 20 denarii are kept in the Town museum of Târgoviște: Vespasian - Antoninus Pius (AD 148-149).
Six denarii (Domitian - Hadrian), found in the estuary of the River Weser in 1842.
The hoard comprised 15 copper-alloy coins from Hadrian to Commodus and we found next to a skeleton.
Hoard of 17 aurei. Only two are known: Pertinax, Septimius Severus.
A small hoard consisting of 15 bronze coins ranging from Hadrian to the reign of Marcus Aurelius was found in 'Haus V der Kiesgrube Lerpscher' during excavations in 1932.
Grave find of 5 denarii (1 plated) Vespasian to Hadrian (AD 134-138)
The hoard comprised six bronze coins dated between AD 70-81 and AD 117/118. It was deposited inside the hollow part of a door frame in the tepidarium of a Roman bathhouse. Votive role?
Over 600 sestertii: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 180-192).
About 5000 denarii: Republic - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
35 denarii found among stones: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 180-192). Only two coins are preserved
Unknown originally number of aurei. Forty-five coins from Nero to Trajan were recovered. Seventeen coins were studied in detail. Nine coins were acquired in 1937 by the mayor of Villeurbanne.
Around 600 denarii; Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: In 1906, there were 355 coins in the Coin Room of the Royal Academy in Königsberg, 16 copies in the Museum of Prussia, Königsberg. The fate of the rest is unknown. Approximately 250 denars were melted down. Lost

summary: The hoard comprised Roman gold and silver coins: Galba - Hadrian (AD 117-138).
Unknown number of denarii found in two small ceramic vessels placed 100 m from each other. 38 pieces are known from one of the vessels: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 163-164).
disposition: Ruse Regional Museum of History, Bulgaria; inv.no. 1600 44-81

summary: 282 denarii found with a ceramic vessel. 222 coins were recovered: Vitellius – Septimius Severus (AD 195).
disposition: National History Museum, Bucharest (182 coins); Institute of Archaeology ”Vasile Pârvan”, Bucharest (40 coins)

summary: The hoard originally comprised 21 bronze coins found with an amphora: Vespasian-Antoninus Pius (73-145 AD). Only 18 coins are still available.
disposition: Soprintendenza per i Beni Archeologici del Veneto, Padova, Iatly

summary: c. 800 aurei: Hadrian - Commodus (AD 180-192). No further information given.
75 denarii: Trajan - Marcus Aurelius. No further details.
disposition: Museum of Southern Podlasie, Biała Podlaska, Poland

summary: The hoard comprised approximately 2,000 sestertii of the Antonine period.
The hoard comprised 6 Roman Provincial coins: Dion (2 Trajan, 1 Hadrian), Thessalonica (1 Trajan, 1 pseudo-autonomous Antoninus Pius), found in grave 7 in Sevasti.
Around 700 denarii found with a ceramic vessel, of which 167 provided information on the issuers: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus) (AD 161-169).
disposition: Museum of History, Lwow, Poland; private collection

summary: Over 112 denarii found on the top soil scattered. Only 8 coins could be described: Vespasian, Trajan (Marciana), Hadrian (Sabina), Hadrian (Aelius), Marcus Aurelius (Lucilla), Commodus, Commodus (Crispina), Spetimius Severus (AD 194). Circa 25 m from Jerzmanowice 2006 hoard. Most likely one owner.

72 aurei ranging from Vespasian to Antoninus Pius (with Diva Faustina I and M. Aurelius Caesar) found in the vicus of Lousonna within a house. The coins had been divided in two concealments of each 35 coins, hidden in the floor. Two further coins were found nearby.

In early June 1958, 368 coins (4 aurei and 363 denarii, 1 Lycian drachm and 1 as) were found near Barway, Soham in Cambridgeshire. Further finds made in 1977, 1989, 1990 and 1991 bring the total to 471 coins, ranging up to Commodus.
disposition: Ashmolean Museum (part); Fitzwilliam Musem (part); British Museum (part); returned to finder (part)

summary: (8) 5 sestertii: Domitian - Antoninus Pius (AD 150-151)
53 denarii: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180). Circumstances of discovery are unknown.
1243 silver coins: 1241 denarii, 2 drachmas: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 164)

A hoard of at least 70 Roman Imperial denarii was discovered in 2018 (?) in the vicinity of Fastiv. Information about the hoard on the treasure hunting forum Violity was posted on 16 December 2018, probably by its finder, who also provided one general photo of the deposit. The coins were fused into one large ingot and had traces of heavy exposure to fire. Three coins were found separately. A silver item in the form of a ring-bent bar measuring ca. 2.5x3 cm (possibly a clasp from the pouch in which the treasure was hidden). There were also small fragments of pottery nearby, whose relation to the hoard is not clear. Judging by the photos posted on the forum, the hoard was sold at the Violity auction. The further fate of the deposit is unknown.
A Regensburg employee submitted 8 sestertii (Antoninus Pius to Commodus) to the prehistorical state collection. The coins were derived from a find of unknown size in Regensburg.
IARCH record for a hoard of five denarii of Septimius Severus in a small conical lead-alloy container.
300 aurei: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).

A. Marsden writes: "Roman coin hoard of 17 coins, all asses or dupondii of the first or early second century. Many of the coins are corroded and in poor condition but the four coins of Hadrian appear to have seen relatively little circulation when they went into the ground. The earlier ones appear heavily worn. We might suggest a date of loss or deposition around the middle of the second century AD.1) Claudius, as, reverse Minerva advancing right, appears regular, weight 5.93g, AD41-542) Uncertain as or dupondius, perhaps Nero, ?AD64-83) Vespasian, as, reverse probably standing figure, AD69-794-6) Uncertain Flavian, asses or dupondii, AD69-96 (3)7) Hadrian, as, reverse female standing right, AD117-258) Hadrian, as, reverse female seated left holding cornucopia, AD117-38 .9) Hadrian, as, reverse standing figure, AD117-3810) Hadrian, quadrans, reverse probably rostrum, probably RIC II, 623, AD121-211-17) Asses or dupondii, illegible (7)"
Unknown originally number of coins. Only five coins are recorded. Uncertain whether they were found together.
disposition: Museu de Martins Sarmento, Guimarães. Portugal

summary: 583 antoniniani (radiates). The precise location is unknown. Based on the high frequency of coins minted in Antioch has been considered a site near this city. Coins: Elagabalus - Aurelian (AD 270-275).

A hoard of about 80 antoniniani was discovered by treasure hunters in the late 2010s between the villages of Stanislavchyk and Bud’ky in Vinnytsia region. It is known that the hoard contained coins of Gordian III.
A hoard of 50 coins found in a Roman building: 18 antoniniani (radiates), 4 denarii, 3 sestertii, 1 dupondius, 24 provincial bronzes: Antoninus Pius - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
483 antoniniani: Gallienus - Probus (AD 276-282)
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria (unknown number)

summary: The hoard comprised more than 1,000 antoniniani (radiates) of which 1,038 were acquired by the Musée des Antiquités de Rouen' 'Une pelleteuse heurta' hit the vessel in which the hoard was buried: Trebonianus Gallus (Volusian Augustus) - Tetricus I (AD 271-274); silver weight: 281.2-1296.6g.
disposition: Musée des Antiquités de Rouen, France

summary: 17 antoniniani (radiates) found in the wall plaster of a domestic building: Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) - Aurelian (AD 270-275); silver weight: 5.6-20.3g.

A pit dug through remains of building 2/3 at Alchester Road, contained small hoard of 3 coins of Claudius Gothicus (268-70) found "cemented together in a stack". The pit fill was black, very ashy with burnt & smithing material mixed with unburnt stone. This demonstrates with other examples in area pattern of coin discard comparable to smaller urban foci elsewhere, though there are interesting anomalies within the Towcester group that would reward further study.Brown, A.E. & Woodfield, C. 1983. Excavations at Towcester, Northamptonshire: the Alchester Road Suburb. Northamptonshire Archaeology 18, 43-140
631 Roman imperial bronze coins: Trajan (Plotina) - Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) (AD 253-268).
12 antoniniani (radiates) found stuck together surrounded by some organic remaines froma leather bag: Gordian III - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 258-259).
Hoard of circa 4,000 coins. 400 coins entered the collection of Gh. Georgescu-Corabia, including issues of Pupienus, Gordian III and Philip I.
1089 silver coins: 14 denarii, 1076 antoniniani: Antoninus Pius - Valerian I (AD 259)
The hoard comprised several thousand coins, mostly of Postumus. It is possibly a hoard described as being found in a copper-alloy basin.
379 tetradrachms of Alexandria: Nero - Diocletian-Maximian I (AD 295-296) found in a small amphora at floor level in an underground room during excavations of a house.
disposition: 329 coins in Ann Arbor, the rest in various Egyptian museums

summary: The hoard was found in a well in a Gallo-Roman villa and comprised two vessels containing a little more than 900 radiates of Elagabalus, Philip, Herennia Etruscilla and Postumus. More than 600 pieces were issues of Postumus.

Six denarii "fairly close together, possibly a small purse hoard. Not possible to obtain details of 2 of these, but the remaining 4 consists of: Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius for Faustina II, Elagabalus (AD 218-222).

of 4,033 pieces, 3296 were recorded at the British Museum: 592 denarii, Domitian-Gordian III; 2704 antoniniani, Caracalla-Trajan Decius, including 2 “Divi”. The other were all antoniniani of Gordian III, Philip I, Philip II and Trajan Decius.
The hoard comprised 11 sestertii: Hadrian-Philip I (117-246 AD).
disposition: Soprintendenza per i Beni Archeologici del Veneto, Padova, Italy

summary: A hoard of originally more than 200 antoniniani of which 147 were split up between different museums and a private owner. 116 of these were published in detail by Laser in 1972 (114 of these could be documented de visu by M. Schlapke in 2015) and FMRD gives a full list of all 147 coins. Unfortunately, the FMRD list is faulty. The mistakes are difficult to correct, as the coins are not all accessible any more today. As a result, all coins ever documented have been listed here, with three FMRD entries having their quantity set to 'zero' (0), as no matching coin exists among the ones seen by M. Schlapke. Surviving coins range from Valerian to Postumus. No trace of a container could be seen.
disposition: Weimar, Museum für Ur- und Frühgeschichte Thüringens (96 coins); Sondershausen, Schlossmuseum (8 coins); Gotha, Stiftung Schloss Friedenstein, Münzkabinett (31 coins, which cannot be identified any more within the collection) and 12 coins in private hands

summary: The hoard was found in a ceramic vessel and comprised 3,258 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Victorinus (AD 269-271). The coins of Postumus (and some imitations) made up a quarter of all the coins studied. The hoard was found during ground levelling works close to the walls of a farm; silver weight: 880.6-5928.0 g.

The hoard comprised 53 Roman bronze coins (sestertii?) from Galba to Elagabalus. A coin of Maximian I was also found but this is thought to have been a stray loss, rather than being part of the hoard.
117,000 ”bronze coins of the 3rd century”, weighing about 38 kg, buried in a pit sealed by tiles. Probably, they were intended for re-minting.
disposition: Institut national de recherche archéologique préventive

summary: The hoard was found scattered on the ground surface amongst the remains of a building and comprised 100 Roman bronze coins from Trajan to Severus Alexander. The coins were mostly worn sestertii.
59+ antoniniani ranging of Aurelian and Probus.
265 coins: 264 antoniniani, 1 bronze: Philip I - Claudius II (AD 268-270).
Before 1933, 20 antoniniani (radiates) of Gallienus, Victorinus and Claudius II were discovered in the Corgnac, now a suburb of Limoges.
56 silver coins found in a ceramic vessel: Commodus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2069

summary: 50 antoniniani (radiates) of Tetricus I and II were found in association with the jaw bone of a skeleton in a lead coffin, suggesting that they had been placed inside the mouth of the corpse. The coins were characterised be being excessively thin and were therefore thought to be minimi.
Unknown number of coins found in a ceramic vessel on the area of an a ancient settlement. 85 provincial bronze coins entered the museum collection in Plovdiv: Antoninus Pius - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2237

summary: Unnown number of Roman coins found duing the construction clay station. Among them: Antoninus Pius/Marcus Aurelius dupondius, Marcus Aurelius sestertius, Gordian III dupondius, Philip I (Otacilia Severa) sestertius, Gallienus (Salonina) antoninianus (radiate).
88 provincial bronze coins found in a ceramic vessel: Commodus - Elagabalus (AD 218-222).

296 AE radiates to AD 286. The coins were 1.5ft below the plough soil with no visible signs of a container. A circular, corroded stud with a narrow band and possible inscription was also discovered with the hoard. This is believed to be Medieval or post-Medieval and, as such, is not considered part of the hoard. A farthing (Seaby, 3992) was also found with the coins during conservation.Addenda of 618 coins found in 2104 added here.

A hoard of 159 provincial bronze coins (Septimius Severus to Philip I) and 73 illegible coins, found at Dura Europos in a room of the Roman barracks (like hoard 14, though nothing indicated that these were part of the same hoard).
704 coins: 2 antoniniani (radiates), 683 sestertii, 9 dupondii, 10 asses: Claudius I - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 254).
Around 30 coins found with ceramic vessel. 16 were recovered: Vespasian (Domitian Caesar)/Domitian - Severus Alexander (AD 231-235).
disposition: Civiche Raccolte Numismatiche di Milano, Italy

summary: The hoard comprised 53 antoniniani (radiates) (AD 270-275, Aurelian).
Unknown originally number of coins. Only eight silver coins are known: 5 antoniniani (radiates), 3 denarii: Caracalla – Gallienus (sole).

Over 500 coins were discovered on a parcel by a collector. G. Dembski have seen 68 denarii. Other scholars (Al. Ruske) expressed some doubts about these coins being part of a hoard: Hadrian - Severus alexander (AD 230).
A hoard of 8 Roman Provincial coins from the mints of Thessalonica, Edessa, Pella and the Macedonian Koinon from the period AD 222-235, found in grave 52 in the western cemetery of Pella.
Two radiates (Gallienus and Victorinus) found along with a gold ring beneath a stone in the valley side around Blaen-cwm-Pennant near Llangynog. No other information is available.
158 coins: 7 denarii, 151 provincial bronzes: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Archaeology Museum, Varna, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 21275-21281 (7 denarii); inv.nos. 5224-5376 (151 coins)

summary: 1,267 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) ranging from Trajan to Philip I (AD 247-248) found with two ceramic vessels.
NMR record of a small radiate hoard of 8 coins found whilst building a house in Keighley in the late nineteenth century.
339 antoniniani (radiates) found with a ceramic vessel: Trajan Decius - Carinus (AD 284-285); silver weight: 62.1-422.8g.
disposition: Landesmuseum, Klagenfurt, Austria (64 coisn); various private collections

summary: A hoard of 16 denarii (Vespasian - Caracalla), found in 1832, approx. 20 min from the so-called stone bridge between Rhede and Borken, on a field in Vardingholt. The coins were sold in 1843 at auction in Münster.
2,944 tetradrachms of Alexandria: Aurelian - Diocletian-Maximian I (AD 295-296) found in an amphora beneath the floor during excavations of a house.
9 sestertii found within the south-west district: Antoninus Pius - Philip I (AD 247).

On July 28, 1937, a hoard of 1478 silver and 2 copper coins was found in Rochester Road, St. Anne's, Bristol, in a pit that was being dug for a garage. No trace of any container could be found, though careful search was made. The silver coins were 1476 denarii (Mark Antony to Septimius Severus) and two drachms (Caesarea in Cappadocia and Lycia). Please note that Pearce and Mattingly's coin summary lists 128 denarii of Hadrian and 66 of Faustina I, but the catalogue includes 126 Hadrianic denarii, and 68 denarii of Faustina I.
disposition: British Museum (part); City of Bristol Museum and Art Gallery (part)

summary: Unknown number of silver coins found in a ceramic vessel. 138 were examined and 18 entered the museum collection in Dalgopol: Titus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: History Museum, Dalgopol, Bulgaria; inv.no. N. 0026/1-18 (18 coins)

summary: Unknown number of coins. 5 antoniniani are in the museum collection in Székesfehérvár: Gordian III, Philip I, Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).

Hilltop settlement. The hoard was found during metal detectorists' surveys next to many single finds. It comprised ca. 50-60 antoniniani (ca. Claudius II to Postumus), which were partly melted down and fused into a lump. A few types are visible: PAX AVG, MARTI PACIFER(O) and FELICITAS AVG.
54 antoniniani (radiates) found in a wall with a ceramic vessel: Gallienus (sole) - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
Hoard of around 200 silver coins comprising Parthian drachms of Gotarzes II, Vologases III; Roman denarii of Otho, Vespasian, Trajan, Hadrian, Sassanid drachms of Varakhran II (AD 274-291).

The hoard comprised 14 Roman Provincial coins, found in grave 11 in Methone: Dion (1 Elagabalus), Edessa (1 Caracalla, 1 Julia Domna), Thessalonica (1 Geta, 1 Commodus, 2 Elagabalus, 1 Julia Maesa, 1 Philip I), Pella (1 Julia Mamaia, 4 Gordian III).
The hoard comprised 50 to 60 'copper or bronze coins' found with a ceramic vessel. The better preserved pieces included sestertii of Valerian I and Salonina.
26 silver coins: 17 denarii, 9 antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 251); silver weight: 35.5-53.2 g.
600 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Postumus (AD 260-269). Found close to the hoard ETTELBRÜCK 1889. Silver: 592 coins; Silver weight: 161.1-740.3g.
18 antoniniani (raddiates) found in the dump of the ancient quarry: Gallienus (sole) - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
IARCH record of a hoard of 11 sestertii from Devon. For details see DEV-37EC41.
50 silver coins, 10 seen: Caracalla - Trajan Decius (AD 250-251).
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv.no. CLXIV in 1957

summary: 4811 denarii and antoniniani, found in one (or two?) urns, in the garden of the school. Coins range from Caracalla to Postumus.
(5 or 6 kg. coins, c.1500 coins?) silver coins, 16 recovered: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249); silver weight: 21.5-34.9 g.
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv. no. 2499; 16 coins

summary: Unknown initial number of coins. 12 antoniniani are kept in the local museum of Sevlievo: Gordian III - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
508 silver coins: 19 denarii, 489 denarii: Septimius Severus - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).

The hoard comprised a ceramic container holding less than 40 antoniniani (radiates). A radiate of Trajan Decius found at the same findspot is likely to be part of the hoard: Trajan Decius - Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) (AD 253-268).
The hoard comprised 7 antoniniani (radiates) of Postumus (AD 260-269).

The hoard comprised 16 coins from Tiberius to Claudius II and were found along with the remains of a coarseware pottery urn. TAF interprets the assemblage as being successive votive offerings rather than a hoard. The coins were found at the entrance to a cave.

A corroded metal container was found in 1937, in the garden of a house. It contained either 20-30, or ca. 15 Roman coins. The 4 coins that were inventoried in 1957 are antoniniani dating from Claudius II to Tetricus I. Coins are lost today.
The hoard comprised five hundred of Roman coins from Maximian, Aurelianus, Tacitus, Florian, Probus, Carus, Numerian and Diocletian.
The hoard comprised a grey-blue ceramic vessel containing 217 antoniniani (radiates) from Trebonianus Gallus to Victorinus. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of 66 g to 270.3g.

A scatter of coins from the hoard were found by a farmer. A systematic investigation of the findspot by Mr. Pioger and Térouanne recoverd a further scatter of 800 coins as well as excavating 3 vessels containing 3,600 coins (radiates and copies): Gordian III - Probus (AD 276-282). A catalogue of 1,941 coins was prepared by R. Boissel. In addition, there were 2,500 imitations and minimi. The coins were dispersed in June 1976, although some of the imitations were preserved in particular collections. A small portion of the hoard was found by a farmer. Following its discovery, there was a systematic investigation of the site. Silver: c.3600 (1941) coins; Silver weight: c.271.1-1874.1g
1243 antoniniani (radiates) and one denarius from Caracalla to Valerian I.
It is unclear whether this is a complete hoard or belongs to other coin finds (not recorded).
Hoard of 166 denarii (512.94 gr.) found stack together: Vespasian - Septimius Severus. It was found within the settlement of Chernyakov culture.
9 coins found near a broken money-box: 5 antoniniani, 2 denarii, 1 sestertius, 1 unidentified denomination: Septimius Severus/Caracalla - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
5 antoniniani (radiates): Philip I - Valerianus I (AD 253-260).

44 Antoniniani (radiates) found with a ceramic vessel: Gallienus (sole) 2, Claudius II 44. Together with coin was found a male bronze statuette of 75 cm height. Some doubts have been expressed about this discovery!
disposition: Coin Room, National History Museum of Latvia, Riga (inv.nos. LNVM NUM - CVVM 120193: 1-27; A 8173). 17 coins were lost during the period of the WWII

summary: Mint totals are given but not linked with coins. This indicates that a full listing of coins must exist. The hoard was found not far from a Roman villa, next to the ancient road (cf. Gallia 20 (1962) p. 429) The hoard was deposited in the Cabinet des Médailles de la BN. Silver: 1098, 3602 coins; Silver weight: 2577.8-6108.2
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles de la Bibliotheque Nationale de France

summary: Unknown original number of denarii and antoniniani (radiates). Among issuers: Gordian III, Philip I, Otacilia, Gallienus, Salonina. Uncertain whether this is part of the 1840 hoard also found in Echternach.
161 coins: 19 denarii and antoniniani, 142 provincial bronzes: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Shumen, Bulgaria; inv. no. 4428-4588

summary: 8 antoniniani ranging from Philip I to Victorinus 8, possibly part of a hoard found in 1935. The coins were found in northern area of Edlington Wood, below Crags.

37 provincial bronze coins minted in Marcianopolis 22, Anchialus 7, Hadrianopolis 6, Nicopolis ad Istrum 1 and Serdica 1. Y. Youroukova published five coins of Gordian III and one of Tranquillina, minted in Hadrianopolis.
Unknown initial number of coins. Based on the diameter it is assumed they were sestertii. 51 coins were examined: Hadrian - Postumus (AD 260-268).
A hoard of 40 provincial coins from Athens (periods VB, VB/C, VC and VI), found among brocken crockery on the floor of the kitchen of the south house, on the northern slope of the Hill of the Nymphs.
166 sestertii: Nerva - Postumus (AD 260-269).
180 bronze coins: Trajan - Caracalla (AD 211-217).
42 aurei: Vespasian - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 258); Gold weight: 237.9 g.
The hoard was found in a stone conduit at a mineral water source and comprised 67 Roman bronze and billon coins from Claudius I to Tetricus I.

The hoard comprised a small earthenware vessel containing 100 'small bronzes' (radiates) of which 86 were identified by the finder: Valerian I and Gallienus/ Gallienus (sole) for Gallienus - Tetricus I (Ad 271-274).
The hoard comprised 215 radiates from Gordian III to Gallienus with a tpq of AD 268.
disposition: Brodsko Posavlje Museum, Slavonski Brod, Croatia

summary: 54 from the 600 coins are known. All are antoniniani (radiates); silver weight: c.162g.
The hoard comprised 16 radiates from Aurelian to Probus, found on the Agora in Athens beneath the post-Herulian wall, lost during the construction of that wall.
31 billon tetradrachms of Alexandria: Valerian I and Gallienus - Aurelian (AD 272-273) found in a pottery jar during excavations beneath the floor in room of a house.

The hoard comprised 300 'minimi' which were very difficult to identify. One article suggests that it was possible to read the names 'Tetricus, Antoninus, Aticus, Constantinus etc' on some examples. Mandin confirmed that the hoard was of barbarous radiates, probably of Tetricus.
2,000 bronze coins, probably, kept in a wooden box: Hadrian - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
Hoard of 44 bronze staters of the Bosporan king, Rhescuporis V (AD 242-252).
(c. 300,000) silver coins: 1 denarius, 4,463 antoniniani/radiates: Marcus Aurelius - Tacitus (AD 275-276).

The hoard comprised a copper-alloy vessel containing approximately 1,440 denarii and antoniniani (radiates). Of this total, 1,424 were catalogued by Chanel. Silver: 1358 coins; Silver weight: 246.9-3528.5g
141 silver coins: 3 denarii, 138 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 253-259); silver weight: 178.1-367.1 g.
Unknown originally number of coins. 19 pieces are known - 7 denarii, 12 antoniniani (radiates): Commodus - Filip I (AD 244-247).
48 antoniniani (radiates) from Elagabalus to Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 253-260).
The hoard comprised 32 antoniniani (radiates) from Valerian I and Gallienus to Tetricus I (AD 271-274).

The hoard comprised 202 antoniniani (radiates), placed inside a sandstone altar and found in association with a variety of objects in copper-alloy, iron and ceramic. The latest coin is an issue of Postumus dating to AD 266.

Hoard found during railway construction work, in a copper-alloy vessel (not preserved). Mainly Tetricus or Tetricus imitations (N. Dürr, Beobachtungen zur römischen Münzprägung. JbHMB 1953, p. 34, mentions Bonosus - this is wrong!). More than 5,000 coins. 5% of these were coins of Claudius II (mainly Consecration issues, mostly of barbaric fabric).
1,892 bronze coins found in a ceramic vessel: Vespasian - Postumus (AD 260-261).
The hoard comprised a copper-alloy vessel containing 3,814 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Aurelian (AD 270-275); silver weight: 601.7-5745.9 g.
42 silver coins: 2 denarii, 40 antoniniani (radiates): Caracalla - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
The hoard comprised 19 antoniniani (radiates) dated between AD 255-257 and AD 271-272.

The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing between 1,500 and 2,000 third century bronzes. 105 of these coins were identified. All were radiates, although it was noted that originally there were a 'certain number' of denarii of Postumus. 100 coins from the hoard were acquired by the Musée de Poitiers. Silver: c.1500-2000 (105) coins; Silver weight: 473.5-2186.5
disposition: Museum of Poitiers; private collections (2 coins); some coins lost

summary: Found during construction work, partially supervised by an archaeologist, in the ruins of a Roman rural building; 15 sestertii, Antoninus Pius to Philipp I, found together with shards possibly of a container. The hoard has been interpreted as a 'Bauopfer' or foundation deposit.

A hoard of 71 Pamphylian bronze coins, mostly from Perge (64) and a few other cities, as well as one coin from Selge in Pisidia that ranges in date from Caracalla to Aurelian. These coins were purchased by John Mossop, which the ticket 'Perge hoard, Dec. 66'. It is unclear whether 'Perge' refers to the find spot, or to the fact that most coins came from that city.
2 aurei of Carausius, found in spoil after the construction of a building near Ashbourne.
A hoard of three provincial coins, found in a grave in Amphipolis.

10 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III 4, Philip I 5, Trebonianus Gallus (Volusianus Augustus) 1 (AD 251-253). Weight coins: 35.74 g. Found together with two silver bracelets and two Anchor type silver brooches and one bronze ring. Weight jewelry: 186.83 g.

The hoard comprised more than 212 sestertii and antoniniani (radiates) from Hadrian to Postumus. All the coins with clear reverses of Postumus were from his 1st issue at Trier, suggesting a tpq of AD 260 to 261. However, 16 of the coins of Postumus were described as having 'diverse' reverses so we cannot be exactly certain of this date.

The assemblage comprised a) a copper-alloy box containing 2 aurei, items of jewellery and a fragment of silk; b) a further earthenware vessel containing a large quantity (10 kilos in total) of small module coins (radiates). 250 of these coins were examined by F. Rever, with the most recent being an issue of Quietus; c) 50 'large bronze' coins were scattered on the surface; d) some iron tools including pruning equipment. It is not clear whether all the constituent parts of the find should be considered to represent a single hoard deposit or at least two separate hoards. Found in a field belonging to M. Denesle (or Denêle) in the course of digging.

The hoard was found in a copper-alloy bucket or situla and comprised 76 sestertii, 4 dupondii or asses and 1 radiate from the Flavian period to Gordian III and 65 bronzes of Postumus. These included 7 doubles sestertii from the mint of Cologne, 17 'large bronzes' from an uncertain mint, 23 'middle bronzes' of which many were cast and 18 bronzes of a size and weight which would suggest that they were imitations.
40 silver coins: 5 denarii, 35 antoniniani (radiates): Elagabalus - Valerian I (AD 258-259).

The hoard comprised a total of 130 coins including 6 sestertii from Hadrian to Trajan Decius and 124 Roman Provincial coins from Athens dating to Periods V and VI (Hadrian to Gallienus). This hoard is linked to the invasion of the Goths in AD 267. It was found 300 m north of the archaeological site of Eleusis.
Unknown number of antoniniani. 27 coins entered museum collection in Haskovo: Gordian - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
disposition: History Museum, Haskovo, Bulgaria; inv.nos. N 656, N 1039

summary: (+hundreds) 94 denarii and antoniniani: Caracalla - Valerian I (AD 253-259); silver weight: 118.9-243.0 g
76 billon tetradrachms of Alexandria: Nero - Gallinus (sole) (AD 262-263) found in a disintegrated cloth bag at floor level in room during excavations of a house.
Group record for a hoard of six silver coins.
76 silver coins: 54 denarii, 22 antoniniani (radiates): Caracalla to Treboninanus Gallus (AD 251-253). Found during landscaping and construction work at the Tennis Club, Cherchell.
28 antoniniani found during a fieldwalking: Elagabalus - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 256).

750 silver coins found in a ceramic vessel. 726 pieces studied: 502 antoniniani, 224 denarii: Hadrian - Philip I (AD 244-249); silver weight: c. 940.4-2135.9 g. Found together with bronze statuettes of horses.
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv. no. 2525; History Museum, Kardzhali, Bulgaria;

summary: 39 silver coins: 1 denarius, 38 antoniniani (radiates): Elagabalus - Postumus (AD 260-269)
disposition: Musées royaux des Beaux-Arts de Belgique (39 coins)

summary: The hoard consists of 73 coins found with a patera: 5 imperial denarii, 6 antoniniani (radiates), 62 Roman provincial bronzes: Trajan - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253). Most of the provincial coins presents early 3rd century AD countermarks.

The hoard comprised approximately 400 coins (although Ledru states the total was more than 1400 coins - an error?). Hucher compiled an inventory of 260 sestertii which were bought by the Musée du Mans Found in a field on the Villeneuve farm. Hollard gives a total number of 280 coins: Vespasian - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: Musée archéologique du Mans, France (1892) - 260 coins

summary: One drachm of Caesarea in Cappadocia (Julia Domna) and 78 antoniniani (radiates) (Julia Maesa to Gallienus), found in the northwest-west suburb of Kerch. 71 of these were published by N. Kunina in 1962. To these, Golenko adds a further 8 antoniniani.

Large numbers of moulds for casting spurious coins, principally antoniniani of the period AD 260-74, have been found at Lyons Court Farm, Whitchurch, near Bristol, in 1891, 1897 and 1960. Coins were found as well, clearly part of a hoard accidentally incorporated into the levelling-material. In 1891, 16 Roman bronze coins were found while cleaning a ditch: Faustina 2, Lucilla 2, Commodus 10, Crispina 1, Postumus 1, associated with large stones, animal bones, and sherds of Samian, Upchurch and rougher pottery. Followed the discovery of a bronze of Commodus, and one of Maximinus. In 1897, additional clay moulds were found and 2 bronze coins oxidised together (Commodus, Septimius Severus). The 1960 finds include a sestertius of Marcus Aurelius and 4 antoniniani (3 Tetricus II and 1 Aurelian).
727 denarii and antoniniani found in a ceramic vessel: Nero - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Shumen, Bulgaria; inv. no.8442-9165

summary: 1,168 silver coins - antoniniani (radiates) and denarii found while metal detecting. Probably, ending with coins of Philip I (AD 244-249).
The hoard comprised a vessel containing 550 3rd century ADcoins including issues of Gordian III and Philip I.
The hoard comprised 22 antoniniani (radiates) dated between the reigns of Valerian I and Gallienus and Claudius II (AD 268-270).
The find originally comprised 151 antoniniani: Caracalla-Philip I (AD 211-249). Further 36 specimens from the same hoard acquired in 1916.
Unknown number of provincial bronze coins found in a ceramic vessel. 22 coins entered museum collection in Plovdiv: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2168

summary: The workers discovered a metallic vase with 20 kg of coins (maybe antoniniani). Only 214 are now recorded, from Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) (Gallienus) - Diocletian (AD 284-293).
disposition: Berry Museum, St. Moritz, Switzerland (part of the hoard)

summary: The hoard was found along with several inhumation burials and the foundations of buildings and comprised a mass of 80kg of Roman coins. The successive editions of the museum catalogue have varied catalogues for this hoard. For example, the catalogue of 1856 notes 35 coins for Otacilia Severa and Trajan Decius; the catalogue of 1903 mentions 3 sestertii of Trajan, Hadrian and Antoninus Pius (possibly site finds?) and 'small bronzes' of Philip and Maximian Herculeus. The mention of Maximian, 60 years after the discovery of the hoard is considered by TAF to be suspect. The hoard was found during dredging and ground levelling work, along with inhumation burials and building foundations. Silver: c.25,000-30,000 (39, 2) coins; Silver weight: -
147 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Victorinus (AD 269).
4127 antoniniani: Valerian I - Aurelian (AD 270-275); silver weight: c. 1261.0-5249.0 g
disposition: Musée d'Annecy, France; inv.no. 3477 (3828 coins); 400 coins dispersed

summary: The hoard comprised a broken vessel containing more than 850 radiates (the total is estimated at approximately 1,000 coins). The hoard was buried in a cemetery, not far from the village. The hoard was discovered by chance.
The hoard comprised approximately 600 coins. However, only 268 coins were catalogued: . The rest were sold: Valerian I and Gallienus - Aurelian /Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
disposition: Instituto Arqueologia de la Universidade de Coimbra, Portugal (200 coins); Mário de Castro Hipólito collection (68 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised approximately 150 antoniniani (radiates). Only 12 were identified, all being of Valerian I.
Unknown number of provincial bronze coins found in a small ceramic vessel. Y. Youroukova examined 9 pieces: Septimius Severus - Caracalla (AD 211-217).
8,400 denarii: Mark Anthony - Elagabalus (AD 218-222). No further information on Hoard?tructure.
The hoard comprised approximately 200 silver coins, only for 97 of them were known the issuers: Antoninus Pius to Maximinus Thrax (AD 235-238).
415 coins found in a ceramic vessel: 413 antoniniani (radiates), 1 possible bronze coin, 1 possible denarius: Trebonianus Gallus/Volusian - Diocletian/Maximian I (AD 284-293).
869 antoniniani (radiates), barbarous imitations: Divus Claudius II and Tetrici (AD 271-274).
disposition: Thermenmuseum Heerlen; Koninklijk Penningkabinet, The Hague, Netherlands

summary: The hoard comprised numerous Roman silver and bronze coins. According to Tardieu and Boyer, the coins were found in three small vessels. The hoard was found in a field and given to the Musée de Guéret. Only two antoniniani (radiates) are known: Philip I, Trebonianus Gallus (Volusian).
10 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Postumus (AD 260-269); silver weight: 3.7-11.5 g.
58 tetradrachms of Alexandria, 1 bronze coin: Vespasian - Diocletian-Maximian I (AD 294-295). Found in a heap beneath the floor of a passageway during excavations of a house.
disposition: 57 in Ann Arbor, the rest in Cairo

summary: The hoard comprised 57 radiates recovered by excavators from the Touring Club de France in 1966. To these it is possible to add another 40 coins of the same date found at the same findspot in 1899 and likely to be part of the hoard. The hoard was found on two separate occasions. The first coins were found in 1899. The circumstances of their discovery are unknown. A second group of coins were then discovered during an archaeological excavation in 1966. Silver: 9, 48 coins; Silver weight: 2.7
Unknown initial number of coins. 7 silver coins seen by T. Gerasimov: 2 denarii, 5 antoniniani: Severus Alexander - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); silver weight: 10.4-17.2 g.

In the summer of 1935, a third, smaller, hoard composed of 59 antoniniani from Gallienus to Probus was found in Edlington among the rocks known as the Crags. Some fragments of a native calcite-gritted jar, found near the coins, may have formed their container. One coin of Salonina and one of Tetricus II were found some time after the main hoard, but clearly belonged to it.
179 antoniniani (radiates) and 2 forgeries (antoniniani): Gordian III - Postumus (AD 260-269).
2,266 antoniniani (radiates) found in a bronze vessel: Septimius Severus - Probus (AD 277).
140 silver coins: 26 denarii, 114 antoniniani: Septimius Severus to Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); silver weight: 175.6-362.9 g.
1,680 silver coins: 1085 denarii, 595 antoniniani: Commodus - Valerian I (Gallienus (AD 254); silver weight: 2151.6-3837.1 g.
More than 1000 silver coins (Trajan - Postumus), found while establishing a water ditch on a field. The composition of the hoard is difficult to reconstruct, see FMRD for details.
356 silver coins: 294 denarii, 62 antoniniani: Vespasian - Gordian III (AD 243-244); silver weight: 490.5-1026.8 g.
disposition: National History Museum of Romania, Bucharest, Romania (348 coins), County Museum Tg. Jiu, Romania (8 coins)

summary: Hoard of 80 coins of Bosporan kings (AD 232-254). One denarius of Severus Alexander among the coins.

The hoard comprises 32 antoniniani (radiates) from Aurelian to Numerian). The first publication by Taracena notes 1 coin of Aurelian and 2 of Numerian. However, Gurt notes 2 examples of Aurelian and 1 of Numerian.

The hoard comprised 9,000 antoniniani (radiates) (35kg) found in a terracotta vessel: Valerian I - Dioletian/Maximian I (AD 284-293). L. Dancoisne bought 1000 of the more interesting and better conserved coins, which may not be representative of the whole assemblage. Found whilst digging in garden; silver weight: 1621.1-11249.1 g+.
1,049 bronze coins found in three ceramic vessels placed one next to the other: 1,045 sestertii, 3 dupondii, 1 as: Nero - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Cabinet des médailles de la Bibliothèque Nationale de France

summary: Unknown number of provincial bronze coins. 42 pieces entered the museum collection in Varna: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Archaeology Museum, Varna, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 4328-4372 (45 coins)

summary: The hoard was found when a farmer noticed coins in a molehill. The villagers then excavated the area and found a stone vault from which two copper-alloy vessels were recovered, along with between 25,000 and 30,000 silver and billon coins which had placed in a pile close by. One vessel contained jewellery and some gold coins. The second vessel contained approximately 620 denarii. Fillon noted that coins of Gordian III, Philip I, Trajan Decius, Trebonianus Gallus, Volusian, Valerian, Gallienus, Salonina and Postumus represented 9/10ths of the the assemblage. The latest coins of Postumus date to Elmer's 14th issue. The discovery attracted attention and soon other villagers discovered two bronze vessels and the vault in which they had been stored. The hoard was dispersed amongst numerous private collections in 1856. These included Arthur Parenteau de la Voute (250 reverse varieties), O. de Rochebrune, Hanaël Jousseaume, De La Brière, Charvet etc. 23 examples were give to the Sociétè Industrielle d'Angers, 18 to the Sociétè des Antiquaires de l'Ouest. Fragments of the 2 copper-alloy vessels were acquired by the Musée de la Roche-sur-Yon and some coins, including the sestertius of Julia Domna. The Musée archéologique de Nantes acquired 4 spoons, 18 finger rings, 2 earrings, 2 bracelets and 414 coins, of which 212 were of Postumus.

170 bronze coins: 83 official, 87 provincial of Alexandria (Domitian - Maximian I). During excavations in this region, where many Roman settlements are known, this lot was presented to de Looz by the mayor of Hannut.
30 silver coins, denarii and antoniniani. 12 pieces were recovered: 5 antoniniani, 7 denarii: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249); silver weight: 39.0-70.0 g.
Unknown number of denarii. 56 coins entered the museum collection in Plovdiv: Nero - Caracalla (AD 211-217).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2590

summary: 3456 antoniniani: Valerian I - Carinus (AD 283-285); silver weight: 623.2-4318.9 g.
disposition: Regional History Museum, Haskovo, Bulgaria; inv. no. N 326 - N 328

summary: A hoard of an unknown number of denarii and antoniniani (radiates). Only 5 coins are documented: Domitian, Trajan, Antoninus Pius, Commodus, Philip I (AD ).
Circa 20 sestertii of Gordian III (AD 238-244) found in a layer of ashes.
+8 kg, c. 2000 (515) antoniniani (radiates): Valerian - Claudius II (AD 268-270); silver weight: c. 541.0-2499.0g (after Hobbs).
A hoard of 28 antoniniani, ranging from Gordian III to Valerian I, discovered in an earthenware container at a field in Mettenbach.
(110) 15 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - ValerianI-Gallienus (AD 253-268); silver weight: 137.5-160.6 g.
disposition: Regional History Museum, Vratsa, Bulgaria; inv.nos. M I 161-176 (15 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised a small greyware vessel containing 50 silver and billon Roman coins ending in issues of Postumus. It was found not far from TAF VIII/2.1 (Oise) (CHRE 3546).
24 large bronze cooins (sestertii and double sestertii?): Domitian - Postumus (AD 260-268).
(200+) 103 silver coins: 78 denarii, 25 antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 246)
51 bronze coins: 18 sestertii, 2 dupondii?, 31 provincial coins: Marcus Aurelius - Maximinus I Thrax (AD 235-238). Together, were found bronze finger-rings, and fragments of bracelets.

The hoard comprised a greyware vessel containing approximately 225 coins, apparently 209 denarii from Clodius Albinus to Gordian III and an as of Caracalla. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of between 305.5g and 698g.
(250) 180 silver coins: Hadrian - Gordian III (AD 238-244); silver weight: 314.1-710.9g.
disposition: Museum of Slavonia Osijek, Croatia (250 coins) - 1981

summary: 65 billon Alexandrian tetradrahms: Nero - Diocletian/Maximian (AD 292-293). 'Presented to the owner by Felix Cary in Marseilles and reported to have been found in Upper Egypt in 1760.'
disposition: 'Probably now in Gotha as the rest of Schachmann's collection'

summary: 17 coins: 1 denarius, 16 provincial bronzes: Commodus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv. no. 2491

summary: Unknown initial number of coins. 69 bronze coins: Augustus - Philip I (AD 244-249).

543 denarii (of which 5 plated) found with a pitcher: Nero - Macrinus (AD 218); 1768 g. The mints of Alexandria, Antioch and Emesa are represented by one copy each, while the one from Laodicea by a total of 12 coins.

Over 90 coins: antoniniani, provincial bronze medallions, provincial bronze coins: Caracalla - Gordian III (Ad 238-244). Provincial coins were minted in: Pautalia, Serdica, Philippopolis, Hadrianopolis, Deultum, Anchialus.
Unknown initial number of bronze coins. 24 pieces are kept in museum of Lovech: 1 sestertius, 23 provincial bronze coins: Septimius Severus - Maximinus I Thrax (AD 235-238).
227 denarii and antoniniani found in ceramic vessel during archaeological excavation in a villa rustica: Maximinus I Thrax - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. no. 2548/1-240

summary: Hoard 2 from Housesteads. Brickstock and Casey in Rushworth ed. 2009, 375 describe the hoard thus: "consists of four Radiate Copies found corroded together (SF No. 9396) in 1981 in H14:4:7, the chalet barrack phase of Building XIV. The identifiable prototypes of the copies are issues of Tetricus I and II (AD 270-73). Deposition may have taken place early in the period AD 273-86 (Period 19) since the copies are of large module and relatively unworn."
1 kilo of antoniniani (radiates). Among the coins, 20 were issues of Claudius II (AD 268-270).
Circa 2,000 coins, only 3 known: 2 of Severus Alexander, 1 of Philip I
(c. 2000) (133, 46) coins: Republic ?, Gallienus - Tetricus I (AD 271-274); Silver weight: c.528.6-2441.5 g.
30 provincial bronze coins: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. no. 17

summary: 214 radiates after AD 280. Found in a pit post-dating the rampart in a concreted mass. One official coin and 212 barbarous radiates of small module, one illegible coin.

111 coins confiscated in 1981. The find encompassed 69 provincial coins from Thessalonica (Commodus - Philip II), 14 from Pella (Caracalla - Otacilia Severa), 6 from Edessa (Caracalla - Gordian III), 3 from Dion (Elagabalus - Maximinus); 1 from Stobi (Septimius Severus), 9 from the Koinon of Macedonia, 5 uncertain ones of 'Greek cities', 4 imperial coins (Vespasian - Maximinus).
26 number of denarii and antoniniani (radiates) from Septimius Severus to Valerian I and Gallienus. Only one coin of Salonina is known (AD 253-260). Hobbs estimates a weight: 33.1-66.5 g.
7 aurei: Carinus - Maximian (AD 286-294) and jewelry, bracelets and rings.
disposition: Numismatic Department of the Hungarian National Museum (Inv.no. 62.1946), Budapest, Hungary

summary: 24 provincial bronze coins entered the museum collection in Shumen: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Shumen, Bulgaria; inv. no. 1676-1699 (24 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised two ceramic vessels containing between 6,000 and 7,000 copper- alloy coins from Macrinus, Severus Alexander, Maximian, Gordian III and Philip I.
17 antoniniani (radiates). According to Boersma 1967, no. 175, they are dated between AD 253-268. No further information.

Found during excavations, in "Brandschicht" in a room in the western part of Insula 30. 4 coins, 2 antoniniani (Philip I and Volusian) and 2 missing, found together with fragments of a bronze vessel (lost).

The three coins found are likely to represent a portion of a larger hoard. The denarius of Balbinus was given to Desjobert; the second was given to the Mans Museum and the third to M. Nepveu of Bellefille.
disposition: Musée de Mans., France; Mr. Nepveu of Bellefille.

summary: The hoard comprised a vessel containing a gold finger ring, a silver bracelet and 28 coins from Marcus Aurelius to Valerian I.
Hoard of 14 gold stateri of the Bosporan kings, Sauromates II (4) and Rhescuporis III (10) (AD 225).
The hoard comprised 32 coins, including 2 denarii and 30 antoniniani (radiates) from Julia Maesa to Postumus. It is suggested that they were originally stored in a box.
79 denarii: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 202-210). "Only 18 coins were found at first, the remainder being recovered when an excavation of the site was carried out the following month."

In 1897 a hoard of silver coins was discovered a little south of the Ladenburg/Keplerstraße junction. Only half of the coins are known, because the others were sold to America. The list given here includes a Greek coin, and 129 denarii and antoninini (late Republic to Postumus).
Around 500 denarii found in two ceramic vessels. 230 coins provided the issuer: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (Plautilla) (AD 202-205).
A hoard of 120+ Syrian tetradrachms dating from Caracalla to Trebonianus Gallus.

The hoard comprised a broken ceramic vessel containing 33 aurei, one gold necklace, two bracelets and one gold ingot. The aurei range in date from Marcus Aurelius as Caesar to Diocletian. Hobbs estimates a gold weight of c. 171.6-221.5g.
The hoard comprised 120 sestertii from Vespasian to Philip I (AD 244-249).
The hoard comprised 43 tetradrachms and 95 radiates dating to the third century AD.
76 coins: 51 antoniniani (radiates), 25 sestertii; silver weight: 16.5-147.8 g.
A hoard of seven antoniniani (Gallienus - Postumus), found while extracting peat in the moor.
9 kg of bronze coins found in ceramic vessels while ploughing. 1076 coins are kept in the museum collection in Shumen: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Shumen, Bulgaria; inv. no. 7670-8441 (772 coins); inv.no. 8/1-45 - Harlanov collection

summary: The hoard comprised 34 antoniniani (radiates) from Gordian III to Valerian and Gallienus; Silver weight: 33.8g.
On an area of 3 sqm were found 22 silver coins: 2 denarii, 20 antoniniani of Philip I, beside a bronze lamp.

The coins were found inside a copper-alloy cauldron with a total weight of 45kg. However, the hoard was rapidly dispersed, leaving a total of 2,421 coins, corresponding to approximately 14% of the original find. This is estimated at 10,000 coins.
Six sestertii: Marcus Aurelius, Severus Alexander 2, Julia Mammea, Maximinus I Thrax, Paulin (Diva) brought together with other Roman materials: glass urns, bricks.
(c. 4.300-4,500) 4148 denarii: Vitellius - Gordian III (AD 240); silver weight: 5625.4-11847.6 g
disposition: Museum of Pitești, Romania, 4,126 coins; private collction Ioan Ciucă, Sâmburești, 16 coins; private collection Traian Cantemir, Bacău, 6 coins

summary: 2611 coins, 2594 recovered: Vespasian - Valerian to Gallienus with some intruders (Divus Claudius II, Constantinopolis). Silver weight: 9,270 kg.

The hoard comprised a vessel containing approximately 150 antoniniani (radiates) from Valerian I to Galerius (Caesar) with a tpq of AD 293 to 294. It was found during the excavation of the Roman amphitheatre.
273 denarii: Nero - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211).
22 coins were reported on, although it is likely that there were originally a few more (although not many more) in the hoard. Metcalfe suggests that there were originally 26 coins.
376 silver coins from Elagabalus to Gordian III (AD 238-244). Found in a cooking pot together with silver brooches, bracelets, fingerings, chain.
disposition: Brukenthal Museum, Sibiu, Romania; mixed with the rest of museum collection; National History Museum of Romania, Bucharest; jewelry.

summary: Unknown initial number number of coins. T. Gerasimov mentions 12 silver coins: 3 denarii, 9 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251). Found in a ceramic vessel
A hoard of 233 Alexandrian tetradrachms, ranging from Nero to Philip, found 1968 in Abu al-Gud, in the vicinity of Luxor.
51 coins: 50 sestertii and 1 as with 2 fibulae found in a looted Roman building
Hoard of circa 100 antoniniani (radiates), of which only 39 pieces were seen: Gallienus (sole) - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
The hoard comprised a cut half-as of Trajan and 800 antoniniani (radiates), which were mostly imitations from Gallienus to Probus.
The hoard comprised 4,000 sestertii from Augustus to Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 253-268).
disposition: Some of the coins were in the possession of colonel de Tourville (in 1846)

summary: 336 antoniniani (radiates) found in Szeskszárd at an uncertain location: Valerian I and Gallienus - Claudius II (AD 268-270)..

The hoard comprised a broken ceramic vessel containing approximately 900 coins of which 200 were dispersed. They included issues of Trajan, Plotina, Hadrian, Sabina, Antoninus Pius, Faustina I and II, Marcus Aurelius, Lucius Verus, Lucilla, Commodus, Crispina, Clodius Albinus and Julia Domna. The cataloguer mentioned these coins in particular: one of Diva Faustina, 2 coins of Divus Antoninus Pius (RIC 1262/1265 and 1274) and one of Commodus with a quadriga on the reverse.
15 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Valerian I (AD 253-260).
220 silver coins, denarii and antoniniani (radiates): Antoninus Pius for Marcus Aurelius (Caesar) - Philip I (AD 244-247).
Unknown number of silver coins. 42 pieces entered the museum collection in Kardzhali: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Regional Museum of History, Kardzhali, Bulgaria

summary: Unknown initial number of coins. 82 bronze coins were studied: 81 sestertii, 1 dupondius: Titus - Gordian III (AD 240/241).

The hoard apparently originally comprised at least 30 coins, of which only three are known. These three coins were photographed before the hoard was dispersed. It is likely that the hoard dated to the mid to late third century AD in date, due to the presence of a sestertius of Severus Alexander.
284 Roman provincial bronze coins of the 3rd century AD. No further information.
49 denarii: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211). Found together with a gold pendant.
25 silver coins, 5 recovered: Septimius Severus Gordian III (AD 238-244); silver weight: 7.1-9.3 g.
9 kg of silver and billon coins of the 3rd century AD. 2,504 coins have been noticed: Caracalla - Postumus (AD 268).
Unknown initial number of coins. 815 silver coins found with a metal bucket: Julia Domna to Philip I; silver weight: 1019.3-2117.9g
disposition: National History of Antiquities Bucharest, Romania (815 coins) - 1886

summary: The hoard comprised between 960 and 1012 denarii from Galba to Elagabalus. Only 413 denarii from the hoard were studied. Silver: c.1000 coins; Silver weight: 1411.7-3148.3 g. Found under some stones by a farmer
disposition: Musees de Beaux-Arts, Quimper acquired 350 coins and Brest (Sociéte Academique) acquired 41.

summary: A large ceramic vessel containing 15 kg of silver coins. 4453 antoniniani were published (Moushmov 1936): Aemilian - Carinus (AD 283-285).
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. no. LXIX (in 1925); 1,231 coins

summary: Small group of denarii and radiates and a finger ring found together, possible purse hoard.
277 antoniniani (radiates) + 28 imitations antoniniani (radiates) and 1 imitation denarius: Valerian I and Gallienus for Saloninus (Caesar) - Victorinus (AD 269-271).
disposition: Musées royaux d'Art et d'Histoire - Koninklijk Musea voor Kunst en Geschiedenis (Brussels)

summary: Silver: 1000+ (83) antoniniani/radiates: Philip I - Claudius II (AD 268-270); silver weight: 271.0-1249.0 g.
disposition: Archaeological Museum Zagreb, Croatia (978 coins); dispersed

summary: Unknown initial number of coins. 24 provincial bronze coins are kept in the museum collection in Sofia: Antoninus Pius - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria

summary: 26 provincial bronze coins: Marcus Aurelius - Maximinus I Thrax (AD 235-238).
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. no. CXXVI

summary: The hoard comprised 10 individual textile bags of coins, stored in a wooden box. Although only fragments of the textile bags survive, the way the coins have settled and corroded into 10 blocks makes it clear that they were originally stored in this way. The largest of the blocks of coins weighed 68 kilos before cleaning (and 55kg after cleaning) and the assemblage as a whole weighed 340kg after cleaning. It is estimated that the total number of coins in the hoard is 110,000. Found during the construction of the new Hôtel de Ville, in the area where the flight of steps up to the building were being constructed. The hoard was deposited (in its entirety?) in the Musée d’Évreux. Several portions of the assemblage have now been lost, but the remainder of the assemblage has been cleaned and conserved, with the exception of a single block of coins which has been preserved in its original state. TAF states that the hoard has now been deposited in the Cabinet des Médailles and a new catalogue is being produced.

In 1890, during railway excavations on the Shipley estate, an earthenware jar, filled with a large mass of corroded coins was found. These to the number of a thousand or more were quickly dispersed. Out of a casual collection of nineteen, may be read the names of Claudius, Aurelianus, Gallienus, Tacitus, Victorinus and Tetricus while others bear the names of Vespasian and Clodius. Cockayne added Postumus, Tetricus II and Constantine to the list of emperors included; G. Bailey, in Antiquary, XXII (1890), 187, added Probus.
100 silver coins were discovered. 24 have been seen: 9 antoniniani, 15 denarii: Caracalla - Philip I (AD 244-249).
Unknown initial number of denarii. 10 known: Antoninus Pius - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235); silver weight: 58.2-107.9 g.
170 Roman imperial large bronze coins: Hadrian - Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) (AD 253-268). Possible part of the same hoard as Capoterra 1928b.
31 coins: 29 antoniniani (radiates), 2 sestertii found together: Philip I - Claudius II (AD 268-270).

The hoard was found in a black ceramic vessel which was broken. It comprised 546 bronze and 'billon' Roman coins from the 2nd and 3rd centuries AD. It was a mixed hoard of Antonine bronzes and later radiates. M. Lepel-Cointet of Jumièges owns the remains of the vessel and some coins.
(100) 32 coins, 1 aureus, denarii and antoniniani: Vespasian - Valerian I (AD 253-260).
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; 29 coins; inv.no. LVII; History Museum, Lovech; 2 coins; inv.no. 1784 1-2

summary: The hoard comprised numerous fragments of silvered copper-alloy tableware accompanied by 21 sestertii and antoniniani (radiates) from Trajan to Philip I (AD 244-249). TAF interprets it as a deposit of scrap metal intending for recycling.
The hoard comprised approximately 2,000 coins ending with issues of Gordian III (AD 238-244).
The hoard comprised 4 coins of Severus Alexander (AD 222-235) and 2 unidentified coins.
25 provincial bronze coins found in a ceramic vessel: Antoninus Pius - Severus Alerxander (AD 222-235). Mints: Nicopolis ad Istrum, Marcianopolis
15 coins: 3 heavily worn out denarii, 12 provincial bronze coins found in a sacred area (sanctuary) in a small dish: Marcus Aurelius - Philip I (AD 244-249).
NA
The hoard comprised 40 coins of Tetricus I and II and were found alongside a toilet set, a glass vessel and a necklace in a female tomb dating to the first quarter of the fourth century AD.
Unknown number of silver coins were found in a ceramic vessel. N. Moushmov examined 119 pieces: Nerva - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
12,000 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) - 33 Kilos - found with ceramic vessel: Antoninus Pius - Gallienus (sole) (AD 260-268).
The hoard comprised a wine amphora containing 953 coins, including 937 sestertii, 6 dupondii and 10 asses from Vespasian to Maximinus I Thrax (AD 235-238).
(169) 137 coins: 5 denarii, 1 antoninianus (radiate), 1 as: Domitian - Gordian III (AD 241-243); silver weight: 10.0-16.2 g
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Namur, Belgium (137, maybe 169 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised 4 denarii from Antoninus Pius to Severus Alexander with a tpq of AD 228 to 234.
3503 radiates to Probus, in a pot. Full identifications of all the coins of Probus is unavailable. Unpublished?

A hoard of approximatively 400 silver coins discovered within a ceramic vessel, comprising a large majority of denarii (Trajan - Severus Alexander) and some Cappadocian drachms (up to Caracalla). The hoard was dispersed. Different accounts exist of its content, with Dundua 1979 publishing the 377 coins in the National Museum in Tbilisi (12 Cappadocian drachms and 365 denarii) and Zograf 1945 listing 417 coins (10 Cappadocian drachms and 407 denarii).
The hoard comprised 2,186 antoniniani (radiates) of Tetricus I and 'other emperors of the same century.'
8 bronze pieces: 6 sestertii, 2 medallions: Antoninus Pius (Diva Faustina I) - Septimius Severus (AD 210).
(100) 12 denarii and antoniniani: Hadrian - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
disposition: Ruse Regional Museum of History, Bulgaria; inv.no. 3426-3437; local school in Suhindol (10 antoniniani of Trajan Decius)

summary: The hoard comprised a large greyware 'olla' filled with small bronze coins, totalling approximately 2,000. These were partially dispersed although 500 coins were studied by Janicaud and 137 examples donated to the Musée de Guéret. No coins of the Gallic Empire were found in this hoard. The hoard was found when a farmer's plough struck a vessel.
The hoard comprised between 400 and 500 radiates: Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) for Gallienus - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
(c. 2,898) 1,902 silver coins: Marcus Aurelius - Valerian I/Gallienus (AD 253-268).
disposition: Museum of Vratsa, Bulgaria; inv.nos. M III 6406 - M IV 7503 (1098 coins); M IV 7507-8345 (839); History Museum, Vratsa; inv.nos. 8750-8839

summary: The coins (15 denarii, ranging from Marcus Aurelius to Maximinus, with the probable addition of a further denarius of Septimius Severus) were found together at the southwest foothills of the Lehenbühl, SE of Fridingen.
Hoard of aurei and jewelry: 94 aurei: Nero - Aurelian (AD 270-275); gold weight: 648.8g.
A hoard of three coins (similar to the coins of hoard Kassanreia 2008A) was found in a destruction layer in Room Θ, of the same large urban Roman building.
The hoard comprised 1,104 radiates from Valerian and Gallienus to Quintillus. 740 have been studied by Salama. (AD 270)
5 antoniniani without any certainty that they were part of a hoard: Gallienus - Quintillus (AD 270).
Two double-pierced gold coins, an aureus of Septimius Severus (AD 203), and its imitation were reported from a village.
Hoard of 281 antoniniani (radiates) found on the territory of the legionary fort: Valerian I and Gallienus - Diocletian (AD 285).
disposition: Museum Lauriacum - Museum der Stadt Enns

summary: The hoard comprised 50 sestertii from Hadrian to Trajan Decius. It was found on the Arcellier property, but dispersed almost immediately.
350 denarii found with a ceramic vessel. Only coin of Julia Maesa is known.

Hoard found during railway construction work, probably from the area of the site of a Roman villa rustica. It comprisesd at least 2114 coins, but no more than 2300. Coins run from Valerian to Aurelian, mainly Gallienus and Claudius II. Reported coins of Tacitus, Probus and Diocletianus (dated 289) seem to be intruders from the Reichenstein hoard (Schaub-Gysin 1930, p. 70).
Hoard of 1,000 silver coins: Trajan - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235). 8 coins are documented.
53 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Vespasian - Caracalla (Julia Domna ) (AD 211-217).
99 antoniniani (radiates): Elagabalus - Valerian I (AD 253-260).
270 coins found in a ceramic vessel: 70 antoniniani (radiates), 200 sestertii. 107 coins were examined: 16 antoniniani (radiates), 91 sestertii: Trajan - Marius (AD 269).
At least 50 denarii and antoniniani (radiates), but only 5 are identified: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
Possible hoard of 7 silver coins and 27 bronze coins. Late Republic - Philippus I (AD 247).
(c. 150) 118 silver coins: 108 denarii, 10 antoniniani (radiates): Marcus Aurelius - Gordian III (AD 243-244); silver weight: c.188.8-387.2 g.
242 antoniniani (radiates) found with a ceramic vessel: Elagabalus - Postumus (AD 260-269); silver weight: 67.7-626.9 g.

Hoard found in a bronze pot during the removal of a fence. It comprised more than 1,100 radiates, mainly from the Gallic Empire (Postumus, at least 763 coins). Bought by J. J. Wilhelm Bachofen-Burckhardt, Basel, but some coins dispersed in trade (ca. 100 coins). In 1925, his heirs sold 472 coins to the Swiss National Museum. Then, in 1941, they sold the container and the remaining coins to the Historisches Museum Basel.
The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 1,000 3rd century antoniniani (radiates), including an example of Gordian I or II.

On the 30.5.1862, approximately 4,000 billon coins and small radiates dating to the third century AD were found during marshland reclamation work. On 21.07.1862, an excavation of the site, recovered a further 3,000 coins of the same date. The coins were deposited in two piles 1.5m from each other at a depth of 0.95m. They were found in a layer of aquatic plant debris. Fillon lists the emperors represented as Volusian, Valerian, Gallienus, Salonina, Saloninus, Claudius II, Quintillus, Aurelian, Postumus, Laelian, Marius, Victorinus, Tetricus I and Tetricus II. There were no more than 100 coins dating to before the death of Postumus. According to Fillon, the radiates of Postumus without exception dated to the Ivth and Vth consulates. The coins of Tetricus made up 9/10ths of the hoard. There were about 10 coins of Aurelian (pre-reform) and for the most part were found in the second pile. Fillon's engravings indicate that there were also barbarous copies of coins of Divus Claudius, Victorinus and Tetricus. The hoard was found during drainage of marshland on the land of Mme de Craon-Beauveau.

475 silver coins: 1 Celtic drahm, 1 provincial drachm, 3 republican denarii, 470 imperial, found in the river near the former Postumius Bridge pillar. It was presumed that the coins may have been kept in a chest/box: Celtic - Gordian III (AD 240).
disposition: Musei Civici di Castelvecchio di Verona, Italy

summary: 200 coins were discovered. Among them coins of Philip I.
The hoard comprised two black ceramic vessels containing approximately 20,000 coins from Gallienus to Carinus (AD 283-285).
43 silver coins: Vitellius - Gordian III (AD 238-244); silver weight: 61.6-125.1 g.
The hoard comprised an unknown number of Roman coins of which 13 were kept and including issues of Trajan to Postumus.
10 antoniniani: Gordian III - Postumus (AD 2630-269); Silver weight: 3.7-11.5 g.
Between 1,500 and 3,000 coins found in a ceramic vessel. 185 coins seen: Julia Domna to Tetricus II Silver: c.1,500 coins; Silver weight: c.287.4-3897.6g.
Unknown initial number of coins found in a copper alloy vessel: Gordian III - Victorinus (AD 269-271).
The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 600 coins. They are described as being base silver coins from Caracalla to Gordian III. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of between 751.3g and 1558.7g
(c. 18 kg, 4,062) 1,590 silver coins denarii, antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253); silver weight: 5078.8-10559.8 g.
The hoard comprised 'more than 8,100 antoniniani (radiates), weighing approximately 30 kilos: Gordian III - Victorinus (AD 270-271).
disposition: Musée des Antiquités de Rouen (172 coins; Inv. II nos. 606 and 680), France

summary: Large hoard of mainly silver coins - denarii and antoniniani (radiates) - and some bronze coins. 242 coins are known: Titus - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 253-260).
The hoard comprised 16 sestertii from Hadrian to Philip I and 25 denarii and radiates from Caracalla to Valerian I (AD 253-260).

Hoard of 21 coins - 6 denarii and 15 counterfeits. Pit also contained broken samian & coarseware pottery and an iron hook, possibly a mount for a purse. Pit found during southern vicus excavs. S of River Tees, to W of the N-S road (Holme House 71-2).

This record has been created for the HER record of a hoard of 36 third century Roman coins found in the Waddon New Road, Croydon. The details of this find seem to differ from those associated with Robertson 2000, 235 no. 963: (apparently a fourth century hoard found in 1903) and the tetrarchic hoard of 34 coins found before 1914 associated with Robertson 2000, 251 no. 1047.Seaby's Coins and Medals Bulletin 1961, 234 reports 36 coins found in the Waddon New Road area during the excavation of a cutting between West Croydon and Pitlake in 1814 and in a private collection. Details are unfortunately vague: "All were Antoninianii and the range of dates encompassed only thirty years...Several rulers were represented and all coins with the exception of one originated from the same mint - Rome".
150 coins: 140 sestertii, 10 antoniniani (radiates): Vespasian - Trebonianus Gallus/Gallienus (AD 251-268). A silver patera and a lead weight were discovered together with these coins.
600 imperial and provincial bronzes found in a ceramic vessel during excavation work. Dr. Harlanov has examined 384 pieces: Antoninus Pius - Philip I (AD 244-249).

In 1951, 119 Roman bronze coins of Claudius II, Tetricus I and II were found under a heavy slab of stone while clearing wasteland. Almost all are imitations, possibly produced nearby as most are also mint fresh.

c. 1300 billon provincial coins of Alexandria: Vespasian - Gallienus (sole) (AD 260-261). 'Common terracotta vase buried in a fairly deep hole, dug out in the sandstone. Found during excavations for a monumental tomb in the Armenian cemetery.'
165 coins (163 denarii, 2 antoniniani (radiates), ranging from Domitian to Alexander Severus), found with 2 silver bracelets ca. 3 km east of the Römerstraße. The coins were destroyed during the war.
disposition: Staatliche Münzsammlung München (lost during WWII; one bracelet survived)

summary: 76 antoniniani (radiates): Gallienus - Tetricus I (AD 271-274); silver weight: 18.9-30.0g.
11 provincial bronzes issued in Rhesaena by Trajan Decius and his family, found in destruction deposits of Room 9J.

find_spot_name: SIRACUSA, EX VIGNA CASSIA, PRIMA TOMBA (GRUZZOLO A)
summary: Hoard in grave, 114 antoniniani (radiates): Gallienus (sole) - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
Only 303 antoniniani (radiates) are identified. The exact findspot is not known, but it is possible that it comes from Oudenburg, Gistel or Torhout: Gordian III - Postumus (AD 260-269).
Aurei found in a Germanic princess grave. Three of the coins, pierced, where part of a necklace: Hadrian, Antoninus Pius(2). One in the mouth: Gallienus. Rich funerary inventory.
disposition: Museum für Ur- und Frühgeschichte Thüringens, Weimar, Germany (inv. nos. 16-19)

summary: 6 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I - Victorinus (AD 269-271).
42 provincial bronze coins found in a ceramic vessel. 12 have been examined: Caracalla - Philip I (AD 244-249).
1,312 antoniniani (radiates) ending with coins of Tetricus I (AD 271-274); silver weight: 249.3g.
The hoard comprises 232 cast denarii: a rejected series of coins depicting emperors from Vespasian to Elagabalus with a tpq of AD 218-222 or soon after.
disposition: National Union Musem, Alba Iulia, Romania (Inv.no. 7438-7673)

summary: A hoard of 788 tetradrachms (Caracalla - Trebonianus Gallus), denarii (Julia Mamaea) and antoniniani (Caracalla - Gallienus) found during the excavations at Dura Europos, in a jar under the embankment beside the Palmyra Gate.
(247) 162 silver coins: 65 denarii, 97 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Postumus (AD 266-267).
disposition: Musée Curtius, Liège, Belgium (161 coins, 1 fragment of container)

summary: 21 bronze coins,found with two pebbles and a bronze ring in the fill of the outer fort ditch. Found concreted together and later separated, probably a purse hoard although no traces of a container survived.

In 1898 42 coins (1 denarius and 41 antoniniani, Macrinus - Postumus) coins came into view during peat digging on the field 'Am Schachen' in the area of Spesbach. The coins were concealed together in a clump, 70-80 cm below the surface. The coins were lost during WWII.
175 antoniniani entered museum collection in Kardzhali: Gordian III - Philip I (AD 244-249). No further information.
144 coins: 4 aurei, 140 antoniniani: Gordian III - Philip I; gold weight: 17.6 g; silver weight: 175.0 g. Together with a silver brooch.
Fifteen aurei were found during diggings at Vinukonda, in the old fort.

The hoard comprised about 50 kg antoniniani (radiates) of Valerian I, Gallienus, Salonina, Postumus, Laelian, Marius, Victorinus, Tetricus I, Tetricus II, Claudius II, Divo Claudio, Quintillus, Aurelian and Tacitus. 2,226 coins and one blank have been studied.
32 silver and provincial bronze coins: 5 antoniniani, 12 denarii, 15 provincial bronzes: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244); silver weight: 26.1-38 g.
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. no. CXXIX

summary: 74 (FMRO VI/1), around 60 bronze coins (Dembski 1977) were found in a Roman well. No certainty whether these coins belonged to a hoard or they were single finds as votive offerings. The coins minted segment: Tiberius - Numerian.
The hoard comprised a coarseware urn containing 1,806 radiates from Valerian I and Gallienus to Allectus.

The hoard was found in a sandstone or earthenware vessel hidden in a wall and covered by a large stone. It comprised 19 kg of corroded silver, billon and bronze coins, equating to approximately 3,600 coins. No certainty, that the latest coins belong to Postumus.
The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel holding approximately 300 'small bronzes' (radiates): Elagabalus - Postumus (AD 263).

The hoard comprised a copper-alloy vessel containing approximately 2,000 coins from Elagabalus to Postumus with a tpq of AD 263. Only 701 coins were catalogued. Note that for Gallienus, Valerian II, Saloninus, Salonina and Postumus, mints are given according to RIC (Lyon), not Elmer (Cologne).
13 aurei: Elagabalus - Severus Alexander and silver coins of Gordian III (AD 238-244).
The hoard comprised 3 Roman Provincial coins: Thessalonica (1 pseudo-autonomous, 1 Commodus, 1 Alexander Severus), found in a grave in the west cemetery of Thessalonica (area of Ramona).
The hoard was found mixed in with earth, without an obvious container. The excavators suggested an organic bag.
Group of 5 coins discovered in an ancient cellar: 4 double sestertii of Postumus, 1 imitation of antoninianus (radiate) of Victorinus (AD 269-271).
Unknown initial number of coins. 12 bronze coins were examined: 3 double sestertii, 8 sestertii, 1 as: Titus - Postumus (AD 264-265).
10 antoniniani: Gallienus - Probus (AD 276-282).
The hoard comprised 20 silver coins from Julia Domna, Julia Mamaea, Gordian III, Philip I, Trajan Decius, Herennia Etruscilla, Volusian, Valerian, Gallienus and Salonina.
196 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Valentinian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) (Salonina) (AD 253-268); silver weight: 245.0g.

Around 1860 a forest warden delivered, among other coins, 6 denarii that lay in rolls, stuck together in a bundle. 7 denarii, ranging from Septimius Severus to Caracalla, were listed among the single finds made in Dambach in 1901 and could be identical with the find made ca. 1860.

During the excavation of Roman fort at Reculver, a rectangular sunken room, poss. the strong room of the principia & sacellum, was excav., 23 ft 10 in. long & 20 ft wide. It had a thin skin floor of white mortar, covered in a deposit 6-12 in. deep of loam, mortar, painted wall plaster & domestic refuse, incl. pottery. It also produced frags. of 2 stone inscriptions from commemorative tablets, 6 iron arrowheads, & 21 coins of Antoninus Pius to Constantine II, with 14 from period AD 260-293. The rubble layer above contained mortaria, roof tile & box tile frags, & may represent collapsed roof, & this layer produced another 4 coins of Postumus of AD 268.Philp, B. 2005. The Excavation of the Roman Fort at Reculver, Kent. Kent Monographs 10. Kent Archaeol. Rescue Unit, pp. 44-45

A hoard of ca. 150 Roman bronze coins (Trajan - Septimius Severus), found in Winnefeld while planting trees. 133 coins were acquired by the museum in Hannover, 117 of which can still be traced. Several coins are badly preserved and identifications are tentative.
+100 coins dating from Philip I to Valerian and Gallienus. No catalogue was made and no further information given about the composition of the hoard.
50 silver coins. 15 pieces were seen: 5 antoniniani, 10 denarii; silver weight: 65.2-131.5 g.
301 antoniniani (radiates): Postumus - Probus (AD 276-282).

A hoard of four provincial coins (3 pseudo-autonomous coins of Thessalonica, with head of Tyche / ethnic - this series extends from Commodus to Philip?. The coin illustrated fig. 8-9 belongs to the latest issue; 1 Pella), found in the demolition layer of the courtyard (room ΣΤ), of a large urban Roman building.
28 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Valerian I (AD 258-259); silver weight: 35.0g.
(c. 250) 216 silver coins: Vespasian - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235), silver weight: 301.0-629.2 g.
disposition: Okrazen Istoriceski Muzej, Pleven, Bulgaria; 204 coins; inv. nos. 843 1-122

summary: Unknown number of imperial and provincial bronze coins. 36 pieces entered the museum collection in Shumen: Antoninus Pius - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Shumen, Bulgaria; inv. no. 13328/1-35 (35 coins)

summary: Unknown number of silver and provincial bronze coins. 100 silver coins were seen: Pertinax - Philip I (AD 244-249).

Roman coin hoard found in a pot during clay digging. 55 coins are preserved today with two further coins only known by their description, but the hoard might have comprised more coins. The coins range from Titus to Trajan Decius and were both bronze (48 sestertii and 1 dupondius) and silver (3 denarii and 5 antoniniani).
41 silver hoards: 2 denarii, 39 antoniniani (radiates): Elagabalus (Julia Maesa) - Gallienus (Salonina) (AD 260-268). The coins were found together in a small pit.
67 coins found in the ruins of an ancient building, on "Trajan's road": 66 silver, 1 bronze of Philip II of Macedon: Philip II of Macedon - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).

in 1852 on a hoard was dug out on a hill in a peat deposit of the Landstuhl municipality, on the island called Krimm. 11 silver coins (denarii and antoniniani, Geta - Philip) were published, but it remains unclear if this is the entire find or not.

5 kg of silver coins with issuers from Nero to Severus Alexander. Only 1,350 were recovered, among which: 233 Septimius Severus, 71 Caracalla, 5 Elagabalus, 5 Severus Alexander (AD 222-235); Silver weight: 1764.3-3938.9 g.
