Hoard of denarii and antoniniani (radiates), 7,206 coins: Septimius Severus - Postumus (AD 260-269). The largest number of coins belonging to Gordian III
A mixed hoard of circa 250 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) dating from Septimus Severus to Valerian I (AD 253-259).
Three Roman hoards found in Stonea. This hoard comprises 22 denarii ranging up to Severus Alexander.
32 bronze coins: Augustus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
698 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I and Gallienus - Gallienus (sole) (AD 260-268).
63 coins: 9 denarii, 54 antoniniani: Marcus Aurelius - Trajan Decius (AD 251). Found in the baths.
disposition: Regional History Museum, Kyustendil, Bulgaria; inv. no. 743-782

summary: A large hoard of silver coins was discovered by Bulgarian soldiers. 6 antoniniani entered the museum collection in Plovdiv: Gordian III 5, Trajan Decius 1.
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2735

summary: 77 antoniniani (radiates) of Tetricus I
236 coins: 6 denarii, 224 antoniniani (radiates), 6 sestertii: Trajan - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 259-260). Found together with jewellery: 1 gold ring, 1 glass ring, 1 bronze brooch.
This hoard is recorded at the level of the coin: Gordian III - Victorinus (AD 269-271); silver weight: 243.1-1909.4g.

The hoard was discovered during antiquarian exploration of a Gallo-Roman site. It appeared to have been originally stored in a cabinet measuring 6 feet square and comprised more than 300 base-silver coins. According to the finder, villagers who knew the findspot continued to find coins in abundance there. 300 silver coins: Severus Alexander - Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) (AD 253-268); silver weight: 76.1-710.8+g.
14 uncertain denominations: Republic - Philip I (AD 244-249).
Hoard of around 150 denarii: Vespasian - Severus Alexander (Julia Mamaea) (AD 222-235).
disposition: Statistical commission, Penza (in 1889); the high-school, Penza, Russia; old collection D. Ya. Samkvasov

summary: The hoard comprised more than 6000 radiates from Julia Domna to Postumus, the most numerous being of Gordian III, Philip I and Philip II. Found by a workman on the land of B. Flamand

A hoard of 1,702 denarii and antoniniani, ranging from Clodius Albinus to Trebonnianus Gallus, found in the surroundings of Düren approx. 15 years before 1930 when it was published. It is not sure that the 1,702 coins listed there encompass all the coins that were originally part of the hoard.
The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 150 sestertii and dupondii, asses or antoniniani (radiates) from Trajan to Probus (AD 276-282).
718 coins: 2 denarii, 2 quinarii, 667 antoniniani (radiates), 3 sestertii/double sestertii: Elagabalus - Postumus (AD 262-265); silver weight: 203.3-1735.5g.
1,100 antoniniani discovered in unknown circumstances. No further Information.
1200 denarii found in ceramic vessel. 156 pieces entered the museum collection in Svishtov: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
disposition: History Museum, Svishtov, Bulgaria; inv. nos. 1072-1142

summary: A depot of 8 antoniniani and 1 denarius (Septimius Severus - Claudius II) found in a pit on one of the rooms of the villa rustica at Oensingen

There is debate about whether 2-3000 coins were found (Lebarbier-Arnoux) or 5-6000 coins (Bottin). The librarian in Valenciennes, Hécart, saw about 500. An English officer, Drummond Hay, took a large portion of the hoard. Found with a ceramic vessel Severus Alexander - Postumus (AD 260-269).
12,093 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I - Aurelian/Tetricus I (AD 270-275), found during the building of the railway in an urn covered by a slate pate. Weight: circa 40 kg.
disposition: Coins given to the 'Kön. Münzkabinet'; Berlin (part: 167 coins acquired in 1879, acc. no. 1879/283)

summary: 200 gold staters of the Bosporan kings found on the banks of the Mortvyy Donets River: Eupator, Sauromates II, Rhescuporis III.
1,088 denarii and antoniniani were found in a copper vessel: Septimius Severus - Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) (AD 253-268).
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 9221-10309

summary: The hoard comprised a greyware vessel containing approximately 1,100 antoniani (radiates) from Valerian to Diocletian and Maximian I. Those of Saloninus, Salonina, Tacitus, Numerian, Carinus and Constantius I were quite numerous; those of Postumus, Victorinus, Tetricus I. Aurelian, Probus, Maximian I and Diocletian were quite abundant; those of Gallienus and Claudius II were the most numerous. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of between 131.1g and 1248.9g.
17,533 antoniniani (59 kg) found in a bronze vessel: Vespasian - Trajan Decius (Herennius Etruscus) (AD 249-251)
disposition: Regional History Museum Vidin, Bulgaria; inv. no. 932

summary: Unpublished hoard of three denarii in BM file report. Declared Treasure Trove in 1980.
194 Roman provincial bronze coins: Septimius Severus - Valerian and Gallienus/Gallienus (AD 253-268).
disposition: Museum of anamur, Turkey (coins); Cabinet des Médailles de la Bibliothèque Nationale de France, Paris, France (moulds)

summary: (53) 50 provincial bronze coins: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
(746) 668 denarii and antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253)
300 silver and billon coins: 1 Augustus, 1 Vespasian, ending with Valerian I (AD 253-260).
Hoard of circa 100 coins. Only two pieces are known: Claudius I sestertius, Caracalla provincial bronze minted in Serdica.
3,501 antoniniani: Gordian III - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
The hoard comprised approximately 1,400 radiates from Gallienus to Tacitus Hobbs estimates a silver weight of between 337g and 1084g.

1610 antoniniani and fragments of a ceramic vessel with lid: Gallienus - Probus (AD 276-282). The coins were minted in Siscia, Sirmium, Serdica and other mints. The majority of the coins belong to Gallienus and Claudius II. Due to poor condition of reservation 157 coins could not be identified; silver weight: 244.1-1686.4 g.
disposition: Regional History Museum, Kyustendil, Bulgaria; inv. nos. 2731-4172, 4319-4414; 1,538 coins

summary: 39 antoniniani (radiates): Gallienus - Tetricus I (AD 271-274). Most likely it is part of the hoard PLOURHAN 1881 (Plourhan II).
disposition: Collection P. du Chatellier; Musée de Bretagne, Rennes, France (inv.no. MAN 80316, 39 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing '30 silver and bronze coins, including 1 of Nero. It is possible that this hoard is the same as the hoard of large and medium bronzes of Domitian, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius, Commodus and Gordian III which were examined by Deville.

A hoard of 15,000 - 20,000 coins, found ploughing a field at Riby Wold Farm on the east side of Lincolnshire Wolds, some 4-5 miles north-east of Caistor. The coins are all antoniniani, ranging from Gordian III to Probus, AD 281. Included were many coins of Gallienus, and of emperors from the Gallic Empire.
disposition: Lincoln City and County Museum (part: pot and 24 coins); Ashmoleum Museum (part)

summary: The hoard comprised 100 coins 'une centaine'. Gricourt only saw three coins from the find. They were antoniniani (radiates) of Gordian III, Philip and Herennia Etruscilla. A pharmacist from Somain discovered the hoard which was immediately dispersed.
2000 silver coins found during road repairing works: Trajan - Philip I (AD 244-249).
12 provincial coins ranging from Commodus to Philip (Dium, Thessalonica, Koinon of Macedononia) found in grave 8 in Methone.
1,325 antoniniani (radiates): Philip I - Probus (AD 276-282); silver weight: 239.6-1,655.3g.
55 antoniniani (radiates): Pupienus - Valerian I (AD 253-260); silver weight: 69.9-128.8 g.

A ceramic vessel with 1,032 Roman provincial bronze coins minted in Marcianopolis, Nicopolis ad Istrum, Callatis, Odessus, Anchialus, Augusta Traiana, Hadrianopolis, Philippopolis and Creteia-Flaviopolis: Marcus Aurelius - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: History Museum, Targovishte, Bulgaria; inv.no. 201 (894 coins)

summary: The hoard was found in a coarseware vessel which was broken. It comprised a block of Roman silver and bronze coins which had been stuck together with corrosion products. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of 249.6-505.0 g.
Over 191 antoniniani (radiates) found in a ceramic vessel: 1 Aurelian, 190 Probus (AD 276-282).
118 coins : 114 bronzes and 4 denarii (1 nummus of Constantin intrusive)
192 denarii and antoniniani (radiates): Republic 1, Vespasian – Philip I (AD 244-249).

A hoard of 387 silver coins, including a large quantity of posthumous Philip Philadelphus (121, year 19 to 32, i.e. 31-18 BC), Roman denarii (141, up to AD 207), Syrian tetradrachms (29), Arabian didrachms (Trajan, 3 coins), as well as Parthian drachms (92 up to Artabanus IV, 213-227). The later coins of Severus and the members of his family are in mint state. Found in the Nineveh excavations in the 1929-30 season.
disposition: British Museum (154 coins); the Birmingham City Art Gallery (17 coins); Sir Charles Hyde (25 coins); Bagdad museum (196)

summary: A hoard of ca. 800 silver and 20 bronze coins, found in a pot while ploughing a field (at Hermendonk?, not far from Wachtendonk). The coins are not preserved, but a list of emperors exists.
circa 150 denarii, 30 preserved. Nero-Seveus Alexander (AD 227). 1 nummus of Constantius II is an intruder.

The hoard was found inside a coarse-ware vessel, of a blackish colour. The coins were within a compacted, ferruginous mass and comprised 47 antoniniani (radiates) from Elagabalus to Valerian I and Gallienus with a tpq of AD 259.
During the construction of a spinning factory in 1852 a hoard consisting of gold and silver coins, ranging from Nero to Severus Alexander, was unearthed. Only 27 specimens were documented.
Hoard of 66 bronze staters of the Bosporan king, Rhescuporis V (AD 242-267).
Antoniniani (radiates): Gallienus - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
(+1000) 92 antoniniani: Gordian - Valerian I (AD 253-259
disposition: Archaeological Museum Zagreb, Croatia (63 coins); dispersed -1981

summary: The hoard (8 denarii and antoniniani, Elagabalus - Philip I) was found at the bottom of a container during construction work at Heilbronn street.

The hoard comprised a red ceramic vessel containing between 1,000 and 1,200 antoniniani (radiates) and one denarius. Pilloy saw approximately 300 of these coins and commented that 5/6ths were of Gallienus (particularly his zoo issue) and of Claudius II or Divus Claudius II. The remainder were of Salonina, Quintillus, Victorinus, Aurelian, Severina and Numerian, with the last three authorities represented by one coin each.
The hoard comprised a coarseware vessel containing more than 600 denarii from Augustus to Elagabalus (AD 218-222).
HER record of a second scattered hoard of radiates of Tetricus I and II from within site LKH 003 found c. 1978. No further information, many thought to be unreported.

At least three aes coins (Domitian and Gallienus), along with numerous other finds, including a tombstone, mortarium, glassware, fibulae, and studs, discovered while digging the foundations of the new gaol (now HMP Usk) on the field known as 'Cae Puta'. The two radiates of Gallienus might constitute a hoard, but the addition of the single aes of Domitian throws this into doubt. In lieu of more accurate information concerning their context, it is just as likely that all three are single finds instead of a hoard. Nash-Williams (1928) speculated that the site might have been the location of a fort.

Originally were 500 coins found with a ceramic vessel. 120 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) from Clodius Albinus to Valerian I and Gallienus. Until AD 253, Mints represented: Rome, except 2 from Laodicea for Septimius Severus and Geta; 2 from Antioch for Elagabalus and Philip I; 2 from Viminiacum for Treboninanus Gallus and 2 from Milan for 'les divi'; after AD 253: 1 Rome, 9 Cologne, 1 Viminiacum, 1 Milan, 1 2nd eastern Mint and 1 uncertain. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of 698.4-1425.8g

Two radiate minimi (8 and 7 mm, 0.40 and 0.34 g., one with head to left, and one from dies too big for the flan), found with 'about seven others' and a coin of Victorinus (Elmer 743, slightly worn) were discovered on the 13th tee of Pyle and Kenfig golf-course, before 1955. There were also some fragments of pottery.
disposition: National Museum of Wales (part); Grosvernor Museum (part)

summary: 10 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I - Claudius II (AD 268-270); silver weight: 3.7-11.5g.

The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing between 4,000 and 5,000 radiates, some of which were issues of Gallienus' The hoard was found under a tree, not far from the route to Grosley, in the Château-Simon woodland, close to Gouttières
The hoard comprised 59 antoniniani (radiates) from Philip I to Aurelian or Tetricus I and was perhaps incomplete.

The hoard derives from the collection of the musician Simon Antoni, which was acquired by the Kreuznach museum in 1888, with an inventory of 1488 Roman coins. Of these, some coins were found 'am Lemberg', probably between 1830 and 1860. FMRD lists 102 antoniniani, ranging from Valerian (for Saloninus) to Tetricus.

230 antoniniani (radiates) were originally described and were thought to represent approximately 1/3rd of the hoard; however, Hiernard increased the number to 230 and argued that this portion was part of a hoard of approximately 1000 coins. Sagredo San Eustaquio gives the number of coins as 231. The latest coin in the hoard is also the subject of some discussion. Originally a coin of Postumus (AD 260 to 268) with a HERCVLI DEVSONENSI reverse was stated to be the last coin. However, with Hiernard's revisions, 3 radiates of Salonina dating to the period AD 263 to 264 were stated to be the last. Furthermore, Balil basing his observations on Mateu y Llopis, gives the latest coins in the hoard as an issue of Gallienus (RIC 280) and one of Salonina (RIC 5).
The hoard was placed next to the skull of a skeleton in an inhumation grave and comprised 33 small bronzes antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
The hoard comprised 381 radiates from Valerian I and Gallienus to Probus and was found under a complete Roman tile. The coins were acquired by the City Library of Bourg.
Few hundreds of provincial bronze coins. 92 entered the museum collection in Sofia: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. nos. 26923-27020 (92 coins)

summary: Around 700 antoniniani (radiates) found at the foot of the mountain by the mouth of the "Beschterbach" river.
18 provincial bronze coins entered the museum collection in Shumen: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Shumen, Bulgaria; inv. no. 13869/1-18 (17 coins)

summary: 56 denarii: Mark Antony - Caracalla (AD 214); silver weight: 87.8-167.0g.
disposition: Voralberg Museum, Bregenz, (initial 51 coins, in 1977 46); Private collection, Innsbruck (1 coin), Austria

summary: 67 denarii found with ceramic vessel: Antoninus Pius - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235); silver weight: 95.2-182.9 g.
24 provincial bronze coins: Caracalla - Maximinus I Thrax (AD 235-238).
disposition: Muzeul de Istorie Națională și Arheologie, Constanța, Romania; inv.nos. 67360-67382

summary: 1889 antoniniani, 43 imitations, 6 forgeries and some fragments: Elagabalus - Probus (AD 276-282).
The hoard comprised 1 denarius of Elagabalus and 15 antoniniani (radiates) from Gordian III to Postumus. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of 7.3 to 19.6 g.
122 antoniniani (radiates)found with a purse and in a wooden casket together with other objects: Caracalla - Valerian I (AD 253-260).

The hoard comprised an unknown number of Roman coins, which was divided in two by the finder. One part was melted down and used to make buttons, chains and a watch. The other part included 3 sestertii and 5 radiates from Trajan to Trajan Decius. It is possible that this hoard is part of one known as Lusigny A.

The hoard comprised a greyware vessel sealed with a wooden plug, containing approximately 820 Roman silver and billon coins, of which 811 were identified. They range from a denarius of Antoninus Pius to a radiate of Probus. They were accompanied by two silver finger rings in a textile wrapping.
142 bronze coins (sestertii, antoniniani?): Trajan - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 253-260); silver weight: 27.9-59.7g.
4 antoniniani: 3 Gallienus (sole), 1 Claudius II (AD 268-270).
11 silver coins: 1 denarius, 10 antoniniani: Caracalla - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
disposition: Regional History Museum Vidin, Bulgaria; inv. no. 605 (11 coins)

summary: Unknown initial number of antoniniani. 8 pieces entered the museum collection in Sofia: Gordian III 1, Philip I 1, Otacilia Severa 1, Trajan Decius 5.
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 21422-21429 (8 coins)

summary: (c. 200 silver, 2 gold coins) 31 gold and silver coins: 1 aureus, 18 denarii and 19 antoniniani/radiates: Vespasian - Valerian and Gallienus I (AD 258); silver weight: 40.6-67g
disposition: the Prince of Schaumburg-Lippe collection; Town Museum Virovitica, Croatia (173 coins); dispersed; Archaeological Museum Zagreb, Croatia (archives)

summary: 37 silver coins: 12 denarii, 25 antoniniani: Antoninus Pius - Valerian I (AD 257).
disposition: Museum of Lovech, department of Archaeology, Bulgaria; inv.no. 1477

summary: Unknown number of silver coins. Three of them are kept in the Museum of Cultural History Stralsund: Antoninus Pius denarius, Philip I antoniniani (radiates) (AD 248).
disposition: Museum of Cultural History Stralsund, Germany (3 coins)

summary: Unknown originally number of denarii found with a ceramic vessel. 47 coins were documented: Vespasian - Elagabalus (Julia Soaemias) (AD 218-222).

4 coins: 1 denarius, 2 plated coins, 1 bronze coin: Tiberius - Gordian III (AD 238-244); silver weight: 6.1-7.4 g. Found together with silver inscribed objects (patera, 2 rings), 2 statuettes, 3 hair-pins.
disposition: Musée d'Art et d'Histoire de Genève, Switzerland

summary: Found during construction work. The subsequent excavations provided no information on any archaeological context. The findspot is situated in the slope above the vicus of Muralto. Hoard/deposition of 4869 aes coins: 1 as, 1 dupondius and 4867 sestertii, in an amphora, Claudius I to Gallienus (253/254).
91 provincial bronze coins: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: History Museum, Razgrad, Bulgaria; inv.no. IF, hoard 18

summary: Forty-sevenound with a ceramic vessel. 45 coins provide information on issuers: Vespasian - Caracalla (Julia Domna) (AD 211-217).
The hoard comprised 'a large number of bronze coins, apparently in gold or silver. Fourteen were identified as issues of Aurelian.
(150) 109 coins: 18 denarii, 19 antoniniani, 2 sestertii, 70 provincial bronze coins: Antoninus Pius - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); silver weight: 42.3-83.4 g.
disposition: History Museum, Kazanlak, Bulgaria (20 coins); Regional History Museum, Shumen, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 1566-1672 (106 coins)

summary: Found during excavations, in the Mithraeum, sector NW, niveau de fréquentation (found in 1994, 69 coins) and above in the demolition layer (found in 1993, 4 coins). Hoard, most probably packed in a container of perishable material, no traces found; 73 aes coins, Nero (?) to Philip I, mostly sestertii with a few dupondii and asses.
disposition: Service des bâtiments, monuments et archéologie, Martigny/Sion

summary: Over 120 silver coins. Among issuers: Gordian III, Philip I (Marcia Otacilia, Philip II), Trajan Decius and Trajan Decius (Herennia Etruscilla). Three coins were bought by the Coin Room of the National History Museum in Bucharest.
disposition: National History Museum, Bucharest, Romania (3 coins)

summary: 2,634 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I - Carus (AD 283).
Hoard of 191 coins: 190 antoniniani (radiates) and 1 Roman provincial coin (Ephesus) found as a pile on the caldarium's floor: Valerian I - Aurelian (AD 272).
Unknown originally number of coins found with a ceramic vessel in a layer of fire. 28 denarii survived: Marcus Aurelius (Divus Antoninus Pius) - Gordian III (AD 241-243; silver weight: 44.4-85.4 g.

The hoard comprised a ceramic jar containing 37 bronze and silver coins dated between 146-139 BC and AD 193-211. The hoard was found in association with the remains of an ancient building, but this was destroyed during construction work.
c. 4000 (2244) antoniniani (radiates): Aurelian - Probus (AD 276-282); silver weight: 720.1-1079.9g.
237 silver denarii and antoniniani: Hadrian - Philip I (AD 244-249); silver weight: 297.8-690.4 g.
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv.no. 1881

summary: Ca. 100 antoniniani (Gallienus to Tetricus II) found in a pot behind the wall of a Roman house, close to the Schloßplatz. 65 have been described in FMRD, the others are lost.
Unknown number of silver coins. 31 pieces were noticed: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
A purse of 14 provincial coins from Athens (period VB, VC and VI), found on the floor of the south house, on the northern slope of the Hill of the Nymphs.
341 denarii (86 information lost) found before 2000; 31 denarii found in 2013. Hadrian - Septimius Severus (AD 201).
disposition: Historisch Museum Deventer; De Nederlandsche Bank (Dutch National Central Bank)

summary: 16 provincial bronze coins minted in Bizya: Geta 1, 15 Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria (11 coins)

summary: Details from HER: 2 coins: 1 of Claudius II Gothicus (AD 268-270), Providentia type; & a local copy (c. AD 270) of Pax Aug type of Tetricus II, with radiate head on obverse.Present location unknown.YAJ 1975, 46: 4.
A hoard of 300-400 antoniniani (radiates). 336 coins were examined by Salama at the home of a dealer in Tunis on 6.5.1965: Gordian III - Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) (AD 253-268).
(c. 300) 49 antoniniani: Elagabalus - Valerian I (AD 258-259); silver weight of 63.8 - 128.7 g.
108 denarii and antoniniani: Vespasian - Gordian III (AD 241-243).
10 coins (denarius, as, dupondius) from Republic to Elagabalus (AD 218-222).
The hoard was found between "Place de la Crémaillère" and "Rue de la Charité", on the Est of "Hôpital de la Charité", in a bronze pitcher. It comprised c. 1300 coins.
(303) 292 silver coins: 240 denarii, 52 antoniniani (radiates): Vespasian - Philip I (AD 247-249); silver weight: 380.4-892.2 g.
c. 200 Alexandrian tetradrachms. 'Probably a whole hoard, offered for sale in Belgium.'
363 silver coins which were first placed in a bag and then in a ceramic vessel: Marcus Aurelius - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2205

summary: (5-6 kg) 2,000 coins. Identified 341 silver coins: 1 denarius, 340 antoniniani (radiates): Severus Alexander - Valerian I (AD 259); silver weight: 2,500.2 - 4,759.1 g+.
disposition: Archeological Museum Zagreb (?980 coins); P. Broz collection Zagreb (83 coins), Croatia; dispersed - 1981

summary: The hoard, found with a bronze vessel, comprised approximately 1,200 radiates from Claudius II to Diocletian (AD 287-288); silver weight: 133.5-237.1 g.

Scattered hoard, found in the Dünnern river bed during correction works of the river bed. Over 1100 coins reported, 906 of them preserved. 8 coins from the 1st/2nd c. AD, the others range from Septimius Severus to Aurelian and Postumus to Tetricus II. Mostly antoniniani, except for the 1st/2nd c. coins and a denarius of Gordian III. Large numbers of coins from Gallienus and Claudius II.
51 antoniniani (radiates) of Tetricus I and II (AD 271-274).
The hoard was found placed on a masonry slab and comprised a sestertius of Hadrian and 21 double sestertii of Postumus, including 4 imitations.
44 coins found in a grave in Lefkohori, Langada in 1970. The coins included one denarius (Marcus Aurelius) and 43 provincial coins (Thessalonica, Edessa, Dium, Pella, Stobi, koinon of Macedonia).
(+200) 126 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Postumus (AD 260-268); silver weight: 38.8-156.5 g.
Unknown quantity of provincial bronze coins. 2 pieces of Caracalla minted in Serdica are known
(55) 17 silver coins: 9 denarii, 8 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); silver weight: 21.6-34.1 g.
In a ceramic vessel were found antoniniani from Gordian III to Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253). 1,153 coins are kept in the History Museum in Lom. 886 antoniniani belong to Volusian.
disposition: History Museum, Lom Bulgaria; inv.no. 2470 (1153 coins)

summary: Mints are quantified but not allocated to issues. 28 Cologne, 15 Rome, 3 Milan: Gordian III - Victorinus (AD 269-271).

A third century hoard of 99 antoniniani (radiates) interpreted as a savings hoard. Found during development control excavation in advance of building new housing estate: Gordian - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 258-259).
Hoard of 32 coins found with ceramic vessel: 21 denarii, 11 sestertii: Trajan - Severus alexander (AD 222-235).
c. 60 antoniniani (radiates) of Gordian III and Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Collection Vanden Berghe, Hal, Belgium, in 1898

summary: Hoard of 223 coins: 6 aurei, 217 denarii and antoniniani (radiates): Severus Alexander - Postumus (AD 260-269); gold weight: 27.1-30.0g.; silver weight: 59.8-315.7g. Together was found a ring (metal not specified).
The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 1,109 coins. They include 1,108 radiates from Valerian to Tetricus and 1 denarius copy of Elagabalus.
Unknown number of provincial bronze coins. 36 pieces entered the museum collection in Shumen: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Shumen, Bulgaria; inv. no. 12359/1-36 (36 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised an amphora containing more than 33 kilos of coins, estimated as representing more than 8,000 examples. Vallier examined 'a suitcase full' of coins which included issues of Gallienus, Claudius II (rare), Aurelian, Severina, Tacitus, Florian, Probus and Numerian. It appears that there were also some earlier coins dating to the first or second centuries AD but the information is vague.
The hoard comprised 1,500 Roman coins from Vespasian to Philip I (AD 244-249).
The original total number of coins in the hoard is not known, although 14 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I and Gallienus - Postumus (AD 260-269).

The hoard comprised an enormous pot containing a very large quantity of Gallo-Roman coins. Although some of the coins were stolen soon after their discovery, the number of coins found totaled more than 2,000. Only 85 of these were described. After its discovery, the pot was left in the middle of the field overnight and some coins from the hoard went missing then: Valerian I - Tetricus I (AD 271-274); silver weight: 541.0-2499.1g.
The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 1,759 antoniniani (radiates) from Gordian III to Victorinus. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of 404.6g.
5,056 silver coins found in one or more ceramic vessels: 17 denarii, 5,039 antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus (Geta) - Tetricus I (AD 271-274); silver weight: 966.5g.
Unknown initial number of silver coins. 260 coins: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 2449-251)
A hoard of 402 silver coins: 31 tetradrachms (Marcus Aurelius - Macrinus), 370 denarii (Nero - Caracalla) and one tridrachm (Trajan) found in two jars at Dura Europos.
7 coins: Nerva – Elagabalus (AD 218-222).
disposition: Regional museum, Kolín, Czech Republic (6 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised 400 silver coins to Gordian III or Gallienus with a tpq of AD 244/268.
The hoard comprised a whiteware ceramic jug contained approximately 2,000 coins of Postumus.
191 billon tetradrachms of Alexandria: Aurelian (AD 274-275) found in a pile at floor level in room during excavations of a house. 1 bronze coin of the Ptolemy V may be regarded as a intruder?
The central site of Sorte Muld at Bornholm has produced a large number of coins, of which 292 are interpreted as belonging to one original deposition.
Around 1,200 antoniniani (radiates) found with amphoras on a shipwreck. 229 coins were studied: Gallienus (sole) - Maximian I (AD 284-293).

51 radiates (Volusian to Victorinus) found in the course of excavations at the Cambria House site on the civil settlement outside the legionary fortress at the NW corner. The coins were in the filling of a drain, but it is not clear whether they represent a deliberate deposit or an accidental loss.

The hoard comprised both coins and other objects, including numerous items of personal adornment in precious metals as well as tableware and other vessels. One of the vessels contained approximately 395 denarii and radiates from Septimius Severus to Saloninus (and Valerian II?) while in the hoard as a whole, there were approximately 1080 bronze coins, nearly all sestertii, but with the exception of 12 dupondii and asses. The bronze coins range in date from Domitian (1 example) through to Trajan Decius. Testenoire-Lafayette noted that issues of Gordian III were particularly prominent in the hoard, that Severus Alexander was also well-represented and that issues of Gallienus and his family made up a large proportion of the radiates in the hoard. The hoard was found when the landowner, M. Charles demolished well-built foundations in his field which were hindering cultivation. Silver: c.395 coins;
disposition: Societé de la Diana, Montbrison, France

summary: Group of 38 bronze coins: 28 sestertii, 3 dupondii, 7 asses: Nero - Postumus (AD 260-268).
The hoard was discovered in a burial and comprised 38 radiates from Gallienus to Tetricus II. An as of Augustus was also recovered which may be intrusive.
The hoard comprised 35 bronze coins: 2 dupondii of Nero, 1 sestertius of Antoninus Pius and 32 bronzes of Postumus - 'all sizes'.

Three Roman hoards found in Stonea. This hoard comprises 37 denarii ranging up to Gordian III and was found with Iron Age coins seen as a separate group (Stonea Grange I group I). Part of the group was detected from site prior to excavation.
Unknown quantity of coins found in a ceramic vessel. 6 pieces entered the museum collection in Pazardzik: Julia Paula, Gordian III, Otacilia severa; silver weight: 8.1-13.5 g.
disposition: Regional History Museum, Pazardzik, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 441-445

summary: 205 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I and Gallienus - Probus (AD 276-282).
7 antoniniani (radiates) of Aurelian found in a grave with a skeleton (AD 270-275).
An unknown quantity of coins was found in the outskirts of an ancient settlement. 31 silver coins were examined: 13 antoniniani, 18 denarii: Hadrian - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2579

summary: Around 700 denarii found with a ceramic vessel. For only two coins are known the issuers: Domitian and Septimius Severus. The archives mention that the coins were minted between years 81 and 222.

The hoard comprised a black ceramic jug containing 8,500 coins (22kg). A list of types that would interest collectors was produced. Fillon notes that coins of Gallienus, Victorinus, Tetricus I and Claudius II made up the majority of the hoard and that were about 20 coins of Aurelian. There was a radiate of Victorinus with a IOVI CONSERVATORI reverse copying an issue of Aurelian in that it reproduced the officina mark P for Milan. The hoard was found by a farmer in his field. The vessel was kept in the Collection de Rouchebrune. Fillon bought the coins for the Soc. Antiq. Ouest.

A small bronze cauldron containing a linen bag with the coins. The money consists of 889 antoniniani (radiates) from Elagabalus to Valerian I and Gallienus. Two pieces of silver-plated crockery, a plate and a platter, were found next to the cauldron.
7 antoniniani (radiates) of Postumus (AD 260-269).
Circa 50 coins of silver and bronze. Only 36 were bought by the Museo Civico di Storia e Arte di Trieste: Vespasian - Maximinus I Thrax (AD 235-238).
disposition: Museo Civico di Storia e Arte di Trieste, Italy. Mixed with the rest of the coins in the museum collection

summary: The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 100 'base silver denarii' [probably radiates]. The majority of the coins date to the period of Gordian and the Philips. According to TAF, it is possible that the closing date for the hoard is much later - Valerian I or Postumus?
3089 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Valerian I (AD 257-258).
2,000 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Augustus - Severus alexander (AD 222-235).
disposition: Dispersend among locals, and buyers from Novara and Torino.

summary: 14 bronze coins, ranging from Caracalla to Philip, found in a clay vessel in the destruction layer of a building in the north section of the Agora. More than 100 bronze (provincial, judging from those ill. in fig. 4 in AEMTh 18, 2004, p. 382) coins were also found in the same layer.
Two aurei found in a lead sarcophagus: Trajan Decius, Tacitus (AD 275-276).
(+200) sestertii: Septimius Severus 2, Severus Alexander 12: Nerva - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235)
700 radiates The hoard was bought by H. Rigaux, but doesn't appear to have gone to Lille Museum with the rest of his collection.
Unknown quantity of coins. 3,693 antoniniani entered the museum collection in Plovdiv. No further information.
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv. no. 2644; 3,693 coins

summary: The hoard was found in a black ceramic vessel placed within a pit lined with four tiles. It comprised approximately 4,000 antoniniani (radiates) from Gordian III to Tetricus I and II. Issues of Gallienus and Claudius II were the most numerous. A small portion of the hoard including 103 coins were catalogued.
4 antoniniani (Gordian III - Trajan Decius) found during field work.

3rd century. Roman fort at Watercrook S of Kendal was excav by Potter in 1975-5. In square stone guard chamber to NE gate of fort, one charcoal rich layer sandwiched in between two occupation layers/phases of use contained a 'large quantitity of objects' incl. pottery, bronze finger ring, arrowhead, calthrops, iron lock & building fittings, a surgical probe, & 4 coins close together. These dated to post-AD 268-273, & were of Claudius II, radiate copies of Victorinus, & Tetricus I. T.W. 1979. Romans in North-west England. Excavations at the Roman Forts of Ravenglass, Watercrook, and Bowness-on-Solway, pp. 158-160, figs. 60-61.
3 denarii and 31 antoniniani (radiates), but this is not certain. Septimius Severus - Valerian I (AD 253-260).
The hoard comprised c. 700 coins including 200 sestertii and 500 antoniniani (radiates) from Septimius Severus to Claudius II.
The hoard comprised 287 denarii: 93 republican, 194 imperial: Republic - Caracalla (AD 215).
disposition: Cabinet des médailles, Paris, France; collection Favre

summary: 92 silver coins: 91 denari, 1 antoninian (radiate): Hadrian - Severus Alexander (AD 230).
disposition: Museo Archeologico Nazionale, Monetiere di Firenze, Italy (inv.no. 78377-78458)

summary: Unknown initial number of coins. 34 antoniniani: Gordian III -Valerian I (AD 259-260); silver weight: 42.5 g+
Unknown number of silver coins found in a ceramic vessel. 102 coins entered the museum collection in Kazanlak: 1 denarius, 101 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
9042 silver coins: denarii, antoniniani (radiates): Caracalla - Valerian I (AD: 257-259); silver weight: 11297.5 g. Approx. 300 unidentified badly preserved coins.
113 coins: Claudius I - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251). No information on the denominations or other issuers.
107 silver coins: Antoninus Pius - Maximinus I Thrax (AD 235-238). No details on denominations.
The hoard comprised two small urns containing more than 1,000 poorly preserved radiates from Valerian I and Gallienus to Probus (AD 276-282).

(+485) 472 silver coins: 106 denarii, 366 Septimius Severus - Gallienus with a tpq of AD 257/258. The coins were minted at Antioch (5 coins), Milan, Rome and Viminacium but data concerning the number of coins from each mint was not recorded. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of 598g to 1241.7g. The coins were accompanied by eight pieces of jewellery: a tubulus, part of a chain; a conical tubulus, part of a chain; the fragment of a bracelet; a fragment of a bracelet; three parts of the coil of a bracelet; a piece of semi-circular sheet-metal, part of a chain.
The hoard comprised 2,118 antoniniani (radiates) from Valerian I to Aurelian with a tpq of AD 270 to 275.
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles du Musée d'Histoire et d'Art, Luxembourg; inv.no. 1991-214/1 - jug; 2:1 - 2120

summary: 1 multiple of 3 aurei Carinus for Magnia Urbica; 1 silver medallion Valerian I and Gallienus for Valerian II (Caesar).
The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing one silver coin and an unknown number of copper-alloy coins of Marcus Aurelius, Commodus and Julia Mamaea.
191 coins, range: Hadrianus -Trebonianus Gallus. Almost all of them sestertii, some halved.
10 silver coins: 9 denarii, 1 antoniniani(radiate) (AD 251-253).

In 1911 a container with Roman coins was found by Italian workers during excavation works for the Welzheim railway station. The precise find location could not be determined. The hoard was dispersed, but 277 coins reached the Stuttgart Museum, and 379 coins in a private collection were also documented. In total, 670 coins are listed in FMRD. Coins range from the Late Republic to Severus Alexander. They are mostly denarii, with a few antoniniani and 4 aurei.
disposition: Local museum, Welzheim, Germany; private collection

summary: The coins (44 denarii, Vespasian - Severus Alexander) were discovered during excavation in room D of building I of a mansio close to Sigmaringen.
26 antoniniani (radiates) found with traces of textile recipient: Aurelian - Carinus (AD 283-285).
disposition: Laboratory of Restoration of Soprintendenza Speciale per i Beni Archeologici di Roma (inv. nos. 508899-508924)

summary: 381 antoniniani (radiates): Elagabalus - Postumus (AD 260-269).
5 bronze coins found in room 42 of the 'Gordian's Palace': Antoninus Pius 1 sestertius, Faustina II 1 sestertius, 1 as/dupondius, Gordian III 2 sestertii.
The hoard comprised a whiteware jug containing between 800 and 900 coins (or 2,000 according to De Closmadeuc): Philip I - Tacitus (Ad 275-276).
disposition: Musée départemental d'archéologie , Nantes, France (900 coins and sherds from the vessel)

summary: The hoard comprised 'a lot of bronze and billon coins, of which 83 coins were recovered and give by M. Timbaud to the Musée de Rouen…'it is likely to represent a hoard or a portion of a hoard'; Antoninian dynasty - ; silver weight: 17.6-151.6g.
disposition: Musée des Antiquités de Rouen, France. Museum Inventory III, p. 61, no. 2157 (donated 17.5.1909)

summary: 73 provincial bronze coins: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Veliko Tarnovo, Bulgaria; inv. nos.1538-1610 (73 coins, 69 have been stolen)

summary: 46 imitations of antoniniani (radiates) of the Tetricus I and II (AD 271-274)and unidentified onject (button?).

Hoard of 460 coins: 446 antoniniani (radiates) from Elagabalus to Gallienus, 11 denarii from Caracalla to Gordian III and 3 Provincial bronzes (Septimius Severus of Hadrianoi and Gordian III of Metropolis).
disposition: National Museum, Athens, Greece (124 coins and the list of the entire hoard)

summary: The hoard comprised a glass bottle containining more than 146 denarii from Nero to Elagabalus. The glass bottle, which acted as the container for the hoard, is preserved by the Musée de Mans (Inv. V. 62)
The hoard comprised approximately 1,200 radiates of 'the epoque of Postumus and some contemporary official and ursurper emperors.'

The hoard was found in 1906 after a farmer discovered some coins of Postumus, Victorinus, Tetricus and Claudius II at the same findspot where two years previously 100 antoniniani (radiates) of Gallienus, Claudius II, Victorinus and Tetricus I and II had been found. As a result, Vigneron-Jousselandière excavated the findspot, discovering 7 silver ligula and a ceramic vessel containing approximately 3,500 antoniniani (radiates). At the middle of the vessel was a radiate of Philip I, 39 worn denarii, 1 aureus of Postumus and a gold finger ring. The ligulae or spoons, the finger ring, the denarii, the aureus of Postumus and 450 radiates were acquired by the Musée départemental d'archéologie. Vigneron-Jousselandière possessed 2,651 radiates (in 1907).
Unknown number of denarii and antoniniani were found in unknown circumstances. 18 pieces are kept in the museum collection in Ruse: Septimius Severus - Claudius II (AD 268-270).
The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 2,507 antoniniani (radiates) from Valerian I to Aurelian (AD 270-275); weight: 6,100 kg.
131 silver coins: 19 antoniniani, 112 denarii found with an urn: Antoninus - Gordian III (AD 242-244). Some scholars also mention gold coins.
disposition: Münzkabinett Kunsthistorisches Museum, Wien (6 coins); Landemuseum Joanneum, Graz (72 coins); Institut für Alte Geschichte, Universität Graz

summary: 128 provincial bronze coins: Antoninus Pius - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Veliko Tarnovo, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 1022-1141

summary: The hoard comprised 773 aurei - 18 coins were already missing in 1874 - from Claudius I to Septimius Severus (Geta Caesar) with a tpq of AD 205-207 and was found in association with a staircase, presumably part of a Roman building or cellar. There are at least 3 different catalogues giving different totals of coins and it is likely that on discovery several coins were retained by the workmen who discovered the find. The Cabinet des Médailles acquired 15 coins from the hoard, for which RIC level data is available. Hobbs estimates a gold weight of approximately 8520.6 to 9239.4g.

A hoard of 500 silver coins (Mark Antony - Caracalla) found in a beaker on a new housing site, to be known as Clarney Place. The find was made 400 yards from the Darfield 1947 (Darfield I) hoard, but their depositions do not seem to be related. Carson and Corder published the hoard in 1948, but the catalogue does not align exactly to the coin summary. Trajan, Hadrian, Septimius Severus and Caracalla all have one fewer specimens in the catalogue compared to the summary, while the reverse is true for Otho. Since it is agreed that the hoard numbered 500, the summary has been regarded as the correct description of the hoard's contents.

The hoard consists of 336 coins, most of which are separate, with some bunches of coins stuck together. Additionally, there are eight fragments of pottery, including the complete base of the ceramic vessel with some coins still intact. Most coins are clearly contemporary copies or 'barbarous radiates'.
18 antoniniani (radiates) found stuck together on the elbow of a skeleton in a grave: Gallienus - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
A hoard of 107 provincial bronze coins (of which 74 were identifiable), found in the Roman barracks at Dura Europos.
The hoard comprised some broken vessels containing approximately 4,000 bronze coins which were thought to have mostly been sestertii.

The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 460 silver coins. Auvray mentions Gordian III, Philip, Trajan Decius, Volusian, Trebonianus Gallus and Valerian. In 1834, Pesche compiled a more complete catalogue. His source (although he does not acknowledge it) appears to be a manuscript held by the Sociétè d'Agriculture which describes Roman coins found in the city of Le Mans and its environs. Pesche adds to his catalogue coins of Marcus Aurelius, Faustina II, Lucius Verus, Lucilla and Pupienus. It is not clear whether these coins are part of the hoard. Silver: c.460 (1, 173) coins; silver weight: c. 576.7-1295.1g.
149 bronze coins of Viminacium and Provincia Dacia. 132 studied: Philip I - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 254-255). Mints: Viminacium 120, Provincia Dacia 12.
disposition: National Museum of History, Vranje, Serbia (132 coins).

summary: The hoard originally comprised an undetermined amount of antoninianii. Only 20 coins of Aurelian belonging to this hoard are now kept in a private collection.
A large hoard of antoniniani (radiates). Only 204 coins were noticed: Gallienus (sole) - Carinus (AD 283-284); silver weight: 36.8-65.2 g.

A hoard found in 1979 to the north west of Bath and thought to be complete except for six coins. Very little is known about the discovery of the hoard, except that it was associated with a few fragments of lead which may be derived from a container. 1'807 of the coins were cleaned and catalogued prior to the resale and dispersal of the hoard; 1805 antoniniani, 1 denarius and 1 quinarius, ranging from Gallienus to Allectus.
The hoard comprised 2,432 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) from Septimius Severus to Valerian I and Gallienus with a tpq of AD 256. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of 3513.1-7304.9g
17 antoniniani (radiates) found while building a house: Valerian I and Gallienus (Gallienus) - Probus (AD 276-282).
Circa 2,000 denarii but only 20 pieces indicate emperors from Antoninus Pius to Maximinus I Thrax.

35 denarii: Nero - Severus Alexander (AD 228-231). There is no certainty that this was the total number of the monetary group. The owner could have retrieved part of the coins, as well as the following agricultural works, probably, led to the finding of other pieces.
disposition: County Museum of History and Art, Zalău, Romania

summary: Concentration of 12 denarii and one drachm of Amisus (Hadrian), found in two adjacent excavations (1988/03 and 1992/42). This could well be a scattered purse or hoard.

1138 silver coins: 25 Greek drachmas, 1033 republican denarii, 54 imperial denarii and antoniniani (radiates), 2 provincial bronzes, 3 nummi, 21 unknown denomination: 150 BC - Valerian I/Gallienus (AD 253-268). Three coins of the House of Constantine I/Constans (AD 333-350) are most likely intruders; silver weight: 1552.6-3959.8 g.
Hoard of 216 antoniniani (radiates): Aurelian - Probus (AD 276-282).
7 bronze coins finds found in excavations: Nero - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Kyustendil, Bulgaria; inv. no. 59/1-5

summary: Hoard of gold and silver coins of circa 6 kilos: 3.85 silver, 2.26 gold. The gold coins were wrapped in leather and together with most of the silver ones they were distributed among the finders. 14 antoniniani (radiates) have been studied so far: Gordian III 8, and Philip I for Otacilia Severa 3, Gallienus 1, Claudius II 2.

in 1917, the museum received a small bronze container without lid that was said to have contained 18 coins (antoniniani, Gallienus to Tetricus), and probably found in Mainz-Kastel. The coins are lost.
The hoard comprised 'a block of between 200 and 400 radiates.': Gordian III - Postumus (AD 260-269.
88 antoniniani (radiates) found by metal detecting. Only 44 pieces were available for study.
The hoard comprised a vessel containing 3,000 antoniniani (radiates) of Tetricus I described as being small in size and therefore likely to be barbarous.

The hoard comprised 2,676 antoniniani (radiates) from Valerian I, Mariniana, Gallienus, Salonina, Quietus, Postumus, Laelian, Victorinus, Marius, Tetricus I, Tetricus II, Claudius Gothicus, Quintillus, Aurelian, Probus, Diocletian and Maximian I.
Circa 20,000 antoniniani (radiates). Among the issuers were Trajan Decius and Tetricus I.
The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing between 2,000 and 3,000 coins. The hoard was immediately dispersed but contained at least 20 radiates of Gallienus and Postumus.

29 Roman silver coins found at Chew Stoke, ranging from Republican denarii to the 3rd century AD. This may be the hoard mentioned by Rahtz (1957, 114) as having been found on Pagan's Hill by its then owner Mr Gray in 1870, though 40-50 silver coins were found. Very wide date spread, which may indicate a shrine or temple in use for a long time rather than a specific hoard (EG).

A hoard of 46 mostly bronze coins (26 provincial and 20 imperial), ranging from Domitian to Trajan Decius, found scattered on the floor of Villa A, in a destruction layer associated with the Sassanid invasion.
A hoard of 21 badly corroded provincial bronze coins, dating from Septimius Severus to Gordian III, found in Dura Europos.

Found during excavations in a Gallo-Roman "Vierecktempel" on a hilltop, above a cliff. Among many single finds a depot of 66 antoniniani (latest coin Diocletian, AD 293), found in the cella of the temple.

A small hoard of 45 radiates in a pot dating "to within a few years of AD 280" (Pastscape 343603) found during archaeological excavations of a Roman settlement in the Weedon Road area by Northamptonshire's Archaeological Unit in the 1970s.
27 silver coins of unknown denomination and issuer. According to the NUMIS the tpq is around AD 250.
18 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Postumus (AD 260-269); silver weight: 5.8-21.5 g.
Unknown originally number of coins. 156 pieces are known of which 39 antoniniani (radiates) of Gordian III, Philip I, Trajan Decius.
9 antoniniani (radiates): Gallienus - Claudius II (AD 268-270).
disposition: Private collection, loan Drents Museum Assen

summary: 494 coins found with a bronze vessel: 2 gold medallions, 6 aurei, 486 denarii and antoniniani (radiates): Nero - Postumus (AD 260-269); gold weight: 63.6 g.; silver weight: 133.8-1515.2 g. The hoard was found by a farmer. The multiple of Gallienus was acquired by the Kunsthistorisches Museum in Vienna.

The hoard comprised one vessel containing a harness fitting and 800 copper-alloy and silver coins of Commodus, Pertinax, Septimius Severus, Albinus, Julia Domna, Caracalla, Plautilla, Geta, Macrinus, Elagabalus, Julia Paula, Julia Maesa, Julia Soaemias, Severus Alexander, Julia Mamaea, Orbiana, Gordian I, Pulpienus, Balbinus, Gordianus III, Philip I, Philip II, Otacilia Severa and Herennius Etruscus.
79 antoniniani (radiates): Philip I - Victorinus (AD 269-271).

73 coins (44 denarii, 3 aurei and 23 bronze coins), ranging from Mark Antony to Severus Alexander, found together over time within the foundation walls of a Roman building located in the vicus surrounding the Roman fort of Eining. The earlier finds had been dispersed, but most of them could be traced in FMRD.

The hoard comprised an unknown number of sestertii from Augustus to Septimius Severus. Blanchet compiled a catalogue of the 45 coins which he saw. He noted that the coins of Antoninus Pius were very worn.
1279 antoniniani (radiates) found with a cooking pot: Gordian III - Gallienus (AD 260-268).
During the digging of a ditch three asses were found placed in a small amphora which was placed in a bigger one: Sextus Pompeius as, Augustus as, Philip I as,
68-70 kg, 28-30000 antoniniani: Valerian I - Florian (AD 276); silver weight: 5221.1-36248.9 g (after Hobbs).
140 bronze coins: 130 sestertii, 10 dupondii: Vespasian - Macrinus (AD 217-218).
11 coins: 1 aureus, 9 denarii, 1 bronze: Marcus Aurelius - Elagabalus (AD 218-222); gold weight: 7.1-7.2 g; silver weight: 17.2-22.6 g.
4957 radiates to Probus (AD 279), found in a jar, 10 miles south of Oxford. The hoard contained a second specimen of a coin of Domitianus (Domitian II), a Gallic usurper under Aurelian.
Hoard of 105 coins of the Bosporan kings: Rhescuporis II, Sauromates I, Cotys II, Rhoemetalces, Sauromates II, Rhescuporis III, Cotys III, Sauromates III, Rhescuporis IV, Ininthimeus.

Hoard of circa 1,200 'large bronzes' found with a large ceramic vessel: Trajan - Aemilian (AD 253). The largest number of coins belonged to Severus Alexander, Gordian III, Philip I and Philip II. Rare issues of the emperors Pertinax, Clodius Albinus, Gordian I and II,
190 antoniniani, probably, part of Sushina 2: Gordian III - Claudius II (AD 268-270).
277 antoniniani (radiates) and 29 imitations (28 radiates and 1 denarius): Severus Alexander - Victorinus (AD 269-271).
Four Alexandria tetradrachm: Claudius II- Tacitus (AD 275-276).
disposition: Museo Arch. Reg. "P. Orsi", Siracusa, Italy (inv.nos: 49600-49603)

summary: A hoard of 243 denarii from Antoninus Pius to Gordian III, including 5 Eastern coins of Septimius to Geta and one uncertain of Severus Alexander.
disposition: Museum of Anatolian Civilisations, Ankara, Turkey (inv.no. 1861)

summary: In 1852 a hoard of antoniniani from the middle of the third century was discovered in the neighbourhood of Klugham. 31 specimens from the hoard fell into the possession of the Historischer Verein von Obb. 33 coins are listed in FMRD, including 2 denarii (Caracalla - Valerian).

The hoard was found in two vessels and comprised 6,700 Provincial bronzes chiefly of Samos, ending with coins of Gallienus (sole reign). Other mints represented include Naxos, Ephesus, Magnesia ad Maeander and Smyrna. The two vessels were resting against the wall of a house, built west of the 'Cicero-Exedra'.
disposition: Staatliche Museen zu Berlin, Münzkabinett; Samos, archaeological museum

summary: 15 radiates (Gallienus to the Tetrici) from a larger hoard of unknown size discovered while ploughing a field somewhere outside Fishguard. No further details are available.

80 bronze coins were bought by M. Alexandrov: 1 sestertius, 79 provincial bronze coins: Hadrian - Gordian III (AD 238-244). Mints: Nicopolis ad Istrum 38, Marcianopolis 30, Hadranopolis 4, Anchialus 2, Deultum 2, Augusta Traiana 1, Pautalia 1, Nicomedia 1.
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 927-991

summary: 1,937 antoniniani (radiates) found in a cooking pot: Caracalla - Postumus (AD 263).

46 (or 47?) sestertii ranging from Domitian to Trajan Decius (or Mariniani, AD 253-260?), from a hoard found in Scarminga in the west of the Peloponnese (at Skarmingas, Pylia, near Maniaki according to Touratsoglou).
The hoard comprised 583 radiates from Gordian III to Postumus (AD 260-269). Hobbs estimates a silver weight of 175.8g to 727.8g.
The hoard comprised 91 denarii and 416 sestertii from Nero to Gordian III (AD 241-244).
disposition: Musée archéologique départemental de Guiry-en-Vexin, France

summary: A hoard of ca. 2000 bronze coins was discovered in 1902 in Eleusis, a few metres east of the peribolos wall of the sanctuary, in the garden of a coffeehouse belonging to Georgios B. Adam. The hoard was divided into two lots, which were said to have been approximately equal in size. One of these was dispersed. The other, consisting of 972 specimens, was examined and catalogued by Svoronos 1904. It included 958 provincial coins from Athens (time of the Antonines and Gallienus), 1 provincial coin from Thessalonica, 1 from Argos and 12 sestertii (Hadrian à Gordian III).
24 silver found in a ceramic vessel: 18 denarii, 6 antoniniani: Antoninus Pius - Gordian III (AD 238-244); silver weight: 34.1-63.8 g.
7 antoniniani (4 copies) Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Namur, Belgium (11 coins); collection Vandermaelen (2 coins and the shards from vessel), in 1851

summary: 2,382 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Postumus (AD 260-269); silver weight: 644.1-2976.5 g.
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles, Bruxelles, Belgium (110 coins and fragments and casts); collection Meire, in 1950

summary: 7 denarii undescribed (Vespasian - Severus Alexander) found in fortifications.
A hoard of 41,339 radiates of which an inventory of 4000 was completed by Salama on 10.3.76: Valerian I and Gallienus - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
(130) 79 coins: 3 denarii, 4 antoniniani, 71 provincial bronze coins: Elagabalus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).

The hoard was found in a vessel and comprised approximately 2,000 antoniniani (radiates), with the majority being Gallienus, Postumus and 'some other Gallic emperors' 'The hoard was found on the ground surface during flint extraction in the triage du Parc, around 2 km from the village in the Breteuil forest.' There appears to be an error with this findspot description as the triage du Parc is 8 km from Breteuil and is in the village of Bémécourt.
(700) 160 silver coins: Trajan - Valerian I/ Gallienus (AD 253-268). Found in a ceramic vessel together with a silver ring.
Circa 400 coins of which 87 were studied: Gallienus (sole) - Tetrarchy(AD 299).

The hoard comprised a black ceramic urn containing 7,563 small bronzes (radiates and copies) weighing 12,393 kg. Copies were estimated to make up 85% of the hoard. A preliminary catalogue was published in 1907; in 1911, a further catalogue with some corrections was made by Ledru; a third catalogue is preserved in Le Fonds Menjot d'Elbenne.
(750) 639 silver coins: Septimius Severus - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253); silver weight: 937.5 g.
disposition: Museum of History, Silistra, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 468-1108 (641 coins)

summary: 26 coins: 24 sestertii, 2 denarii: Trajan - Severus Alexander (Julia Mamaea) (AD 222-235); silver weight: 4.75 g.
disposition: Collection Ms. Ausselet, Charleroi, Belgium (26 coins and the lid)

summary: 700-750 bronze coins. 483 provide some information and 273 can be entered at the coin data level: Augustus - Postumus (AD 260-269).
The hoard was found in a hollow stone and comprised 300 denarii: Vespasian - Caracalla (AD 211-217).

Unknown initial number of silver coins. According to some information from a private collector the number of coins was between 2,500 and 3,000. 26 coins entered museum collection in Sofia: Otho - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. no. 32865

summary: (1213) 1209 silver coins: 10 denarii, 1199 antoniniani: Caracalla - Gallienus (AD 259-268); silver weight: 1752.4-2218.6 g. The hoard was foun within the ruins of a Roman building placed in a bronze vessel
disposition: Muzeul Na'ional al Unirii Alba Iulia, Romania

summary: 24 silver coins found in a stone quarry: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251)
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Veliko Tarnovo, Bulgaria; inv. nos. 2424-2446 (24 coins)

summary: 62 coins found with a vessel and traces of textile material. Only 29 pieces are now recorded: Elagabalus - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 260-268).
34 silver coins: 14 denarii, 20 antoniniani (radiates): Elagabalus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
4 coins of Gordian III: 2 antoniniani (radiates), 2 sestertii P M S COL VIM (AD 238-244).
1980 antoniniani: Gordian III - Claudius II (AD 268-270); silver weight: 535.6-2474.0 g.
Unknown number of coins from Gordian III, Philip I, Philip II, Trajan Decius, Etruscilla, Trebonianus Gallus, Valerian I, Gallienus and Salinina. 4 coins were donated to the Musée Château d'Annecy.
disposition: Musée Château d'Annecy, France; 4 coins, inv.no. 1055-1057-

summary: 5 antoniniani (radiates) of Probus and 'few hundred smaller bronze coins from the time of the thirty tyrants' (AD 260-274).
45 coins found by the farmer Peder Madsen in 1850. The hoard was found collected without a preserved container. The coins were found bundled together beneath a big stone.
The hoard comprised approximately 500 Roman billon coins (radiates), with the most recent being issues of Diocletian and Maximian.
Originally, 201 silver coins. 190 silver coins are documented: Hadrian - Carus (AD 282-285). The half follis of Justin I/Justinian I is, most likely, an intruder.
disposition: Regional History Museum, Targovishte, Bulgaria; inv.no. 165 (190 coins)

summary: A container with possibly 3000 antoniniani (Valerian - Quintillus) found in the Schwarzbruch forest close to Orscholz. The coins were dispersed, but 2842 were described. 619 were given to the Rheinisches Landesmuseum in Trier where 227 coins could still be traced.

The hoard comprised 84 coins (probably radiates) of Gordian III, Philip I, Philip II, Otacilia Severa, Trajan Decius, Herennius Etruscus, Hostilian, Herennia Etruscilla, Trebonianus Gallus, Volusian, Valerian, Gallienus, Salonina and Valerian II.
26 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Gallienus (AD 254). With silver jewelry.
Unknown initial number of coins. 12 silver coins: Antoninus Pius - Aurelian (AD 270-275); silver weight: 5.3-26.2 g.
Silver: 3 denarii, 208 antoniniani (radiates): Severus Alexander - Diocletian/Galerius (Caesar) (AD 293); silver weight: 43.8-497.0g.
disposition: Landesmuseum Niederösterreich, St. Pölten (in 1977 in Wien), Austria

summary: 151 silver coins: 17 denarii, 134 antoniniani (radiates): Marcus Aurelius (Divus Antoninus Pius) - Trebonianus Gallus/Volusianus (AD 253).
disposition: The Iron Gates Region Museum Drobeta-Turnu Severin, Romania (1957)

find_spot_name: SIRACUSA, EX VIGNA CASSIA, PRIMA TOMBA (GRUZZOLO C)
summary: Hoard in grave, 9 antoniniani (radiates): Gallienus (sole) - Quintillus/Aurelian (Divus Claudius II) (AD 270-275).
25 coins: 1 denarius, 12 antoniniani (radiates), 2 quadrantes, 10 unknown denomination: Claudius II - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
3,000 coins: Septimius Severus – Philip I (AD 244-249). No further details.
disposition: National History Museum, Bucharest, Romania (unknown number of coins)

summary: 1,156 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) together with 136 bronze coins found in two ceramic vessels ranging from Trajan to Gallienus.
The hoard comprised 39 bronze coins dated between the reigns of Herod Philip (4 BC - AD 34) and Gordian III (AD 238-244).

14 aureii (13 mounted): Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 204); gold weight 110 g. Found with a bronze pitcher. The content: two crosses; three chains; a brooch; sixty-eight pendants and sixty-four grains of necklace; fourteen coins of Roman emperors of the second-third century, the Antonines mainly, and two bracteates.
115 antoniniani (radiates) ranging from Gordian III to Valerian I and Gallienus.(AD 257-258). Part of a larger hoard.
539 antoniniani (radiates), ranging from the sole reign of Gallienus to Aurelianus, incl. Vabalathus. Hoard hidden in the debris of an earthquake dating from AD 241, covering the stadium building.
Unknown number of antoniniani. 3,562 coins in the Regional History Museum of Vidin: Gordian III - Aurelian (AD270-275).
disposition: Regional History Museum Vidin, Bulgaria; inv. no. 1074

summary: A hoard of ca. 677 provincial coins, ranging from Commodus Caesar to the joint reign of Valerian and Gallienus (AD 253-60), found in the sanctuary of Apollo Smintheion. Coins were mainly minted in Alexandria Troas (665 coins), but also in Parium (6 coins) and Abydus (1 coin). Çizmeli connects the deposition of this hoard with the invasions of the Goths in Asia Minor.
disposition: Laboratoire du Musée des Civilisations Anatoliennes, Ankara, Turkey

summary: 32 coins found scattered on an area of 3sqm: Gallienus (sole) - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
5 antoniniani of Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv. no. 2475

summary: 27 sestertii found together in a room from a Roman building considered to shave served as a warehouse.
Group of 2 coins found with an urn: Maximinus I Thrax bronze, Gordian III antoninianus (radiate) (AD 238-244).

The hoard comprised 'a ceramic vessel containing more than 300 middle bronzes. They were of Marcia Severa, the young Gordian, Gordian II. They were all different, but all base silver.' It is clear that the coins were radiates, although it is possible that there may have also been some denarii if the identification of coins of Gordian II is correct. The hoard was found by a labourer.

Before 1939, an archaeologist bought a hoard comprising 2,065 antoniniani (radiates) from a clerk in Évron. The hoard appears to have come from the north of the département, perhaps Aron or Évron, or, according to Cordonnier is another hoard from Jublains: Trajan Decius - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
4 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I - Postumus (AD 260-269).
disposition: Provinciaal Utrechts Genootschap van Kunsten en Wetenschappen, Utrecht, Netherlands

summary: A hoard of 1985 denarii (Nero-Julia Mamaea); 310 drachms of Arabia (242 of which depict Arabia and 68 show a camel, some overstruck on Nabataean kings); 1 Caesarean drachm (Domitian); 31 tetradrachms of Antioch (Nero-Hadrian); 2 Lycian drachms (Trajan); 2 Amisus drachms (Hadrian), found in a village near Amman.
disposition: American Numismatic Society (2333, 2321 of which are still listed in ANS records), American University in Beirut (17)

summary: Unknown number of antoniniani. 10 pieces were seen: Philip I, Otacilia, Trajan Decius.

3000 antoniniani (ranging from Trajan Decius to Tetricus, several of which are imitations) fund in a vessel close to Nieder-Ingelheim. 1174 specimens reached the museum Wiesbaden, the other coins are lost.
56 coins found in a ceramic vessel: 21 silver coins, 35 provincial bronzes: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv. no. 2070

summary: Unknown original number of coins. 19 antoniniani (radiates) were sold to a goldsmith. Probably the same hoard mentioned as found with an urn.
(316) 214 silver coins: 23 denarii, 191 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Postumus (AD 261); silver weight: 112.2-779.3 g.
Around 25 kg = 7,656 antoniniani (radiates): Elagabalus - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
A hoard of 25 aurei (Faustina I - Trajan Decius), one medallion of Gallienus and 16 articles of jewellery, found at Octavian Augustus Street in the ancient Jewish quarter in Alexandria.
(c. 7 kg) 300 silver coins: Hadrian - Maximian I (A284-293); silver weight: 56.7-852.5 g.
1058 billon provincial coins of Alexandria: Claudius II - Probus (AD 276-282).
Contents of a little purse. Six denarii Septimius Severus - Caracalla.
166 antoniniani (radiates): Caracalla - Philip I (AD 247-249); silver weight: 208.9-430.2 g.
disposition: Village museum, Slăveni, Romania, 122 coins; Muzeul Olteniei, Craiova, Romania, 44 coins

summary: The hoard comprised a greyware vessel containing between 1,100 and 1,500 silver and bronze coins, weighing 2.5kg. Desjobert who saw a small number of the coins, detailed that the coins included issues of Caracalla, Plautilla, Severus Alexander to Claudius II. When the hoard was dispersed, Drouet bought 27 radiates for the Musée du Mans including 7 Gallienus, 4 Claudius II, 4 Postumus, 3 Victorinus The hoard was found by a worker cleaning a fountain.
40 billon tetradrachms of Alexandria: Hadrian - VAlerian I and Gallienus (AD 257-258) found at floor level of a room during excavations of a house.
disposition: 34 coins in Ann Arbor, the rest in various Egyptian museums

summary: A hoard of 34,000 coins (100 kg), comprising large numbers of antoniniani from the period of the 'Gallic Empire' (AD 260-274), found in two storage ceramic vessels. A few denarii were also recorded. Coins range from Hadrian to Probus (276-282).

The hoard was found in a container beneath an altar to the goddess Fontana and comprised numerous bronze and brass issues which were deposited in the Gabinete de Numismática de la Biblioteca Nacional Portugesa. The coins appear to be the offerings of devotees. Only four of the coins have been described and these were in a poor state of preservation.
disposition: Gabinete de Numismática de la Biblioteca Nacional Portugesa., Lisboa.

summary: (c. 3000) 1831 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I - Aurelian (AD 270-275); silver weight: c. 811.0-3749.0 g.
A dispersed group of barbarous radiates noted by Penhallurick. Possibly a hoard. The identifiable prototypes are of Tetricus I and II.
160 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Diocletian (AD 284-293).
disposition: Sold to a British private collector.

summary: 21 silver coins: 9 denarii, 12 antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus (Geta Caesar) - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
disposition: County Museum of History and Art, Zalău, Romania (inv.no. CC 256/00)

summary: Unknown initial number of coins. 81 antoniniani (radiates) are available: Trebonianus Gallus - Claudius II (AD 268-270); silver weight: 18.5-80.3 g.
disposition: Regional Museum of History, Burgas, Bulgaria; inv.no. XVII, XXXIV; History Museum, Sliven, Bulgaria (3 coins); History Museum, Yambol, Bulgaria; inv.no. 1066 /0-12/

summary: The hoard comprised about 600 bronzes of Postumus.

337 silver coins: 272 denarii, 65 antoniniani: Antoninus Pius - Valerian I (AD 255). The hoard found in an urn contains also jewelry. It was found in an area where other archaeological evidence suggests Roman occupation.
43 coins, part of a larger hoard: Republic - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).
A possibly large number (1700?) of Roman coins were found at Cadnam, in the Forest, contained in a thumb pot. This included coins of Tetricus (I or II?).
26 antoniniani found in the house known as the 'House of Domitian's Diploma' with a small ceramic vessel: Severus Alexander - Quintillus (Divus Claudius II) (AD 270).
7 denarii: Trajan 1, Marcus Aurelius 1, Severus Alexander 1, uncertain 4.
199 Roman imperial large bronze coins found with a ceramic vessel: Hadrian - Valerian I and Gallienus/ Gallienus (sole) (AD 253-268).Possible part of the same hoard as Capoterra 1928a.

The hoard comprised between 300 and 400 Roman coins, stuck together with corrosion products: Gallienus (sole) - Allectus (AD 286-293). Approximately 80 coins were destroyed during cleaning. Just over 220 coins were identified by A. Deville. In 1846, a further 4 or 5 argentei (?) and 40 antoniniani (radiates) said to be from the same hoard were noted by Joseph Curt. In 1862, Charles Roach Smith published an aureus from a Continental mint (RIC 621) from the Warne Collection which was reputed to be from the same hoard. The stated provenance for this coin should be treated with some caution. The nummus of Constantine I is also an intruder.
disposition: Musée des Antiquités, Rouen; Muncipal Library of Rouen; Cabinet des Médailles de la Bibliothéque Natinoale, the Musée de Boulogne-sur-Mer, the British Museum (fewer than 10 coins), the Ashmolean Museum (fewer than 3 coins

summary: The hoard was found in a copper-alloy vessel covered with a silver plate and comprised 73 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) vfrom Vespasian to Valerian I. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of between 55.4g and 208.8g.
186 coins: 185 antoniniani (radiates), 1 billon Alexandrian drachm: Gallienus - Maximian I. Circumstances of find not known.
1013 silver cois: 1004 denarii, 9 antoniniani: Galba - Gordianus III (AD 239); silver weight: 1417.0-3160.9 g
The hoard comprised 'a lot of 62 double sestertii of Postumus (AD 260-268). They were sold to a dealer in Rouen who claimed they had been found in Eu.
1,204 coins: 4 antoniniani (radiates), 1,199 sestertii, 1 as: Vespasian - Postumus (AD 268).
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles de la Bibliothèque nationale de France, Paris

summary: A farmer from Buprich uncovered an earthenware container filled with many Roman coins in the vicinity of the village. The container appears to have contained more than 1000 antoniniani (Gallienus - Tetricus). 832 of them were described, but giving only the reverse legend, not the type. 727 are listed in FMRD.
45 bronze coins: 44 sestertii, 1 dupondius: found together in an edifice hypotetically identified as of collegium augustales: Domitian 0- Maximinus I THrax (AD 236-238).
disposition: Museo Arqueológico Municipal de Cartagena, Spain

summary: 745 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I and Gallienus - Diocletian (AD 293).

The hoard was found in a well under the Roman ramparts and comprised 18 denarii from Septimius Severus to Severus Alexander and 8 antoniniani (radiates) from Philip I to Trebonianus Gallus. All the coins were from the mint of Rome, with the exception of a denarius of Severus Alexander from Antioch and two denarius copies of Caracalla and Severus Alexander.
Unknown number of bronze coins. 5 pieces were examined: Caracalla - Elagabalus.
241 antoniniani (radiates): Elagabalus - Postumus (AD 260-269); silver weight: 67.4-624.3 g.
The hoard comprised an iron pot filled with several hundred denarii and radiates from Trajan to Postumus (AD 260-269).
1,576 coins found in two ceramic vessels: 1 denarius, 1,575 antoniniani (radiates): Severus Alexander (Julia Mammaea), Trebonianus Gallus - Tetricus I (AD 271-274); silver weight: c. 300.6-2,110.7 g.

The hoard comprised a copper-alloy vessel containing 931 radiates for which Bourriau provides a summary catalogue: Trebonianus Gallus - Tetricus I (AD 271-274). Atgier noted the presence of coins of Quintillus and Constantine but TAF believes this to be an error. The coins were acquired by the Bibliothèque Municipale de La Rochelle. The jug handle is in the Musée d'Orbigny.
disposition: Bibliothèque Municipale de La Rochelle (coins); Musée d'Orbigny (jug)

summary: The hoard comprised 54 antoniniani (radiates) of Postumus with a FELICITAS AVGVSTI reverse type. The hoard was found 20 meters from the deposit found in 1865 at Fontaine Saint-Aubin.
It comprised 258 antoniniani (radiates) from Elagabalus to Aurelian (AD 270-275).
"Few hundreds" Roman coins found in a field. Only 33 coins provided some information and some of them have been entered to the level of the coin. The precision is not certain.

Remains of a wealthy residential development was unearthed during excavation for the new synagogue. In the process 11 Roman bronze coins were found (2 großerz of Antoninus Pius, 2 mittelerz of Commodus, and klenerz from the father Tetricus).
A hoard of 1,545 coins (270 tetradrachms, 1 bronze, 1,274 antoniniani down to Claudius II, AD 270), found during the excavations at Capharnaeum.

More than 1,000 pieces were found, of which nearly 700 were brought to the museum. Due to corrosion products on the coins, only about 100 of the coins were identified. There were problems of identification and classification and therefore it is not possible to date the latest coin in the hoard. However, several coins had the legend GALLIENVS AVG suggesting a date range of AD 260 to 268.
The hoard comprised an iron vessel containing between 700 and 800 coins of Elagabalus to Postumus (AD 260-269).
The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 4,000 plated coins. The hoard was found by workmen digging ditches on the ancient route from Mans to Paris.
The hoard comprised fragments of a greyware vessel containing 90 sestertii from Trajan to Postumus with a tpq of AD 261.

The hoard was found in a broken ceramic vessel and comprised 8 to 9 kilos of coins. Magaud catalogued 2,406 coins: 1 denarius, 2,405 antoniniani (radiates) and in 1910, the abbot Angot added another 43 coins which Magaud incorporated into the hoard. The hoard was found by a farm labourer in a field: Maximian I Thrax - Tetricus I (AD 271-274); silver weight: 651.7-5724.2g.
The hoard comprised 1 radiate of Claudius II and 38 Provincial coins of the early third century AD, found in a grave (Grave Θ) in Amphipolis in 1976

Depression F3321 contained 7 re-deposited (curated?) Palaeo. handaxes in lowermost gravel fill, pottery & coins. Upper dark fills contained tile frags., mortar frags., a copper alloy brooch, finger rings, bracelet frags., tweezers, nail cleaner, pins and a key; a lead-filled bronze head, a bronze priest's head moulding, iron knife blades, an iron buckle, bone pins & pieces of antler. Also 78 coins from F3321 - 17 of AD 270-284 & 10 of AD 293-296 in lower fills, 9 of AD 330-345 & 42 of AD 388-402 in upper fills.

The hoard comprised between 800 and 1000 antoniniani/radiates including coins of Valerian I, Gallienus, Salonina, Claudius II and Quintillus (AD 270). The exact size of the hoard is not known as the hoard was not preserved as a whole. Found together with a ceramic vessel.
Said to have been found at Satala. The hoard comprised 17 antoniniani (radiates) dated between the reigns of Valerian I and Carus.
Over 2,897 antoniniani (radiates): Treboninaus Gallus - Claudius II (AD 268-270).
disposition: Landesmuseum Joanneum, Graz, Austria (for restoration work - in 1977)

summary: 6 antoniniani (radiates): Gallienus - Claudius II (AD 268-270).
The hoard comprised a copper-alloy patera or pan containing 700 denarii from Augustus to Maximinus, a silver intaglio finger ring and an unspecified amount of gold jewellery.
56 denarii found in the Seaside baths complex. Only 31 have survived: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 202-205).
114 provincial bronze coins: Antoninus I (Faustina I) - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Regional Museum of History, Burgas, Bulgaria; inv.no. inv.no.741-758, 760-766,768-770,772-780, 782-842, 845-855, 982

summary: 24 coins: 2 antoniniani (radiates), 1 denarius, 6 sestertii, 4 dupondii, 12 asses: Tiberius (Divus Augustus) – Florian (AD 276)
The hoard comprised between 600 and 700 antoniniani (radiates) from Gallienus to Tetricus I. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of between 210.9g and 874.1g.
The hoard comprised 27 coins from Gallienus to Postumus and Tetricus I and one gold ring. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of between 8.7 and 31.5 g.
3 coins: Vitellius sestertius, Antoninus Pius (Diva Faustina I) denarius, Philip I antoninianus (radiate) (AD 244-245).
3 coins: Hadrian dupondius, Septimius Severus denarius, Gordian III dupondius (AD 238-244).

The hoard comprised a vessel containing 13kg of Roman coins (between 4500 and 4600 coins). Breuillac studied 2300 'small bronzes and billon coins' dating from Valerian to Aurelian, although Allard also notes a coin of Philip I. The hoard was found in a ditch close to the ruins of the Château de Curzay; silver weight: c. 1216.0-5624.1g.
1233 silver coins: 2 denarii, 1231 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Valerian I (AD 258).
The hoard comprised 4000 coins with emperors from Severus Alexander to Postumus represented. The hoard was found by a farmworker.
The hoard comprised 1,147 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) from Septimius Severus to Gallienus (AD 260-268).

The hoard comprised 216 coins (without doubt mostly denarii and antoniniani (radiates) and a range of silver vessels, gold and silver jewellery and a copper-alloy figurine. The earliest coin was an aureus of Galba and the latest were issues of Gallienus. The hoard was found close to a mill at a depth of 15 inches. Most of the hoard was acquired by the Musée de Genève. The aureus of Galba was stolen before 1903.

The hoard comprised a finger ring with an intaglio depicting Mercury, a worn dupondius, 64 denarii and 75 antoniniani (radiates) from Septimius Severus to Trebonianus Gallus. The objects and coins were enclosed in a leather bag which had been placed in a small recess in the foundations of a third-century building.

Around 1910 a hoard with 423 Antoniniani was salvaged during excavation of a building pit. The find spot ('auf den Kästrich') could not be further circumscribed, so that it is uncertain whether the deposit was found inside or outside of the legionary camp. The find is said to have been found with leather remnants in an earthenware container.

Unknown initial number of coins. 15 bronze and billon coins entered the collection of the museum in Cagliari: 7 sestertii, 8 antoniniani (radiates): Antoninus Pius - Aurelian (AD 270-275); silver weight: 4.6-19.5g.
1310 silver coins: Antoninus Pius - Valerian I/Gallienus (AD 253-259) coins; silver weight: 1496-3124.7 g.
41 coins: 1 antoninianus (radiate) and 41 imitations in an alloy of copper and lead: 1 Valerian I, 40 Gallienus (AD 257-258).
176 coins: 3 medallions, 58 sestertii, 115 antoniniani (radiates): Domitian - Gallienus (AD 260); silver weight: 145.4-337.5 g.
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Namur, Belgium (171 coins); private collection (2 coins), in 1961

summary: It comprised c. 100 bronze coins found with a ceramic vessel: Trajan - Philip I (AD 244-249). Only 30 are now recorded: 29 sestertii, 1 as.
Unknown number of silver coins. 19 antoniniani are known: Caracalla - Philip I (AD 244-249).
