disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2729

summary: In a bronze bucket 951 bronze coins: Augustus - Postumus (AD 260-261).
The six antoniniani (radiates) were interpreted as representing a purse hoard or being part of a larger deposit.

A hoard of 124 coins, comprising tetradrachms (Philip I - Gallus), denarii (Domitian - Alexander Severus, one quinarius (Caracalla) and one provincial bronze coin (Gordian III & Abgar), found at Dura in G1, during the season 1936–7. No container was reported.
(c.700) 601 bronze coins: 598 sestertii (+ imitations), 2 dupondii, 1 as: Vespasian - Postumus (AD 262).
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles, Bruxelles, Belgium (37 coins); in 1959, 13 private collectors: 564 coins

summary: The hoard comprised somewhere between 2,000 and 2,500 coins, of which a large proportion were taken by the finders. Only 308 coins were catalogued.
14 denarii (late Republic to Severus Alexander) were found in 1906 in front of the door sill of cellar 83 (in the Roman settlement).
676 Roman imperial bronzes found in the ground: Trajan - Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) (AD 253-268).

A hoard of Syrian tetradrachms (668 according to Coin Hoards, 666 according to Bland) ranging in date from Caracalla to Trebonianus Gallus. It is said to have been found at Iskenderun, 57 km north of Antioch.
600 antoniniani (radiates), of which 122 were recovered: Valerian I and Gallienus - Diocletian (AD 284-293); silver weight: 22.3-146.6 g.
Unknown originally number of coins found with a ceramic vessel. 130 silver coins are known: 1 antoninianus (radiate), 129 denarii: Antoninus Pius - Gordian III (AD 238-244).

The hoard was found in the foundations of a 15th century house and comprised a small deposit of 3rd century coins. J. Chappée told Blanchet there were 10 coins: Victorinus 2, Tetricus I 3, Tetricus II 5.
Unknown initial umber of coins. 46 denarii: Vespasian - Elagabalus (AD 222).
Hoard of 2,093 coins of the Bosporan kings, Ininthimeus and Rhescuporis V (AD 242-276).

The wooden box contained pieces of silverware and various Roman artefacts. The finder sold the jewellery to the Imperial Library, today the National Library. The coins were dispersed; 1,450 denarii and antoniniani (radiates). The hoard consists of: 8 gold necklaces, pearls or semi-precious stones; 5 gold rings; 6 silver rings; 1 ivory styllus; 1 silver ingot; 1 gold roll of wire; hollow gold fingers (plectrum); a stone statuette of Aesculapius; several rings with intaglio; 2 silver hearts and 1 necklace pendant with a gold coin.
523 antoniniani (radiates) found with a ceramic vessel: Gallienus - Claudius II (AD 268-270).

The hoard comprised 10.6kg of coins. Mints represented are Rome (3195); Milan (135); Viminiacium (1); Siscia (151), Sirmium (2), Antioch (1); Cyzicus (10); Cologne (13); Trier (11); uncertain (53) Found during the construction of a vault. Silver: 28, 3590, 47 coins; Silver weight: 1008.5-4527.4
(c.3.500-5,000) 61 antoniniani: Valerian I/Gallienus - Probus (AD 276-282); silver weight: 721.1-4999.1 g.
disposition: Museum of Chambéry, France (2 kg), including the ceramic vessel

summary: 17 sestertii and middle bronzes from Augustus to Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
488 silver coins: 227 denarii, 1 plated denarius, 260 antoniniani: Commodus - Philip I (AD 244-247).
disposition: Muzeul de Istorie Națională și Arheologie, Constanța, Romania

summary: 340 denarii: Nero - Septimius Severus (AD 202-210).
136 large imperial bronzes (sestertii?), well-preserved: Trajan - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 253-260).
The hoard comprised 79 sestertii from Vespasian to Treboninanus Gallus (AD 251-253).

The hoard comprised a coarseware vessel containing silver and billon coins (denarii and antoniniani (radiates). Although the hoard was immediately dispersed, 183 coins were examined by M. Le Pesant: Antoninus Pius - Postumus (AD 260-269)
The hoard comprised approximately 100 'small bronzes' - 'radiates' of Gallienus, Claudius II, Victorinus, Tetricus I and Tetricus II The hoard was found in the Reverchon quarry
24 coins: 1 antoninianus (radiate), 22 sestertii and 1 dupondius. The latest coin is a sestertius of Trajan Decius for Herennia Etruscilla (Augusta) (AD 249-251).

The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel 'containing 9kg coins, mostly 3rd century small bronzes of the Gallic emperors, Gallienus, Postumus etc., although according to Triger there were some earlier coins of Trajan, Antoninus Pius, Faustina, and Justine (sic). This information was repeated by numismatic reviews and by Blanchet. In 1911, Ledru wrote about the coins acquired by Julien and Louis Chappée and gave a list of emperors. A lot of 1,219 coins were bought by the Musée du Mans in 1890. The hoard was found during quarrying. Silver weight: c.812.3-7797.7g.
(4033) 3296 silver coins recorded: 592 denarii, 2704 antoniniani: Domitian to - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251). Found in a ceramic vessel.
disposition: The British Museum, London, United Kingdom

summary: The hoard comprised 283 tetradrachms dated between the reigns of Septimius Severus (AD 193-211) and Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
200 antoniniani, most of them belonging to Gordian III, were found beneath a collapsed roof within an ancient settlement.
57 billon: Hadrian - Gallienus (Salonina) (AD 264-265) found as an unprotected heap on the floor of an underground room during excavations of a house. Range: Hadrian - Gallienus (AD 260-268).
disposition: 37 in Ann Arbor, the rest in various Egyptian museums

summary: The hoard comprised one denarius and 72 antoniniani (radiates) ending with coins of Aurelian (AD 270-275) found with a bronze vessel.
(488) 168 silver coins: Commodus - Quintillius (AD 270)
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. no. LXVII (75 coins)

summary: A hoard of 180+ AE provincial coins of Thrace (1), Macedonia (2) and Asia Minor (177, mostly Pamphylia (64), Pisidia (50) and Western Cilicia (10)), dating from the first century AD to the reign of Aurelian.

The hoard was scattered by the plough, but 124 coins were recovered. They comprised 2 denarii and 122 antoniniani (radiates) from Septimius Severus to Gallienus and Postumus with a tpq of AD 263. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of 37.6g to 154.7g.
501 silver coins. 496 entered the museum collection in Pazardhzik: 78, 427: Antoninus Pius - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); silver weight: 644.3-1323.4 g.
disposition: Regional History, Museum, Pazardhzik, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 1904-2087

summary: 134 sestertii: Nero - Gordian III (AD 238-244).

There were 914 antoniniani (radiates) in the hoard. The obverse details for each coin were not recorded and it is not possible to assign the coins to mints. Although Mira (1995-7, 137) gives the total number of coins as 914, only 905 are accounted for in the catalogue.
34 bronze coins: 20 sestertii, 14 asses: Severus Alexander - Valerian I and Gallienus (Gallienus) (AD 254-255).
96 denarii found with a ceramic pitcher: Republic – Septimius Severus (AD 201-210).
disposition: History Museum "lulian Antonescu", Bacău (91 coins); Cultural room, Ardeoani (4 coins); High-school ”Vasile Alecsandri”, Bacău (1 coin)

summary: Recorded by the Somerset Levels Project. Hoard comprised just 3 radiates, found during peat digging. No archaeological context.
Indeterminable total number of coins found by remains of an important Roman villa. Among issuers: Gallienus, Tetricus I

Hoard found in a cooking pot (not preserved) during construction work for the Nordostbahn railway track. It comprised an unknown number of antoniniani, of which 204 (possibly the greater part) are preserved in public collection, ranging from Trebonianus Gallus to Claudius II. - After the publication in 1992, at least another 6 coins from this hoard were recorded, in a private collection in Diessenhofen. The sherds of the pot are described in the 1893 publication. Four Gallienus coins were also subjected to chemical analysis at the same time, pp. 11-12: "Derselbe hat drei Stücke auf ihre Zusammensetzung quantitativ und qualitativ, das vierte nur qualitativ untersucht und folgendes gefunden: I. 6 Theile Zinn, 94 Theile Kupfer; II. 30 Th. Silber, 0,3 Th. Gold, 69,7 Th. Kupfer; III. 18 Th. Antimon, 82 Th. Kupfer; IV. Kupfer, Antimon und wenig Bismuth."
disposition: Thurgauisches Historisches Museum, Frauenfeld (158 coins); Museum Allerheiligen, Schaffhausen (40 coins); Schweizerisches Landesmuseum Zürich (6 coins); private (6 coins)

summary: Nine antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Claudius II (AD 268-270).
Unknown number of silver coins. 23 silver coins were seen: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249); silver weight: 18.2-34.5 g.
disposition: Museum of History, Karnobat (12 coins); Regional History Museum, Burgas, Bulgaria (inv.no. XVI)

summary: The hoard was found in a tomb and comprised a copper-alloy vessel containing 75 (or 78) radiates, 17 surgical implements and 5 tinned or silvered containers, which probably originally contained ointment: Victorinus - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).

The hoard comprised 24 coins which were scattered over an area measuring approximately 1m² , a fragment of a copper-alloy brooch dating to the second half of the first century AD and a piece of copper-alloy. They were found at the site of a Gallo-Roman villa where in 1919 another hoard of coins was found. It is possible that they are part of the same deposit.
1,745 coins: 1,742 antoniniani (radiates), 3 denarii: Gallienus - Diocletian (AD 285); silver weight: 318.0-439.9 g.
2,290 silver coins found with ceramic vessel: Commodus - Valerian I (AD 257-259).
758 coins from Augustus to Gallienus (sole) (AD 260-268).
disposition: Medagliere del Museo Nazionale Romano, Roma, Italy

summary: 45 silver coins: Caracalla - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); silver weight: 63.1-128.9 g.
160 silver coins: Septimius Severus - Valerian I (AD 253-260).
disposition: AM Zagreb (41); ZM Sarajevo (114); Fojnica monastery; dispersed

summary: 762 tetradrachms of Alexandria: Aurelian - Diocletian-Maximian I (AD 295-296) found in a jar in underground room H during excavations of a house.
About 20 antoniniani (radiates) found during prospections. Only 10 of them were studied: Valerian I and Gallienus or Gallienus (sole reign) - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
In the vicus was found a hoard of 161 sestertii: Vespasian - Postumus (AD 267).
691 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) - Diocletian-Maximian I (AD 284-293). No further details.
(c. 1000) 995 silver coins: 203 denarii, 792 antoniniani: Vespasian - Valerian I/Gallienus (AD 253-268); silver weight: 1277.0-2659.3 g.

A hoard of 10 denarii (Septimius Severus - Alexander Severus) discovered during groundwork for the continuation of Harthauser Street into wooded area in southern Harlaching. The coins lay close to the remains of a skeleton.
60 large bronze coins (i.e. sestertii) were found in a bowl in Trier, in the suburb St. Barbara inside Roman stonework.
Unknown orignal number of coins. 72 antoniniani (radiates) were available for study. The hoard was found in two large ceramic vessels.

The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 31 radiates of the third century AD. Chardome examined 18 in the Musèe de Beaufort in August 1973. Collin and Provost provide a different catalogue of 7 Gallienus, 5 Claudius II, 3 Postumus, 4 Victorinus, 1 Tetricus I, I Tetricus II.
disposition: Musèe de Beaufort, France (18 coins studied)

summary: (104) 98 provincial bronze coins up to Gordian III (AD 238-244).
700 antoniniani (radiates) of Claudius II, Aurelian, Severina, Tacitus, Probus, Carus, Numerian, Nigrinianus (AD 283-285).
The find comprised numerous (1000-2000) copies of radiates of Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
The hoard comprised 135 sestertii from Vespasian to Postumus with a tpq of AD 260.
16 gold staters of the Bosporan kings: Sauromates II, Rhescuporis III.

Five coins from the Trajan Decius reign were discovered by treasure hunters in 2011. The exact location and circumstances of the find are unknown. The coins have traces of fire, therefore, they may have been found in a burial (cremation).

There is an account of Borlase receiving four radiates from the Rector of Lanreath that were found at the unidentified place of "Carlean" in 1785. The findspot was described as "near the northern extremity of [the earthwork known as] the Giant's-hedge, not far from Ethy", at Lerryn creek, on the Eastern banks of the River Fawy". Penhallurick suggests that Carlean is a misreading of Collon.
155 silver coins: Vespasian - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); silver weight: 216.6-451.6 g.
Small assembly of 8 sestertii, found in El Molinete.
332 silver coins: 45 denarii, 287 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Valerian I (AD 253-259); silver weight: 383-758.6 g. Found in a ceramic vessel.
disposition: Regional History Museum, vratsa, Bulgaria; inv.no. M II 3011-3330 (320 coins)

summary: The hoard comprises of 67 silver coins, 34 denarii, 33 antoniniani (radiates), from Commodus to Trajan Decius with a tpq of AD 249-251.

A grave found in the peribolos of the west cemetery of ancient Rhodes (reused in late Roman times) contained a hoard comprising 4 Roman bronze coins: 1 of Aemilianus (in the mouth of the deceased), 1 of the first to second century AD, 1 of Caracalla and 1 of Alexander Severus (beside the head).
The hoard was found in pot with 1,600 low-grade silver coins of Postumus. Silver: c.1600 (500) coins; Silver weight: c.432
27 coins. 26 denarii. One possible barbarian imitation: Septimus Severus- Severus Alexander (ca. AD 235.)
The hoard was comprised a black pot containing 356 denarii and antoniniani (radiates)
77 coins: 11 denarii, 39 antoniniani (radiates), 12 AR, 10 sestertii 5 AE: Tiberius - Postumus (AD 266-267); silver weight: 31.3-136.1 g.
Originally were 420 silver coins. 274 pieces were recovered: 1 denarius, 273 antoniniani (radiates): Caracalla - Gallienus/Postumus (AD 259-268).

summary: Four gold coins (Antoninus Pius to Caracalla), found by a farmer from the village of Umm Qeis (anc. Gadara), and seen by the archaeologist Paul Ilton.
The hoard comprised 3,604 small module radiate copies, known as 'minimi' [antoniniani (radiates)]. The hoard was found in an amphora covered by a tile while digging foundations for a building
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles de la Bibliotheque Natiobnale de France (in 1937)

summary: 2,239 coins: 4 antoniniani (radiates), 2,181 sestertii, 6 dupondii, 1 as, 47 cast sestertii: Republic - Valerian and Gallienus (AD 254-256); circa 50 kilos.

summary: Of those seen (934), were denarii and antoniniani (radiates) from Septimius Sverus to Philip I (AD 244-249); silver weight: 1364.0-1708.8g.

Unknown number of coins. Few coins are mention in the collection of Reydet de la Vulpillière, which indicate a large diversity of coins, denarii, antoninaini, sestertii, from Republic to Tacitus (AD 276)

The hoard comprised 2000 coins of 'copper, silver alloy and silver'. In the report compiled by P. Ilarregui the hoard contained pieces of the emperors: Pius Gordianus, Philip, Trajan Decius, Trebonianus Gallus, Volusian, Gallienus, Saloninus (Caesar), Saloninus (Emperor) and Postumus. summary: A hoard of 299 tetradrachms (Caracalla - Elagabalus) and denarii (Domitian - Severus Alexander) from Dura Europos, found in J 7 W.
The hoard comprised nearly 1,500 antoniniani (radiates) of Gallienus to Probus, with coins of Probus being the most numerous. Only one coin of Gallienus' sole reign was described (RIC 599).
11 antoniniani of Philip I found in a small ceramic vessel (AD 244-249)
The hoard comprised 'some 500 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) of which only 20 were examined' Found at the ancient port in unknown circumstances.
201 sestertii from Domitian to Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 254-255).
29 antoniniani (radiates): Aurelian - Probus (AD 276-282).
300 denarii and antoniniani (radiates), 130 coins were recovered: Vespasian - QuintillusI (AD 268-270).
The hoard comprised 6 aurei and silver jewelry. Two of the aurei are mounted in gold frames. The coins are: Antoninus Pius, Caracalla, Julia Domna, Macrinus and 2 of Severus Alexander (AD 234).
disposition: Musée national des Antiquités et Arts musulmans, Alger, (ex Musée Stéphane Gsell), Algeria; inv.nos. 1045 - 1053

summary: Circa 150 antoniniani (radiates). 77 coins, including 24 copies. Together was found a small bronze hatchet: Gallienus - Tetricus I (AD 271-274); silver weight: c.35.0-156.5g.
disposition: Musée des Antiquités de Rouen (collection Thaurin), France (77 coins). Hoards file in the Archives of the Museum (no inv.nos)

summary: unknown initial number of coins. 154 silver coins: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Veliko Tarnovo, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 2447-2561 (154 coins) - stolen

summary: 1,173 antoniniani (radiates) found with a ceramic vessel: Valerian I and Gallienus - Tetricus I (AD 271-274); silver weight: 317.7-1465.3g.
190 bronze coins: 1 sestertius, 170 provincials: Antoninus Pius (Faustina I) - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Haskovo, Bulgaria; inv.no. 211-257

summary: The hoard comprised 6,010 antoniniani (radiates) and one as from Severus Alexander to Probus. In 1967, a further 7 antoniniani (radiates) of Tetricus I were recovered from the same findspot and are assumed to be part of the same hoard. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of between 1084.4 or 15626.3g.
More than 1,500 coins were discovered in a bowl. However, only 77 pieces are known in any detail, 5% of the original hoard: Caracalla - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 258-259).

The hoard comprised 1,094 antoniniani (radiates) including issues of Valerian I, Gallienus, Postumus, Marius, Victorinus, Claudius II, Divus Claudius II, Quintillus, Tetricus I, Tetricus II and Aurelian. Silver weight: 208.4-798.1 g.
242 antoniniani: Philip I - Postumus (AD 260-269).

The hoard comprised a black ceramic vessel containing a hoard of coins and jewellery. The jewellery included a gold necklace, 3 gold intaglio finger rings, a gold and silver intaglio finger ring and an iron finger ring with silver decoration. The number of coins in the hoard is not known with any certainty. Pérot claims there were 100 sestertii and 150 denarii, whereas Clément catalogued 92 coins, including 67 bronzes (mostly sestertii) and 25 denarii (and radiates?). There were some identification errors with 1 sestertius and 2 denarii attributed to Antoninus Pius, when in fact they were issues of Caracalla.
A hoard of 3 Roman Provincial coins minted at Thessalonica (2 of Elagabalus, 1 Gordian III), found in grave 35 in the western cemetery of Pella. The grave also contained numerous other artefacts.
Unknown originally number of coins. 72 antoniniani (radiates) were available for study: Valerian I and Gallienus - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
37 sestertii: Hadrian - Elagabalus (AD 221-222).
The hoard was enclosed or set within a square-cut stone and comprised 11 antoniniani (radiates) from Valerian I and Gallienus to Postumus (including E.384 and E.385).
(40) 20 silver coins: Septimius Severus - Postumus (AD 263); silver weight: c.14.6-84.0 g.
disposition: Collection Derjicke, Iddergem, Belgium (20 coins), in 1965

summary: The hoard comprised 39 radiates of Gallienus and Salonina, found in the Euripides / Peristeria cave, on the south of the island of Salamis.
Hoard of 600 coins of Sauromates I, Cotys II, Eupator, Sauromates II, Rhescuporis III, Cotys III.
ca. 1500 to 2000 coins, but only 528 are identified: Valerian I - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
The hoard comprised 586 bronze coins: Augustus-Philip I (AD 244-249).
The hoard comprised 2394 bronze coins: sestertii, dupondii and asses Galba to Gordian III (AD 238-239).
About 100 antoniniani up to the 3rd century AD.
The hoard comprised 5 silver denarii from Septimius Severus to Elagabalus. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of 9.2g.

116 coins found in 1870 close to Moneybury Hill, with articles of metal, animal remains, and broken Roman pottery. The coins range from the first half of the 1st century AD to ca. AD 270 and included 2 denarii, 8 antoniniani, 78 bronze and 28 cast coins. These coins could have formed two separate hoards (one consisting of AE up to ca. AD 249; the other ranging down to AD 270).
The hoard comprised 42 bronze coins from Nero to Gallienus including imperial bronzes (sestertii) and Provincial bronzes from Knossos, Kydonia, Koinon of Crete and Alexandreia Troas.
4,778 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I and Gallienus - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
disposition: Beekvliet / Sint Michielsgestel Romeins Museum / Museum Den Bosch / private collection; Rijksdienst voor het Oudheidkundig Bodemonderzoek

summary: 21 antoniniani. T. Gerasimov saw 2 of Gordian III

The hoard was found during the excavation of 21 'puits funéraire' at Troussepoil and comprised 231 brass coins (sestertii?). Close to the hoard, 3 broken black ceramic jugs were excavated, two of which were filled with ashes and funeral pyre debris. Baudry thought that the coins had originally been placed in the jugs, but that hypothesis is not certain. The hoard was discovered during the excavation of 21 'puits funéraire' of Troussepoil.
33 tedrachams from Philip I (Otacilia Severa) - Diocletian. Before the monetary reform of AD 297. Only 16 pieces could be identified.
The hoard was found during the course of a rescue excavation and comprised 8 antoniniani (radiates) from Gordian III to Valerian and Gallienus.

Around 500 radiates (Valerian I to Diocletian) found by a workman in a rock crevice inside a coal mine near Aberkenfig. The coins were apparently lying on a fragment of decayed cloth, suggesting a container. Three different lists of this hoard exist, totalling c. 530, 500 and 492 coins. The list here follows the one given by Robertson, based on the 492 coins deposited at the National Museum Cardiff.

On the site of a Roman temple or shrine (?) in a field: 30 coins, significantly limited to the inner recessed area. The number joined by corrosion suggests the possibility of a disturbed hoard. They are mainly debased antoniniani covering the same period as the hoard found during the last century. Undated. Late 3rd century AD
It comprised 93 sestertii found with a ceramic vessel. Only 88 are now recorded: Trajan - Philip I (AD 244-249).
17 denarii, 11 antoniniani (radiates) and 1 sestertius (separated): Septimius Severus - Valerian I (AD 253-260).
(16-20 kg) (8-900) 501 bronze coins: 459 sestertii, 2 dupondii: Vespasian - Maximinus I Thrax (AD 235-238).
disposition: Town museum, Kortrijk, Belgium (240 coins); Collection Heritiers Adriaen (212 coins); Collection Ms. Depoorter (5 coins)

summary: 12 bronze coins of Viminacium probably issued under Gordian III and Philip I (AD 246-247)
disposition: Museum of Sofia; inv. nos. CIII and CLXVII (1936 and 1953)

summary: 32 coins: 23 sestertii, 7 dupondii and 2 antoniniani (radiates): Titus - Postumus (AD 260-268).
The hoard comprised 15 coins (2 denarii and 13 Provincial issues: Thessalonica, Amphipolis, Stobi, Cassandrea, Koinon of Macedonia), found in sarcophagus 1 in Ierissos.
55 coins: 4 gold medallions, 5 aurei and 46 silver coins: Only 17 coins are studied: 4 medallions, 5 aurei, 8 argentei: Numerianus - Constantius I (AD 294).
disposition: National Hungarian Museum (Inv.no. 104.1885 - gold pieces only), Budapest, Hungary; private collections F. Trau (Vienna) and A. Bachofen von Echt (Nussdorf, Vienna)

summary: Unknown originally number of coins. 53 denarii were recovered in two lots: Vespasian – Gordian III (AD 238-244).
809 silver coins: 91 denarii, 718 antoniniani: Antoninus Pius (Faustina II) - Valerian I (AD 258). Found with two ceramic vessels.
6 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III 1, Philip I 4, Valerian I 1 (AD 258-259). Found with jewelry.
disposition: Museo Nazionale Romano, Medagliere, Rome (inv.nos. 516410-516415 coins; 517911-517915)

summary: 28 coins found in the Dionysos House: 1 sestertius, 22 provincial coins, 5 undocumented coins: Septimius Severus/Caracalla (Julia Domna) - Philip I (AD 244-249).
See hoard IARCH-4FC580 for details of the find. This record has been created for the coins from pot 2.

Six coins were found together with the artefacts of this hoard: Domitian bronze coin, Trajan (1 sestertius, 1 dupondius), Hadrian 1 sestertius, Antoninus Pius 1 dupondius, Postumus 1 antoninianus (radiate). The Chaourse Treasure is made up of 39 objects in total, all of which are silver apart from five small vessels and a silvered bronze mirror. There are four large serving platters; one of which has the swastika in its central medallion, another has a gilded figure of the Roman god Mercury holding his caduceus flanked by a ram and a cockerel. In addition, there are plain silver drinking cups, various jugs, two large situlas one of which has an acanthus-scroll frieze, shallow plates, hemispherical bowls (one of which was used for washing hands), flanged and fluted bowls (some with engraved decoration of animals amid floral patterns), some mirrors, an ornate strainer with floral and geometric designs, a statuette of the deity Fortuna and a pepper-pot in the shape of an African slave-boy. (Wikipedia)

Forger's hoard of 121 coinsand blanks (only two coins). The finder also found a fragment of copper alloy rod, a sherd of courseware pottery and a brooch. It is possible, but by no means certain that the hoard was secreted in a pot, but the surviving rim comes from a vessel much larger than was needed to contain the coins and other objects.
